Correct Answer: B) Arnold’s nerve

Explanation:

  • The Arnold’s nerve, also known as the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, is responsible for the syncopal episode during ear syringing. This nerve provides sensory innervation to the external auditory canal. Stimulation of Arnold’s nerve during ear wax removal can lead to a reflex vagal response, causing bradycardia, hypotension, and, in some cases, a syncopal episode (vasovagal syncope).

Incorrect Options:

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option A): The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory innervation to parts of the ear and temporal region. However, it does not have a vagal connection and is not involved in reflex syncopal episodes.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option C): The glossopharyngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx and posterior one-third of the tongue. While it can be involved in reflexes like gagging, it is not responsible for vagal responses during ear syringing.

Jacobson’s nerve (Option D): Jacobson’s nerve, a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, supplies the tympanic plexus in the middle ear. It is not involved in the vagal reflex responsible for syncope during ear wax removal.

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have noticed their daughter often staring blankly, which is sometimes associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she did not have a problem with maintaining posture, nor were there generalised tonic and clonic movements. The child's EEG is given below. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Sodium valproate

  • The symptoms described (blank staring, chewing movements, daydreaming, and EEG findings) are consistent with absence seizures, a type of generalised seizure.
  • Sodium valproate is a first-line agent for treating absence seizures. It works by increasing the availability of neurotransmitters and stabilizing the electrical activity in the brain.

Absence Seizures:

  • They are generally seen in children aged 5 to 15 years.
  • A classic EEG finding of a 3-Hz spike and wave discharges is found.
  • Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures. It blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • Valproate is the DOC in atypical absence seizures.
  • Phenytoin (Option B) and Carbamazepine (Option A) are contraindicated in the Absence seizures.

Clonazepam (Option D) is a benzodiazepine that can be used for seizures, but it is not typically first-line for absence seizures and is usually used in cases of refractory seizures.

questions.text: A 55 year old shipbuilding worker presents with dyspnea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Malignant mesothelioma

Explanation:

Malignant mesothelioma is a tumor of mesothelial cells. It is the most specific malignancy seen in asbestosis

Workers in the shipbuilding and construction trades, including pipe fitters and boilermakers, are occupationally exposed to asbestos.

  • Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung.
  • Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • Complications include mesothelioma and carcinoma of the lung .

Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer .
  • It is not associated with smoking.

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene- CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin.
    • Epithelial membrane antigen.
    • Cytokeratin.
    • Mesothelin.

 

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain

Coarse, partially calcified right pleural plaques, accompanied by massive right pleural effusion, causing total right lung collapse and mass effect.

Lobulated pleural soft tissue mass encasing the right lung. Associated erosion of the right 3rd rib anteriorly.

Calcified pleural plaques were noted bilaterally, indicating previous asbestos exposure.


Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option A) is the most common lung malignancy, it is not the most specific malignancy associated with asbestos exposure (shipbuilding → asbestos exposure)

questions.text: The probable diagnosis for a 60-year-old diabetic patient who is experiencing intense ear pain and otorrhea that has not improved with antibiotics, along with the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal and facial nerve paralysis, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Malignant otitis externa

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of intense ear pain, otorrhea unresponsive to antibiotics, granulation tissue in the ear canal, and facial nerve paralysis strongly suggests malignant otitis externa (MOE). MOE is a severe, life-threatening infection of the external ear and skull base, primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is most commonly seen in elderly patients, diabetics, or immunocompromised individuals. Facial nerve paralysis indicates advanced disease with cranial nerve involvement.

Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis Externa (MOE)

  • Inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas infection.
  • Commonly affects elderly diabetic patients or those on immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Severe ear pain, granulations in the ear canal, and facial paralysis are common symptoms.
  • Infection can spread to the skull base, jugular foramen, and cause multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Etiopathogenesis:

  • Early presentation mimics diffuse otitis externa but with intense pain.
  • Granulations in the ear canal indicate disease progression.
  • Infection can extend:
    • Anteriorly to the temporomandibular fossa.
    • Posteriorly to the mastoid.
    • Medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

Investigations:

  • Clinical suspicion based on severe otalgia and granulation tissue in elderly diabetics.
  • Imaging:
    • CT scan/MRI: Shows bone destruction and soft tissue involvement.
    • Gallium-67 scan: Indicates soft tissue infection; useful for diagnosis and follow-up.
    • Technetium-99 bone scan: Detects bone infection but not useful for disease monitoring due to prolonged positivity.

Treatment:

  • Control of diabetes: Essential for management.
  • Ear canal toilet: Clean the ear, remove discharge, debris, and granulations.
  • Antibiotics:
    • IV Gentamicin with Ticarcillin (both ototoxic/nephrotoxic).
    • Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime), combined with an aminoglycoside.
    • Quinolones (e.g., Ciprofloxacin 750 mg orally) can be combined with Rifampin.
    • Antibiotic therapy typically lasts 6-8 weeks or longer.
  • Culture and sensitivity of ear discharge to adjust antibiotics if non-responsive to treatment.
  • Prolonged antibiotic treatment has largely replaced the need for radical surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Otomycosis (Option A): Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear, typically presenting with itching, mild discomfort, and discharge. It does not cause severe pain, granulation tissue, or cranial nerve involvement, as seen in this case.

Serous otitis media (Option B): Serous otitis media involves non-infectious fluid accumulation in the middle ear, often following an upper respiratory infection or eustachian tube dysfunction. It does not present with otorrhea, granulation tissue, or facial nerve paralysis.

Eczematous otitis externa (Option D): Eczematous otitis externa is an inflammatory condition of the external ear, associated with itching, scaling, and mild discomfort. It does not cause granulation tissue, severe pain, or cranial nerve paralysis.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 34-year-old male who has been consuming maize as his main diet for an extended period and is now experiencing symptoms such as abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and diarrhea? Additionally, upon examination, glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) and a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas were observed, along with a lesion on his neck.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pellagra

Explanation:

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

Dermatitis:

  • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
  • Casal’s necklace - ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia.
  • The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis.
  • Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism

Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:

  • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
  • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
  • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
  • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
  • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
  • Malabsorption Syndromes

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with an 8-month history of shortness of breath and non-productive cough. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes for the past 30 years. On physical examination, clubbing is seen and fine crackles are heard on both sides during inspiration. You perform pulmonary function tests and it shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. The CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pulmonary fibrosis

Explanation:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given his symptoms such as shortness of breath, persistent nonproductive cough, clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, pulmonary function tests, and imaging findings.
  • The CT image shows the presence of honeycombing (black arrows), traction bronchiectasis (white arrow), and a reticular pattern (black dotted arrows). The lesions are typically located along subpleural regions.
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common cause of interstitial lung disease (ILD) of unknown cause. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades. Men are affected more commonly than women. PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis show a restrictive pattern. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural), bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion,including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following medications can lead to the development of gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that has anti-androgenic effects, which can lead to gynecomastia. This is due to its ability to block androgen receptors and inhibit testosterone synthesis.

Drugs causing Gynecomastia:

  • Alcohol, marijuana, heroin
  • Spironolactone
  • Risperidone
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Cimetidine
  • Digoxin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Metoclopramide
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Phenytoin therapy
  • Bromocriptine
  • Finasteride

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Promotes fibrinolysis

  • Alteplase is a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) that promotes fibrinolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which in turn breaks down fibrin in blood clots.

Fibrinolytic Drugs (Thrombolytics)

  

Mechanism

Activate plasminogen to plasmin via tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA)→ digests fibrin →lyse thrombi to recanalize occluded blood vessels, primarily coronary arteries.

  
 

Examples

  • Streptokinase (not in use)
  • Urokinase (not in use)
  • Alteplase
  • Reteplase
  • Tenecteplase

 

Uses
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
    • The chief indication is for STEMI.
    • Not indicated for unstable angina (UA) and low-risk NSTEMI.
    • Alternative to emergency PCI.
  • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
  • Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
    • Indicated for large, life-threatening PE
  • Peripheral Arterial Occlusion
    • Indicated when surgical thrombectomy is not possible.
  • Stroke (Ischemic Stroke)
    • Alteplase is approved
    • Contraindicated after 4.5 hours of symptom onset due to increased intracranial hemorrhage risk.

 

Contraindications

  • History of intracranial hemorrhage.
  • History of ischemic stroke in the past 3 months.
  • History of head injury in the past 3 months.
  • Intracranial tumor/vascular abnormality/aneurysms.
  • Active bleeding/bleeding disorders.
  • Patients on anticoagulants.
  • Peptic ulcer, esophageal varices.
  • Recent wound, fracture, or tooth extraction.
  • Major surgery within the past 3 weeks.
  • Uncontrolled hypertension.
  • Pregnancy.

 

Inhibits Vitamin K-dependent factors (Option A) is characteristic of anticoagulants like warfarin, which inhibit the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Alteplase does not work by inhibiting these factors.

Inhibits factor X (Option B) is the action of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) like rivaroxaban or apixaban. Alteplase does not target Factor X; instead, it activates plasminogen to plasmin to break down fibrin.

Activation of thrombin (Option D) is involved in clot formation by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. Alteplase does not activate thrombin. Instead, it promotes fibrinolysis by activating plasminogen, which cleaves fibrin and dissolves clots.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound compressing the swelling. X-ray of the neck is seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a professional trumpet blower with a swelling on the side of the neck, associated with a gurgling sound upon compression, strongly suggests a laryngocele. A laryngocele is an abnormal air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that can communicate with the laryngeal lumen. It is often seen in individuals who engage in activities requiring frequent or high-pressure breathing, such as wind instrument players or glassblowers.
  • Key clinical features of a laryngocele:
    • Swelling in the neck that may increase in size with activities like blowing.
    • Gurgling sound or fluctuation on palpation if it contains mucus or air.
    • Can present as an internal, external, or mixed type (external is visible as a neck swelling).

Incorrect Options:

Pharyngeal pouch (Option A): Typically presents with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and a swelling that may gurgle but is located posterior to the pharynx. It is not associated with trumpet blowing or activities requiring forced expiration.

Trachea-oesophageal fistula (Option C): This is a congenital or acquired condition presenting with recurrent aspiration, coughing, and feeding difficulties. It does not cause a compressible neck swelling or gurgling sound.

Tonsillar cyst (Option D): This would present as a localized swelling near the tonsillar region without the gurgling sound or association with forced expiratory activities.

questions.text: In patients affected by COVID-19, which of the following patterns is frequently observed in chest CT scans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ground glass opacity

Explanation:

  • Ground Glass Opacities (GGO) towards the periphery are the earliest manifestation in COVID 19. Crazy pavement pattern and reverse halo sign is also noticed. GGOs are hazy areas with slightly increased density without obscuration of underlying bronchial and vascular margins.

CT Findings in Covid 19:

  • Common Findings: Ground-glass opacities (GGO), consolidation, and reticulations.
  • Characteristic Patterns: Bilateral peripheral and lower lobe predominance; features may resemble organizing pneumonia.
  • A reversed halo sign, halo sign, reticulations, and nodules are uncommon and usually appear later.
  • Other atypical findings can include cavitation, isolated lobar or segmental consolidation, lymphadenopathy, pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, and pleural effusions.

Chest X-ray (CXR) Findings:

  • Bilateral peripheral and basal multifocal airspace opacities (ground-glass opacities (GGO) and consolidation)

Imaging and Assessment:

  • CO-RADS assesses the level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 based on unenhanced chest CT findings.
  • The level of suspicion increases from very low (CO-RADS category 1) to very high (CO-RADS category 5)

CO-RADS

Suspicion Level

CT findings

CO-RADS 0

 

Technically inadequate

CO-RADS 1

No

Normal or non-infectious abnormalities

CO-RADS 2

Low

Abnormalities consistent with infections other than Covid-19

CO-RADS 3

Indeterminate

Unclear whether covid-19 is present

CO-RADS 4

High

Abnormalities suspicious for covid-19

CO-RADS 5

Very high

Typical covid-19

CO-RADS 6

PCR+

 

Diagnosis: Confirmed through positive reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)

Interlobular septal thickening (Option A) and Crazy paving pattern (Option D) is seen in pulmonary alveolar proteinosis

questions.text: Which one of the following choices does not represent a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glycolysis

Explanation:

Glucagon is a hormone produced by the alpha cells of the pancreas that primarily increases blood glucose levels, especially during fasting or low glucose states.

  • It achieves this by stimulating processes that increase glucose availability and energy production.
  • Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy (ATP).
  • Glucagon inhibits glycolysis in the liver to conserve glucose and promote the release of glucose into the bloodstream.
  • Instead of promoting glucose breakdown, glucagon promotes glucose production and release.

Gluconeogenesis (Option B): Stimulates the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources (amino acids, lactate) in the liver.

Glycogenolysis (Option C): Stimulates the breakdown of glycogen into glucose in the liver to release glucose into the bloodstream.

Ketogenesis (Option D): Stimulates the production of ketone bodies in the liver from fatty acids during periods of prolonged fasting or carbohydrate restriction.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not considered safe for a pregnant woman diagnosed with extensively drug-resistant TB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Kanamycin

  • Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside and is generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to its potential to cause fetal harm, including ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

Antibiotics safe in pregnancy:

  • Penicillin group
  • Cephalosporins
  • Erythromycin
  • Metronidazole (Except 1st trimester)

Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy:

  • Tetracycline
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Metronidazole (First trimester)
  • Fluoroquinolones

questions.text: What would be the subsequent course of treatment for a child with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss who did not experience any improvement after using hearing aids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cochlear implant

Explanation:

  • For a child with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) who has not experienced improvement with hearing aids, a cochlear implant is the next appropriate step. A cochlear implant bypasses the damaged parts of the cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, enabling hearing in individuals with severe-to-profound SNHL who derive limited or no benefit from conventional hearing aids.
  • Cochlear implantation is recommended in cases where:
    • Hearing aids provide insufficient benefit.
    • The patient has severe-to-profound SNHL as confirmed by audiological assessments.
    • Speech and language development is at risk due to hearing impairment (especially in children).

Indications:

  • B/L severe (70-90 dB) to profound (>90 dB) SNHL
  • Prelingual deafness: A child who is born deaf and has not yet developed speech.
  • Post lingual deafness: Child/adult who has become deaf but has already developed speech.

Contraindications:

  • Cochlear aplasia
  • 8th nerve abnormality (like aplasia or retrocochlear pathology, conduction via the auditory nerve is dysfunctional)
  • Central auditory lesions
  • Michel aplasia: Complete absence of the bony and membranous labyrinth, including the petrous apex, while the external and middle ears remain unaffected.

Prerequisites:

  • Age in prelingual deafness: Minimum age as early as possible, maximum age 7 years
  • There is no age limit for post-lingual deafness
  • Failed trial of hearing aid
  • Intact acoustic nerve and central hearing tract

Incorrect Options:

Bone-anchored hearing aid (Option A): This is suitable for patients with conductive or mixed hearing loss, or those with anatomical issues preventing the use of regular hearing aids (e.g., chronic otitis media, atresia). It is not appropriate for severe-to-profound SNHL.

Tympanoplasty (Option B): Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure to repair the tympanic membrane or middle ear structures and is used in conductive hearing loss, not in sensorineural hearing loss.

Normal hearing aid (Option C): The child has already tried hearing aids without improvement. Recommending a different hearing aid would not be beneficial in cases of severe-to-profound SNHL.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain, easy fatigability, and a past history of multiple urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. His ESR is elevated, x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following investigations is useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serum electrophoresis

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation and x-ray features are suggestive of multiple myeloma. Screening tests for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

  • Serum protein electrophoresis > urine protein electrophoresis - Shows spike in monoclonal M-protein

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia which is depicted by uncontrolled proliferation of cells or bone marrow. The skull x-ray reveals Raindrop configuration of Lytic lesions of the skull which is a characteristic feature for multiple myeloma.

  • Diagnostic modalities include hypercalcaemia, creatinine > 2 mg and Bence Jones protein is typical in Urine analysis.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%, often >30% of cellularity
    • Flame cells: Fiery red cytoplasm.
    • Mott cells: Contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets.
    • Russell bodies: Globular cytoplasmic inclusions.
    • Dutcher bodies: Globular nuclear inclusions.

        Mott cells: Russell bodies seen within the cytoplasm as vesicles

questions.text: In patients with indications for warfarin usage, what is the recommended range of INR in a patient with mechanical heart valves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 2.5-3.5

  • The recommended International Normalized Ratio (INR) range for patients with mechanical heart valves is typically 2.5 to 3.5. This range helps to balance the risk of thromboembolism (clot formation) and bleeding complications associated with warfarin therapy.
  • Warfarin therapy is monitored using prothrombin time, as it is sensitive to reductions in prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X levels. The International Normalized Ratio (INR) is used to standardize prothrombin time results.

1.0-1.5 (Option A): This INR range is too low to achieve the desired therapeutic effect of warfarin.

2.0-3.0 (Option B): For patients on regular warfarin therapy, the recommended INR range is typically between 2.0 and 3.0.

3.5-4.5 (Option D): An INR above 3.5 is generally not recommended, as it significantly increases the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the deficiency causing classical galactosemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

Explanation:

Classical galactosemia is a genetic metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

  • This enzyme is essential for the proper metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

Role of GALT in Galactose Metabolism:

  • GALT converts galactose-1-phosphate to UDP-galactose, which is required for various biochemical processes, including the synthesis of glycoproteins and glycolipids.
  • A deficiency in GALT leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactose in tissues, which can cause toxicity and damage to the liver, kidneys, and brain, leading to the symptoms of classical galactosemia.

Clinical Features of Classical Galactosemia:

  • Failure to thrive and jaundice in the neonatal period after feeding with milk.
  • Liver damage, cataracts, intellectual disability, and sepsis from E. coli infections (due to impaired immune function).

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated galactose-1-phosphate in red blood cells.
  • Genetic testing for mutations in the GALT gene.

Treatment:

  • Lactose-free diet (avoiding galactose) to prevent the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites.

Aldose reductase (Option A): Involved in the reduction of galactose to galactitol, which is implicated in galactose toxicity but is not the enzyme deficient in classical galactosemia.

Galactokinase (Option B): Deficiency causes galactokinase deficiency or non-classical galactosemia, which leads to cataract formation but does not cause the systemic effects seen in classical galactosemia (liver damage, intellectual disability).

UDP-galactose-4-epimerase (Option D): Deficiency causes epimerase-deficient galactosemia, a less common form of galactosemia with milder symptoms than classical galactosemia.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent stages in the vitamin D metabolism necessitates exposure to sunlight?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol

 

Explanation:

The conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) is the stage in vitamin D metabolism that requires exposure to sunlight.

 

This reaction occurs in the skin under the influence of UVB radiation from sunlight.

  • 7-dehydrocholesterol is a compound found in the skin, and when exposed to UVB light, it is converted to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3).

 

Vitamin D Metabolism:

  • Skin (sunlight exposure): 7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) under UVB light.

 

  • Liver: Cholecalciferol is then converted to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol), the major circulating form of vitamin D.

 

  • Kidneys: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is further hydroxylated to form the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol).

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with breast cancer, who is 53 years old and also has heart failure, which medication should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Epirubicin

  • Epirubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy agent known for its potential to cause cardiotoxicity, particularly in patients with pre-existing heart conditions like heart failure. This makes it contraindicated in such patients.

Adverse effects of Epirubicin:

  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Alopecia
  • Anemia
  • Amenorrhea
  • Leukopenia
  • Diarrhea

Methotrexate (Option A) is a folate antagonist used in cancer treatment, and it does not typically cause significant cardiotoxicity. It can have other side effects, but heart failure is not a contraindication for methotrexate use.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C) is an alkylating agent used in breast cancer treatment. While it can have some cardiovascular effects, it is not as directly linked to severe cardiotoxicity as epirubicin. It is used cautiously but not avoided entirely in patients with heart failure.

Cisplatin (Option D) is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug that primarily affects kidneys and has nephrotoxic potential. It does not carry the same level of risk for cardiotoxicity as epirubicin and can be used with caution in patients with heart failure, particularly if renal function is well monitored.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Maxillary sinus

Explanation:

  • The maxillary sinus is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, located within the maxilla (upper jaw bone). It is pyramid-shaped and lies lateral to the nasal cavity, with its base forming the lateral wall of the nose and its apex extending towards the zygomatic bone. On radiographic or anatomical images, it appears as a large, air-filled cavity inferior to the orbit and lateral to the nasal cavity.
  • Key features of the maxillary sinus:
    • Largest paranasal sinus.
    • Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity through the semilunar hiatus.
    • Commonly involved in sinusitis due to the high location of its drainage opening.

The maxillary sinus or the Antrum of Highmore, is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla.

  • Shape - Pyramidal
  • Size - 15mL
  • Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose
  • Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone

Relations:

  • Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla.
  • Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meatuses and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity.
  • Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit
  • Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oro antral fistula.

Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery.

Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein.

Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes.

Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2).


Incorrect Options:

Frontal sinus (Option A): Located above the orbit in the frontal bone; appears superior to the nasal cavity and orbits in images.

Pyriform sinus (Option B): This is a structure in the hypopharynx, not a paranasal sinus. It is unrelated to the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses.

Ethmoid sinus (Option C): Consists of multiple small air cells located between the eyes, medial to the orbit, and posterior to the nasal cavity. These appear as smaller clusters on imaging.

questions.text: During a scorching summer afternoon, a man, who had been toiling in a field, unexpectedly collapsed. Upon examination, there were no apparent physical indications of dehydration, although his radial pulse was detectable. The doctor determined that the man's serum electrolyte levels were within the normal range. Shockingly, the man's body temperature measured 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Considering these circumstances, which of the following should be administered as an initial form of immediate assistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cover with cool damp sheets

Explanation:

  • The above patient seems to be suffering from a heat stroke. There are no signs of dehydration and the body temperature is quite high and the radial pulse is present. The next best step is to cover the body with cool damp sheets.

 

Epinephrine injection (Option A) can be fatal for the patient.

CPR (Option D) is not required as a steady radial pulse is perceived and the patient is not in shock.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the presence of a B tympanogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serous otitis media

Explanation:

  • A B tympanogram indicates poor middle ear compliance, which is typically associated with fluid in the middle ear as seen in serous otitis media. This flat-shaped tympanogram suggests that the middle ear is filled with fluid, preventing the eardrum from moving normally in response to changes in air pressure. It is one of the most common findings in middle ear effusion.

Incorrect Options:

Ossicular dislocation (Option A): This condition typically results in a hypercompliant tympanogram, showing an Ad curve (type Ad), rather than a flat B curve.

Otosclerosis (Option B): Otosclerosis is associated with stapes fixation and reduced middle ear compliance. It results in an As tympanogram (shallow curve) due to reduced mobility of the ossicular chain, not a flat B curve.

Normal ear (Option D): A normal ear produces a type A tympanogram, indicating normal compliance and middle ear pressure.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 50-year-old man who presents with symptoms of anemia, fever, and recurrent nosebleeds? The patient has hepatosplenomegaly and lab investigations indicate a hemoglobin level of 6g/dL, a total leukocyte count of 40,000/cu.mm with 10% blasts, and a platelet count of 12,000/cu.mm. Further investigation reveals the presence of t(8;21) in the blasts.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute myeloblastic leukemia

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis for this patient is Acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) as it has clinical and laboratory features consistent with AML and chromosomal translocation of t(8;21).
  • AML is the most common type of acute leukaemia in adults and is typically seen in the elderly. When symptomatic, clinical features are those of pancytopenia. The diagnosis is clinched by bone marrow showing >20% myeloblasts. Emergencies include hyperleukocytosis, neurologic involvement, and DIC.


Aetiology of AML:

  1. Idiopathic
  • 25-50% cases
  1. Bone Marrow Failure
  • Fanconi Anemia
  • Diamond-Blackfan Syndrome Diamond-Blackfan Anemia (DBA) is a rare inherited form of macrocytic anemia characterised by a failure of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow.
  • Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome: An autosomal recessive disorder involving exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
  1. Defective DNA Repair
  • Bloom Syndrome
  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  1. Down Syndrome
  • AML is associated with Down syndrome, particularly the subtype known as Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia (AML M7), which involves the GATA1 gene.
  1. Exposure to Anticancer Drugs

 
  • Alkylating agents -> Monosomy 5 & 7 -> AML (After 4-6 years).
  • Anticancer drugs (Topoisomerase 2 inhibitors) -> Chromosome 11 involvement -> AML (After 1-3 years).
  1. Radiation Exposure

Exposure to radiation, benzene, phenylbutazone, and chloramphenicol may increase the risk of developing AML and bone marrow failure.
  1. t(15:17)

 

Chromosomal translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion gene, which is associated with acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), a subtype of AML.
  1. t(8:21)

Chromosomal translocation (RUNX1- RUNX1T1) is associated with myeloid sarcoma.
  1. Inversion 16 or t(16;16).

-

Work up of AML:

  • Blast concentration <20% in peripheral blood/bone marrow aspiration.
  • Decreased Hb
  • Decreased platelet count
  • Decreased TLC initially

 

ALL (Option A) is the most common childhood leukaemia having symptoms such as fever, night sweats, unexplained weight loss painless lymphadenopathy bone pain which are not present here.

Pre-leukaemia (Option C) Is a myelodysplastic syndrome

Aleukemic leukaemia (Option D) Is a rare type of leukaemia in which the leucocyte count is normal or to the lower side.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman,who received steroids and remdesivir for COVID, and is now experiencing a malodorous black discharge from her nose? On examination a necrotic black mass, filling the nasal cavity and causing erosion of the septum and hard palate is found.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mucormycosis

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman with a malodorous black discharge from the nose, a necrotic black mass filling the nasal cavity, and erosion of the septum and hard palate is mucormycosis. This is a severe fungal infection caused by molds from the Mucoraceae family, often affecting immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes, receiving steroids, and having viral infections like COVID-19. Mucormycosis commonly presents with:

  • Nasal or sinus involvement (as seen with black, necrotic tissue and discharge).
  • Erosion of surrounding structures, such as the septum and palate.
  • A rapidly progressive course, especially in diabetic and immunocompromised patients.
  • Malodorous discharge due to tissue necrosis.

Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

Incorrect Options:

Aspergillosis (Option A): Aspergillosis is another fungal infection, but it typically does not present with black necrotic masses. It is more commonly associated with chronic sinusitis or allergic reactions, not with necrosis and tissue destruction seen here.

Foreign body (Option C): A foreign body might cause a localized obstruction and discharge but would not lead to the extensive necrosis and erosion of the nasal cavity, septum, and palate as described in this case.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D): Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, typically involving the nasal mucosa. It causes polypoidal growths, not necrotic black masses. It is more common in endemic areas, such as India and Sri Lanka.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a history of yellowing of the skin and eyes for 11 weeks, but he does not have any other symptoms. He had a viral infection 10 days ago and experienced a similar episode of yellowing 2 years ago for 2 weeks. Upon further questioning, he mentioned having long hours of basketball practice 2 years ago, which left him physically exhausted. His current blood tests show a serum bilirubin level of 2.4 mg/dL, with unconjugated bilirubin at 2.1 mg/dL and conjugated bilirubin at 0.3 mg/dL. His liver enzyme levels (AST and ALT) are normal. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gilbert syndrome

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis of Gilbert Syndrome as it causes mild jaundice under stressful circumstances.

Gilbert Syndrome

About
  • Gilber Gilbert Syndrome (GS) is a common, benign condition with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver function tests, affecting up to 8% of people, more common in males.

Pathophysiology
  • Caused by reduced UGT1A1 enzyme activity (10–35% of normal), often due to a TA insertion variant in the UGT1A1 promoter (A[TA]7TAA).
  • Inheritance is typically autosomal recessive with the promoter variant; some cases show dominant inheritance with other mutations.

Clinical Features

 
  • Serum bilirubin <51 μmol/L (<3 mg/dL), fluctuating with stress, fasting, alcohol, or illness; jaundice may occur during elevations.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, though jaundice can occur during episodes of elevated bilirubin levels.
  • Often diagnosed incidentally in adolescence or adulthood.

Investigations
  • Serum bilirubin levels are intermittently high, with Normal liver function tests and hepatic histology.
  • UGT1A1 gene testing may reveal the A[TA]7TAA promoter variant.

Management
  • Lifestyle adjustments, such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining regular calorie intake, may help manage bilirubin levels.
  • Phenobarbital can normalize bilirubin levels if required.
  • Caution with drugs metabolized by UGT1A1 (e.g., irinotecan, HIV protease inhibitors) due to risk of toxicity.

 

Dubin Johnson (Option A) has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown black melanin-like deposition on the liver.

Crigler Najjar type 1(Option B) presents with kernicterus and neurological damage in neonates, is characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (typically >20 mg/dL) due to the complete absence of UGT1A1 activity. Patients often exhibit significant jaundice from infancy and are at risk for kernicterus.

Rotor syndrome (Option D) is similar to Dubin Johnson syndrome but the presentation is mild and there is increased conjugated bilirubin and the liver does not have black coloured deposits.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the view that provides the optimal visualization of the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Water’s view

Explanation:

  • Water's view (also known as the occipitomental view) is the radiographic projection that provides the best visualization of the maxillary sinus. This view is obtained by having the patient tilt their head back, with the chin raised and the X-ray beam directed at the patient’s face. It allows optimal imaging of the maxillary sinus, as it projects the sinus clearly and eliminates superimposition of other structures.

 

View

Position

Purpose

Image

Waters' View (Occipitomental View)

Chin-up position.

Best view to visualize the maxillary sinus.

Pierre’s View

Similar to Waters' view but with the mouth open.

Best view to visualize the sphenoid sinus.

Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View)

Chin-down position.

Best view to visualize the frontal sinus.

Lateral View

Lateral (as the name indicates)

Allows visualization of all sinuses (frontal, maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoidal).

Helps to understand the pneumatization pattern of the sphenoid sinus.

Incorrect Options:

Towne’s view (Option B): Towne's view is used primarily for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital region, and is not specifically for the maxillary sinus.

Law’s view (Option C): Law's view is used to assess the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and not for the maxillary sinus.

Stenver’s view (Option D): Stenver’s view is used to image the petrous portion of the temporal bone and is not ideal for visualizing the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed adverse effect of orlistat among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Steatorrhea

  • Orlistat is a weight-loss medication that inhibits pancreatic and gastric lipase, leading to decreased absorption of dietary fat.
  • The most common adverse effect of orlistat is steatorrhea (fatty, oily stools), which occurs due to the unabsorbed fats passing through the gastrointestinal tract.

Acute kidney injury (Option A) is not a common side effect of orlistat. While there have been rare reports of kidney problems, they are not the most frequently observed adverse effects of orlistat.

Osteoporosis (Option B) is not a typical side effect of orlistat. However, long-term use of orlistat can interfere with the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), which may affect bone health but does not directly cause osteoporosis.

Colorectal cancer (Option D): There is no direct evidence linking orlistat use with colorectal cancer. In fact, orlistat may have a potential role in reducing the risk of colorectal cancer due to its effects on weight loss and fat absorption.

questions.text: A patient with symptoms of psychosis is prescribed aripiprazole. Which of the following best describes this drug when compared to other antipsychotic drugs?

choices.text: No intrinsic activity, high affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms, andmore weight gain
High intrinsic activity, no affinity for D2 receptor, more extrapyramidal symptoms, and less weight gain
Low intrinsic activity, high affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms, and less weight gain
High intrinsic activity, high affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms, and less weight gain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Low intrinsic activity, high affinity for D2 receptor, less extrapyramidal symptoms, and less weight gain

  • Aripiprazole is a partial agonist at the D2 receptor, which means it has low intrinsic activity.
  • It has a high affinity for D2 receptors and is known for causing fewer extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and less weight gain compared to other antipsychotics. I
  • t is considered an atypical antipsychotic with a more favourable side-effect profile.

Metabolic abnormalities associated with atypical antipsychotics:

  • Weight Gain
  • Hyperglycemia/Diabetes
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Increased Prolactin Levels
  • Electrolyte Imbalances

Metabolic risk potential:

  • Highest: Clozapine, olanzapine
  • Immediate: quetiapine, risperidone, paliperidone

Least: aripiprazole, ziprasidone, iloperidone, asenapine

questions.text: Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydrocarbons

Explanation:

Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management

  • Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations.

Timing and Effectiveness

  • Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion
  • Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases
  • Beyond 6 hours, poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy

Procedure Steps

Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Contraindications

  • Corrosive Poisoning: Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation
  • Convulsant Poisons: Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine)
  • Comatose Patients: High aspiration risk
  • Volatile Poisons/ Hydrocarbons: May cause aspiration pneumonitis
  • Risk of Hemorrhage/ Perforation: Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present
  • Additional Contraindications to Emetics
    • Severe heart or lung diseases
    • Advanced pregnancy
    • CNS depression or seizures

Complications

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternatives to Gastric Lavage

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

Incorrect Options:

Organophosphate poisoning (Option A): Gastric lavage is recommended for organophosphate poisoning (e.g., insecticides) because it can effectively remove the poison from the stomach if performed early, particularly within 1 hour of ingestion. The risks of aspiration or complications are considered manageable in this case with proper techniques.

Ethanol poisoning (Option C): Gastric lavage is recommended in cases of ethanol poisoning if it is performed within 1 hour of ingestion. Ethanol is rapidly absorbed, so the procedure is most effective if performed early. Gastric lavage may help prevent further absorption of the alcohol and reduce toxicity.

PCM (Paracetamol/Acetaminophen) toxicity (Option D): In PCM toxicity, gastric lavage is used if the patient presents within a few hours of ingestion, particularly in cases of massive overdose. It helps remove remaining drug from the stomach before it is absorbed into the bloodstream.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of chronic NSAID usage. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Peptic ulcer perforation

  • The patient presenting with diffuse abdominal pain, chronic NSAID usage, and rigidity on examination is highly suggestive of perforation of a peptic ulcer.
  • The most relevant radiological finding in this context would be free air under the diaphragm, visible on an X-ray, which is a hallmark of hollow viscus perforation.
  • Chronic NSAID use increases the risk of developing peptic ulcers, which can perforate and lead to peritonitis, presenting with abdominal rigidity and pain.

Adverse effects of NSAIDs

System

Side effects

Additional information

Gastrointestinal

Nausea and vomiting

Selective COX-2 inhibitors: Less likely to cause GI side effects

GI hemorrhage, erosion, Ulcers

Due to ↓prostaglandin synthesis, leading to loss of mucosal protection

Hematological

Platelet dysfunction → Increased bruising and hemorrhage risk

From reduced thromboxane A2 activity

Renal
  • Renal dysfunction/failure
  • Reduction in efficacy of loop diuretics & antihypertensives
  • Salt and water retention
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Renal papillary necrosis
  • Interstitial nephritis
  • Analgesic nephropathy

Analgesic nephropathy leads to renal failure with papillary necrosis and chronic interstitial nephritis, which is less common since the ban of phenacetin.

 

Cardiovascular
  • Precipitate heart failure
  • Edema

Hepatic
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Hepatic failure

Hypersensitivity

 
  • Urticaria
  • Flushing
  • Anaphylaxis

Dermatological
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome
  • Photosensitivity

questions.text: Which confirmatory test is utilized by forensic experts to establish the presence of a bloodstain at a crime scene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spectroscopic test

Explanation:

  • Spectroscopic tests, such as mass spectrometry, are used for high-sensitivity and specific detection of bloodstains. They analyze components like hemoglobin or lipids in the blood, offering reliable results for confirming blood presence at a crime scene.

Confirmatory Tests for Blood Stains in Forensic Medicine

  • Confirmatory tests are critical for identifying blood presence and origin in forensic investigations.
  • Methods include chemical, immunological, and mass spectrometry techniques for reliable results.

Chemical Confirmatory Tests

Test

Description

Takayama Test

Detects hemoglobin by forming red, feathery crystals of pyridine ferroprotoporphyrin.

Teichmann Test

Converts hemoglobin to hemin, creating brownish-yellow rhomboid crystals, confirming blood presence.

Immunological Tests

Test

Description

Precipitin Test

Identifies species origin through antibody-antigen reactions, using antisera specific to human blood.

HemaTrace Test

Uses monoclonal antibodies to detect human hemoglobin, showing a visible pink band for confirmation.

Mass Spectrometry Techniques

  • Thread Spray Mass Spectrometry: Analyzes whole blood directly on textiles, differentiating species based on lipid composition and hemoglobin chains. It offers high sensitivity and specificity.

Incorrect Options:

Kastle-Meyer test (Option B) is a presumptive test used to detect the presence of hemoglobin. It involves adding a reagent that causes a color change in the presence of blood. Although useful for initial screening, it is not a confirmatory test as it can yield false positives from other substances like plant peroxidases.

Benzidine test (Option C): This was historically used as a presumptive test for detecting blood, relying on benzidine reacting with hemoglobin in the blood. However, the test is now outdated and largely replaced by more sensitive and safer methods. It is no longer used in forensic investigations due to health concerns related to benzidine's carcinogenic properties.

Orthotoluidine test (Option D) is another presumptive test that detects the presence of blood by reacting with hemoglobin. It is similar to the Benzidine test but has the same limitations of not being confirmatory. Like the Kastle-Meyer test, it can lead to false positives, making it unsuitable as a definitive test for blood.

questions.text: Which of the options below acts as a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist in medical practice?
questions.solution:
Answer C - Prazosin:

  • Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It selectively blocks alpha-1 receptors, leading to vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure.

Phenoxybenzamine (option A): Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective alpha blocker that blocks both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors. It is primarily used for managing pheochromocytoma but is not selective for alpha-1 receptors.

Phentolamine (option B): Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha blocker that also blocks both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors. It is used in the treatment of pheochromocytoma and acute hypertension but is not selective for alpha-1 receptors.

Idazoxan (option D): Idazoxan is an alpha-2 receptor antagonist, not an alpha-1 receptor antagonist, and is used primarily in research settings.

questions.text: In the scenario provided, what is the probable diagnosis for a patient who ceased drinking alcohol for three days and subsequently exhibited symptoms such as irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and changes in consciousness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Delirium tremens

  • The symptoms are consistent with delirium tremens (DTs), which is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs within 48-72 hours after the last drink.
  • Symptoms include delirium, confusion, disorientation, hallucinations (tactile & visual), delusions, agitation, and autonomic hyperactivity.

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

Wernicke encephalopathy (Option B). is an acute neurologic disorder characterized by ataxia, vestibular dysfunction, confusion, and a variety of ocular motility abnormalities.

Korsakoff syndrome (Option C) is a chronic neurologic disorder characterized by impaired mental syndrome and anterograde amnesia in an alert and responsive patient.

In Alcohol-Induced Psychosis (Option D), patients experience auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions. The clear sensorium is a distinctive feature.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old female who exhibits abrupt palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a sensation of being choked? She contracted COVID-19 a year ago and is worried about her life due to her prior positive status. All physical examinations, ECG, and laboratory tests have yielded no significant findings. This episode, lasting approximately 20 minutes, is the first occurrence of its kind.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Panic attack.

  • A panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehension that may last from minutes to hours. In this case, fear of death from COVID-19 infection triggered the panic attack. Patients can feel physical symptoms like choking, palpitations, chest discomfort, nausea or git discomfort, sweating, etc.

Panic Disorder

  • It is the recurrent, acute, intense attack of anxiety accompanied by a feeling of impending doom.
  • More common in females than males.
  • Median age of onset: Late adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Familial risk: Highest for early-onset panic disorder.
  • Patients with panic disorder commonly have agoraphobia
  • Panic attacks for more than a month are termed as a Panic disorder.
  • Neurotransmitters that are implicated in the development of panic disorders are norepinephrine, Serotonin, GABA, and Cholecystokinin.

Symptoms:

Panic attacks
  • Unexpected, i.e., not restricted to any particular situation.
  • Usually last for 20 to 30 minutes, rarely, they may last more than one hour.

Cardiopulmonary
  • Feeling short of breath
  • Palpitations (Option A ruled out)
  • Chest discomfort (Option C ruled out)

Gastrointestinal
  • Nausea
  • GI discomfort

Skin and systemic

 
  • Sweating
  • Chills
  • Feeling flushed

Neurologic

 
  • Tremors
  • Dizziness
  • Numbness and tingling sensation

Psychiatric

 
  • Derealization
  • Depersonalization
  • Fear of losing control
  • Fear of dying (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms are random and unpredictable.
  • The patient is free from anxiety symptoms in between attacks.
  • Anticipatory anxiety: Fearing further attacks. Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety or panic.
  • Unpredictable Physiologic symptoms.
  • Avoidance behaviours: Trying to avoid real or imagined triggers to prevent another attack.

Treatment: Pharmacological, psychological, and combined treatments.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Drug of choice: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI).
  • Other first-line: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) venlafaxine. Second-line: Tricyclic antidepressants, MAOIs, Other Psychotropics - Agomelatine, Buspirone, Mirtazapine.
  • Benzodiazepines: Short-term use as an adjunct to SSRIs.
  • Acute phase – Benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam & Clonazepam.

Psychosocial therapies:

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal therapy.

Note: Treatment of choice: SSRIs + Psychotherapy (CBT)

Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (Option A) follows a traumatic or stressful event. Symptoms include avoidance, negative mood, and hyperarousal, which are present for more than a month.

Bipolar disorder (Option B) presents as either manic or depressive episodes. An elevated, expansive, or irritable mood is the hallmark of a manic episode. The depressive episodes are similar to those of depressive disorders.

Depression (Option C) features include a stooped posture, decreased movement, and a downward averted gaze.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 43-year-old individual who arrives at the emergency department accompanied by the police, alleging that his daughter intends to harm him, but subsequent investigation by the police reveals it to be a false accusation? The patient's physical examination does not reveal any notable findings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Delusional disorder

  • The patient's false belief that his daughter intends to harm him, despite a police investigation revealing no evidence, points to a delusional disorder.
  • It is characterised by one or more non-bizarre delusions (false beliefs about real situations) lasting for at least a month. These beliefs persist despite evidence to the contrary and are not explained by any other mental health condition.
  • Delusions are fixed false beliefs that are resistant to reason or contrary evidence and not aligned with the individual’s cultural context.

Types of delusional disorders

Type

Description

Persecutory

(Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous

(Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic

(Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose

(Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type

(Delusion of misidentification)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

Illusion (Option B) is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus, not a false perception without a stimulus. It occurs when a real object is perceived incorrectly, such as seeing a stick and mistaking it for a snake. is a disturbance of perception.it is the false perception of a real object.

Cotard’s syndrome (Option C), also known as nihilistic delusion, is a rare psychiatric disorder where the patient believes that they are dead or that their body or mind has ceased to exist. They may also deny the existence of others or the world around them, experiencing a distorted perception of reality.

Hallucination (Option D) is a false perception without any external stimulus. The individual perceives things that are not present, such as hearing voices or seeing images that don't exist. This is distinct from illusions, which involve real external objects.

questions.text: What diagnosis would you give to a 30-year-old woman who is brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend, where she claims that her boss is in love with her and stalks her, but her friend denies these allegations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Erotomania

  • Erotomanic delusion, or "passionate psychosis," involves the belief that someone, typically of higher status, is in love with the patient. Affected individuals are often socially withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited, with poor social and/or occupational functioning. A hallmark is "paradoxical conduct", where denials of affection are seen as affirmations. In males, this delusion can sometimes lead to aggression.

Types of delusional disorders

Type

Description

Persecutory

(Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous

(Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic

(Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose

(Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type

(Delusion of misidentification)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

Megalomania or delusion of grandeur (Option A): The patient believes that he has some exceptional identity or power.

Delusion of reference (Option B): The patient believes that events happening around him are somehow related to him. For example, a patient claimed that the tube light of his apartment was flickering as there was a camera fitted inside through which his movements were being recorded.

Delusion of control (Option C): The patient believes others are trying to control their thoughts or behaviours. For example: ”My doctor is trying to plant thoughts inside my head.”

questions.text: Which of the following is not a management approach used for a violent patient in psychiatry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - CBT

  • CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) is a psychotherapeutic approach that focuses on identifying and modifying negative thoughts, beliefs, and behaviours.
  • While CBT is effective in treating a wide range of psychiatric conditions, it is not typically the primary intervention for managing an acutely violent patient.
  • In the immediate management of violent behaviour, other interventions, such as medications and ensuring the safety of the patient and others, are usually prioritised.

BZD (Benzodiazepines) (Option A) are sedative medications used to manage anxiety, agitation, and acute aggression. Though not the first-line choice for violent behaviour in psychiatric patients due to their sedative effects, they can be effective in calming agitated patients and creating a safer environment.

ECT (Electroconvulsive Therapy) (Option C) involves inducing controlled seizures using electric currents to the brain and is primarily used for severe psychiatric conditions like depression, catatonia, or certain psychoses. Although not a first-line treatment for violent behaviour, it may be considered in cases of severe agitation or aggression unresponsive to other interventions, including medication.

Haloperidol (Option D). Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication commonly used in psychiatry. It belongs to the class of typical antipsychotics and is known for its sedative and antipsychotic properties. Haloperidol can be used to manage acute agitation and aggression in psychiatric patients. It is often administered in emergency settings to rapidly control violent behaviour.

questions.text: Double depression is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Depression with dysthymia

  • Double depression refers to the coexistence of dysthymia (persistent depressive disorder) and episodes of major depressive disorder (MDD).
  • Individuals experience a chronic baseline depressive state (dysthymia) with intermittent periods of more severe depression (MDD).
  • Features:
    • Persistent low mood lasting at least 2 years (dysthymia).
    • Superimposed episodes of major depressive symptoms.
    • Increased risk of disability and difficulty in treatment, as the chronic dysthymic state often persists even after resolving the major depressive episodes.

Major depressive disorder from 2 years (Option A): Although major depressive disorder can have a chronic course, the term "double depression" specifically refers to the coexistence of MDD and dysthymia, not chronic MDD alone.

Major depression with OCD (Option B): Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is characterised by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviours (compulsions). While depressive symptoms may coexist with OCD, "double depression" specifically refers to the combination of major depressive disorder and dysthymia, not OCD.

Depression with anxiety attack (Option D). While anxiety symptoms can often co-occur with depressive symptoms, the term "double depression" is not used to describe this combination.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations should be conducted in a 7-month-old child who has a hemoglobin level of 6.3, a history of recurrent blood transfusions, an MCV of 70 fl, normal MCH, normal MCHC, and a peripheral smear indicating a hypochromic microcytic image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hb electrophoresis
Explanation:

  • The above child is most probably suffering from thalassemia. The next best step is to get Hb electrophoresis done for confirmation of diagnosis. In Thalassemia, Hb electrophoresis indicates elevated levels of HbF and HbA2. It is best for identifying thalassemia minor HbA2: >3%.

Hb electrophoresis

Hemoglobin

At Birth (1st day)

At Adult (6 months)

HbF (Fetal Hemoglobin)

95%

2%

HbA (Adult Hemoglobin)

2%

95% (α2β2)

HbA2

3%

3%

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Serum iron (Option A) is measured to check for iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions and is not the next best step.

Direct coomb’s test (Option B) is for autoimmune haemolytic anemia and not for thalassemia.

Osmotic fragility test (Option C) is done for hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after an accident in which he sustained a fracture of the femur. The oxygen saturation in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Diffuse petechiae are noted on examination. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism

Explanation:

  • Fat embolism is the most likely diagnosis, given the recent trauma, respiratory distress, altered mental status, and petechial rash, which are characteristic signs of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES). Symptoms often develop within 24-72 hours following fat emboli entering circulation.

Fat Embolism Causes

Blunt trauma: Accounts for 90% of cases, especially involving extremity fractures.

 

Associated conditions:

  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Burns
  • Joint reconstruction surgeries
  • Liposuction
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Decompression sickness
  • Parenteral lipid infusion
  • Sickle cell crisis
  • Pathologic fractures

Increased risk factors (in trauma patients):

  • Age 30 years or younger
  • Closed femur fracture
  • Multiple long-bone fractures

 

Pathophysiology of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES):

  • Mechanism: Not fully understood but involves fat emboli entering circulation, usually after major trauma or surgical procedures (intramedullary nailing).
  • Pulmonary effects:
    • Fat emboli occlude microvasculature, leading to inflammatory responses and endothelial injury.
    • Pulmonary consequences mimic acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), presenting within 24 hours with symptoms of respiratory failure.
    • Fatty acids released from emboli increase vascular permeability, causing alveolar haemorrhage and oedema.
  • Systemic effects:
    • Involvement of the brain and kidneys, especially in patients with patent foramen ovale
    • Neurologic symptoms include encephalopathy and cerebral oedema due to cerebral vasculature occlusion.
    • Histopathological image

Pulmonary Embolism (PE) (Options A) can present with sudden dyspnea and hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following imaging tests should be performed to confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CT pulmonary angiography

Explanation:

  • CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries and identification of any occlusions.

Investigations for Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Clinical Evaluation

 

PE symptoms are nonspecific, often leading to excessive use of CT pulmonary angiograms. Age-adjusted d-dimer testing is recommended for patients over 50 years with low-to-moderate PE probability.

D-Dimer

A sensitive but nonspecific test for PE. Elevated levels indicate possible PE but can also occur with conditions like MI, pneumonia, or sepsis. Normal d-dimer helps rule out PE.

Electrocardiogram (ECG)

Common findings include sinus tachycardia(most common) and the S1Q3T3 sign (most specific) (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, inverted T wave in lead III). T-wave inversion in V1 to V4 suggests RV strain or ischemia.

Venous Ultrasonography

Uses loss of vein compressibility as a key indicator for diagnosing DVT, which is associated with PE. Doppler imaging can assess blood flow dynamics.

Chest X-ray

Often normal but may show specific signs like Westermark’s sign (focal oligemia), Hampton’s hump (wedge-shaped pleural density), or Palla’s sign (enlarged pulmonary artery).

Chest radiograph demonstrating focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) in the right lung (area between white arrowheads) and a prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow).

The chest radiograph demonstrates a wedge-shaped opacity (arrow) in the right middle lobe consistent with Hampton hump.

Chest CT with Contrast

 

The primary imaging test. It offers high-resolution visualisation of pulmonary vasculature. RV enlargement on CT indicates a higher risk of mortality.

Lung Scanning

A second-line test, mostly for patients who can’t tolerate contrast. High-probability perfusion scans (two or more segmental perfusion defects) strongly suggest PE.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) Imaging

MR venography with gadolinium can diagnose DVT when ultrasound is inconclusive, though MR pulmonary angiography (Option D) is less reliable for smaller PEs.

Echocardiography

It is not reliable (Option A) for directly diagnosing PE but useful for detecting mimicking conditions. McConnell’s sign (RV-free wall hypokinesis) is an indirect sign of PE.

CT Pulmonary Angiography

Identifies intraluminal filling defects or abrupt vessel occlusion.

 

Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan (Option C) can suggest the likelihood of PE by showing mismatched perfusion defects, but it is not as definitive as other imaging modalities.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of a young patient experiencing desaturation and bilateral basal crepitations shortly after undergoing surgery with general anesthesia using 02, Nitrous oxide, and Desflurane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Negative pressure pulmonary oedema

Explanation:
