  • The most likely cause of desaturation and bilateral basal crepitations in a young patient shortly after undergoing surgery with general anesthesia using O2, nitrous oxide, and desflurane is Negative Pressure Pulmonary Edema (NPPE).
  • NPPE can occur when there is significant negative intrathoracic pressure, often due to upper airway obstruction or laryngospasm post-extubation.

The presentation of Laryngospasm:

  • Chest movement with limited airflow at the mouth or nose and limited bag movement
  • Silence or stridor
  • Body movements; engorged neck veins
  • Intercostal retraction
  • Tracheal tug
  • Paradoxical breathing
  • Desaturation
  • Bradycardia
  • Cyanosis
  • Absence of ETCO2 on capnography

Extubation:

Factors associated with increased risk

Complications

  • Airway risk factors
  • Known difficult airway
  • Airway deterioration (bleeding, edema, trauma)
  • Restricted airway access
  • Obesity and obstructive sleep apnea
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Respiratory disease
  • Neuromuscular disease
  • Special surgical requirements
  • Laryngospasm
  • Bronchospasm
  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema
  • Hypoventilation
  • Aspiration
  • Paradoxical vocal cord motion
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Arytenoid dislocation

ARDS, pleural effusion, and atelectasis (Options A, B, and D): are also potential causes, but the rapid onset and specific clinical presentation of NPPE due to laryngospasm make NPPE the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was rescued from a village in Bihar where she had been sold off by her father for Rs. 25000 to a 45-year-old man. On examination, she was found to be 12 weeks pregnant. She was granted permission to abort the pregnancy, taking into consideration the age of the girl and the circumstances of her pregnancy. A doctor who will be eligible to perform the abortion for this girl should have performed at least how many MTP prior to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 25

Explanation:

Qualifications of an RMP to conduct MTP:

  • For MTP up to 12 weeks:
    • Experience of assisting in 25 MTP cases. (Options A, B, & D ruled out)
    • At least 5 cases performed independently.
    • Must be in an approved hospital by the government.
  • For MTP between 12-20 weeks:
    • Post-graduate degree/diploma in Obstetrics & Gynecology.
    • 6 months of house surgeoncy in Obstetrics & Gynecology.
    • 1 year or more of practice in Obstetrics & Gynecology at any hospital.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pain and swelling in his knee joint for 10 days. He also complains of pain and discomfort during urination. He says that he had diarrhea one month ago and he has been unwell since then. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reactive arthritis

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is reactive arthritis. It is a post-infectious autoimmune disease. The most common systems affected would be the gastrointestinal or urinary tract.

Joint involvement in different types of arthritis

Characteristics

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

Osteoarthritis (OA)

Psoriatic Arthritis

Gout

Reactive Arthritis

Joint Involvement Pattern

Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP)

Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints

Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints

Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe)

Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints

Morning Stiffness

Lasts over 1 hour

Resolves within 30 minutes

Varies, often significant

Rarely significant

Variable often follows infection

Key Symptoms

Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation)

Pain and stiffness with use

Dactylitis, nail changes

Sudden, severe pain and swelling

Joint pain following an infection

Affected Joints

MCP, PIP, wrists, knees

Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP)

MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons

Typically big toe (1st MTP joint)

Larger joints ( knees, ankles)

Radiographic Findings

Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing

Osteophytes, joint space narrowing

Erosions, possible nail changes

Erosions and tophi possible

Similar to RA but typically larger joints

 

Enteropathic arthritis (Option B) Is a spondyloarthropathy that is associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis. It typically causes sacroiliitis and spondylitis and involves peripheral joints.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C) is seen in mostly young females and presents with painful tender joints. PIP and MCP are affected symmetrically in bilateral limbs. Patients experience morning stiffness and the hallmark feature is flexor tenosynovitis. Swan neck deformity and Boutonnière deformity is also seen.

Psoriatic arthritis (Option D) is associated with a chronic inflammatory skin disorder. Psoriasis causes inflammatory arthritis and primarily affects the hands, feet, or spine.

questions.text: A 20 year old male was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45. He has a long face, large ears, large testis and a cardiac murmur and history of poor intellectual function is present in the paternal family. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fragile X syndrome

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis for this patient is Fragile X syndrome. It is the second most common cause of mental retardation whereas Down’s syndrome is the most common cause. Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant disease due to CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion.

Fragile X Syndrome

Genetic Basis

CGG repeats on FMR-1 (Familial mental retardation) gene on X chromosome

CGG Repeat Numbers
  • Normal population: 5-55 repeats
  • Carriers (premutation): 55-200 repeats
  • Fragile X Syndrome: >200 repeats

Gender Prevalence
  • More common in males
  • Females mostly carriers

Clinical Features
  • Long face and large ears
  • Large mandible/Prominent jaw
  • High arched palate
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Macroorchidism (seen in adolescent age group)
  • Intellectual disability

Clinical features of female carriers

  • May be associated with premature ovarian failure
  • 10% may have an intellectual disability/low IQ


 

Cushing syndrome (Option A) presents with acne, hirsutism, thin skin, delayed wound healing, anxiety, irritability, depression are seen along with involvement of musculoskeletal, endocrine and metabolic systems.

Rett syndrome(Option B) presents with autistic-like behaviors, breathing irregularities, feeding and swallowing difficulties, growth retardation, and seizures.

Williams syndrome(Option D) is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems.

questions.text: From the dense vegetation near the highway, the police have found the remains of a burnt body. The location was discovered with the help of a sniffer dog, as they were tracing a 25-year-old IT worker who had gone missing the night before. To determine the identity of the victim, the team needs to gather a suitable sample. Which type of tissue from a charred body is most effective for identification purposes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Teeth

Explanation:

  • Teeth are highly resistant to heat and decomposition, making them the most effective tissue for identification in burnt or charred bodies. Dental records can provide age, sex, race, and other identifying features.

Medicolegal Applications of Dental Profiling

  • Identification:
    • Dental identification is crucial for identifying unknown, burnt, charred, mutilated, or decomposed bodies, especially in mass disasters.
    • Useful for individuals without proper records in developing countries.
  • Age Estimation: Teeth help estimate the age of an individual.
  • Identification of Characteristics: Teeth can reveal race, sex, occupation, and habits (e.g., betel nut chewing or smoking).
  • Grievous Hurt: Fractured or dislocated teeth qualify as grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC.
  • Teeth can reveal signs of lead poisoning or phossy jaw long after death.
  • Dentures with names or codes assist in identifying individuals.
  • Criminal Identification: Bite marks on tissues or foodstuffs can help identify criminals.

Incorrect Options:

Hair (Option A): While hair can sometimes be used for DNA analysis, it is not as resistant to heat or fire damage as teeth, making it less effective for identification in charred bodies.

Bone (Option B): Bone can be useful for identification in some cases, but it may not provide as much detail as teeth, especially when teeth remain intact in the face of high heat.

Blood (Option D): Blood is rarely useful in cases of burnt bodies due to its destruction in the fire. It does not survive the intense heat and would not be available for analysis.

questions.text: What is the treatment of Grade I Meningioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surgical excision

Explanation:

  • Meningiomas are the most common benign tumors seen in adults and originate from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. The treatment of grade 1 meningioma is surgical excision.
  • In Grade 2 and grade 3, radiotherapy (Option D) is employed in addition to surgical excision.

Meningioma

  • Meningioma is a primary CNS tumor, originating in the brain or spinal cord. Most common type of primary brain tumor, but high grade meningiomas (Grade 2 and 3) are rare. Diagnosis often requires tumor biopsy.

Cause: Mostly due to genetic mutations

Risk factors:

    • Radiation exposure (especially in childhood)
    • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (genetic disorder)
    • Age > 60

Grades of Meningioma:

  • Grade 1 (Low Grade):
    • Slow-growing, most common grade, more common in females whereas Grade 2 and 3 are more common in males.
  • Grade 2 (Atypical, Mid-Grade):
    • Higher recurrence risk
    • Subtypes:
      • Chordoid
      • Clear cell
  • Grade 3 (Anaplastic, Malignant):
    • Fast-growing, aggressive
    • Subtypes:
      • Papillary
      • Rhabdoid

Origin and Spread:

  • Originates in dura mater (outer brain and spinal cord covering).
  • Grade 2 meningiomas can invade nearby bone tissue.
  • Grade 3 meningiomas can spread to the brain and other organs.

Symptoms:

  • Depends on location but may include:
    • Vision changes
    • Hearing/smell loss
    • Confusion
    • Seizures
    • Morning headaches

MRI Appearance:

  • Grade 2 and 3 meningioma appear as an enhancing mass along the outer brain lining.
  • May brighten with contrast on MRI scans.

Treatment:

Grade 1: Surgery is main treatment of choice

Grade 2 and 3 : Surgery followed by post-surgery treatment (Option C, D):

    • Radiation
    • Chemotherapy
    • Clinical trials (e.g., targeted therapy, immunotherapy).

questions.text: Which of the following foods is not included in the DASH diet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rich in sodium

Explanation:

  • The DASH diet (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) recommends limiting the intake of sodium, as high sodium consumption is associated with increased blood pressure. The DASH diet suggests reducing the use of table salt and avoiding processed foods that are typically high in sodium, such as fast food, canned soups, and salty snacks.

DASH-type dietary plan:

  • A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content.
  • Diet is also rich in potassium (Option A), calcium (Option B), and magnesium (Option D).

DASH Diet

  • Originated in the 1990s through NIH-funded research, found to lower systolic BP by 6-11 mm Hg. It promotes fruits, vegetables, lean meats, and low sodium (~1500 mg/day) and encourages fresh, minimally processed food.

Key Nutrients in DASH diet:

  • Carbohydrates: Whole grains, legumes, leafy greens.
  • Fats: Healthy fats (olive oil, nuts, omega-3 fish), avoid trans fats.
  • Proteins: Plant-based proteins preferred, lean meats, low-fat dairy.
  • Electrolytes:
    • Potassium: Helps lower BP, prevents muscle cramps, and supports heart function. Sources: bananas, oranges, spinach, beans.
    • Sodium: DASH limits sodium to ~1500 mg/day to reduce hypertension risk.
    • Calcium: Essential for bone health and muscle function. Sources: dairy, leafy greens.
    • Magnesium: Aids blood vessel relaxation and BP control. Sources: whole grains, nuts, seeds.

Clinical Significance of DASH diet:

  • Lowers BP, blood glucose, LDL, triglycerides, and insulin resistance.
  • Helps with metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and heart failure.
  • Linked to reduced risk of colorectal cancer, liver disease, and celiac disease.
  • Reduces hospitalization and mortality in heart failure patients.
  • Meets ADA recommendations for diabetes management.

questions.text: Death registration in India done within?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 21 days

Explanation:

  • According to the Births and Deaths Registration Act in India, any birth or death occurring in a hospital, medical institution, or at home must be reported to the concerned authorities within 21 days.

Birth and Death Registration in India

  • Government/Private Hospitals/Nursing Homes/Medical Institutions: The head of the institution must report births and deaths to the concerned Registrar within 21 days.
  • Homes: The head of the family or any family member must report births and deaths to the Sub Registrar within 21 days.

Incorrect Options:

28 days, 30 days, & 40 days (Options B, C, & D): This is not the correct time frame. Registration must happen within 21 days for compliance with the law.

questions.text: The mask given below works on which of the following principles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bernoulli principle

Explanation:

  • The picture depicts a High Flow Venturi mask that uses Bernoulli’s principle to deliver a predetermined and fixed oxygen concentration to the patient.
  • This principle states that as the velocity of a fluid (in this case, oxygen) increases, the pressure within the fluid decreases.
    • The mask uses this principle to entrain room air when pure oxygen is delivered through a small orifice, resulting in a high-velocity jet.
    • This creates a predictable and controlled oxygen concentration that is delivered to the patient​

Venturi Mask:

Is a high-flow device with fixed performance that delivers a precise concentration of oxygen (FiO₂) by mixing oxygen with ambient air at specific flow rates, typically ranging from 2 to 15 L/min. It is often used in patients requiring controlled oxygen therapy, such as those with COPD.

Color coding of Venturi mask

Color

FiO2

Require Flow rate (L/min)

Blue

24%

4

White

28%

4

Orange

31%

6

Yellow

35%

8

Red

40%

8

Green

60%

12

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Bohr effect (Option A): describes how hemoglobin's oxygen-binding affinity decreases in response to increased levels of carbon dioxide and decreased pH, facilitating oxygen release to tissues. This physiological phenomenon pertains to blood gas exchange

Boyle's principle (Option B): states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at a constant temperature.

Mapleson’s circuits (Option D): are Semi-closed types of Breathing circuits used during anesthesia to deliver oxygen and anesthetic agents and effectively washout CO2.

questions.text: A patient has presented with features of cardiac tamponade. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

Explanation:

  • Cardiac tamponade refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which puts pressure on the heart and impairs its ability to pump effectively. Jugular veins column distending without pulsations is a characteristic finding in cardiac tamponade. Due to the increased pressure in the pericardial sac, the jugular veins become visibly distended, but the normal pulsations with each heartbeat are diminished or absent.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Beck's triad
  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other Clinical features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg. It is present in most of the conditions but not always(Option A) and can vary depending on the severity of tamponade and other factors.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Kussmaul sign refers to an abnormal rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration. It is not specific to cardiac tamponade (Option B) and can be seen in various cardiac and respiratory conditions. It is not always present in cardiac tamponade.

The A wave represents atrial contraction on the jugular venous pulse waveform. In cardiac tamponade, the elevated pressure in the pericardial sac can impair atrial filling, leading to a reduced or absent A wave rather than a tall A wave (Option C).

questions.text: The most reliable criteria among Gustafson's criteria for age estimation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Translucency of root

Explanation:

Gustafson's Method:

Developed by Gosta Gustafson, this method estimates age by evaluating six specific regressive changes in teeth:

  1. Attrition (A): Wear of the occlusal surface due to chewing, starting with enamel and progressing to dentin and pulp. (Option D ruled out)
  2. Periodontosis (P): Retraction of the gums, exposing the root and neck of the tooth, leading to loosening. (Option B ruled out)
  3. Secondary Dentin (S): Gradual deposition in the pulp cavity, reducing its size and potentially obliterating it.
  4. Cementum Apposition (C): Thickening of cementum around the root as the tooth shifts in position, with continuous deposition forming incremental lines.
  5. Root Resorption (R): Degradation of cementum and dentin at the root apex, progressing upwards. (Option A ruled out)
  6. Root Transparency: Increased transparency in the root due to rarefaction of dentin, beginning from the apex and moving upward in lower teeth, and downward in upper teeth. This is considered the most reliable of all criteria. (Option C) (Option A, B, & D ruled out)

Each change is scored from 0 to 3, and the total score (Y) is used in the formula for age estimation.

  • 0- No change
  • 1- Beginning of change
  • 2- Obvious change
  • 3- Maximum change

A + P + S + C + R + T = total score (Y)

An increase in age shows a linear increase in the total score. The age is estimated using the following formula:

Age = 11.43 + 4.56 × Y (total score)

 

  • The method is most accurate for individuals between 25–60 years old.
  • It requires extracting and microscopically examining a longitudinal section of the tooth, limiting its use to deceased individuals or skeletal remains.

questions.text: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

choices.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

Explanation:

  • Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa is the first postmortem change that happens, typically within 24–48 hours after death. It results from the breakdown of red blood cells and the release of hemoglobin, which reacts with the tissue and gives a greenish hue. The right iliac fossa is where the large intestine is located, and the green discoloration indicates the onset of decomposition, particularly the production of hydrogen sulfide by bacteria in the intestines.

Decomposition:

  • Decomposition is the biological process by which organic substances break down into simpler matter, critical for recycling nutrients in ecosystems.
  • It occurs through two main mechanisms: Autolysis and Putrefaction.

Autolysis

Putrefaction

Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death.

 

Characteristics of Autolysis:

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture.

Examples of Autolytic Changes:

  • Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown.
  • Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis.

Note:

Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement.

Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.
  5. Timing of Discoloration:
    • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

Incorrect Options:

Maggot formation (Option A) occurs during the later stages of decomposition. Maggot infestation usually begins a few hours after death, but it's not the first change that happens in the body. This is a sign of decomposition, but it does not occur immediately after death.

Putrefaction (Option B) is the process of decay caused by bacterial action, which begins a few hours after death. It leads to the breakdown of tissues and release of gases, causing bloating and a foul smell. While putrefaction is a significant postmortem change, it is not the first to occur.

Mummification (Option D) occurs in specific environmental conditions, such as very dry climates, and involves the preservation of the body due to dehydration. It happens much later in the decomposition process and is not the first change after death.

questions.text: What is the clinical diagnosis for a young male who has no symptoms but is found to have a wide fixed split S2 during auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ASD

Explanation:

  • A wide fixed split S2 on auscultation is a characteristic finding in atrial septal defects (ASD), where there is abnormal communication between the atria. It allows increased blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium, causing a delay in the closure of the pulmonic valve, resulting in a wide fixed split S2.

Types of S2 split

Conditions causing split

Narrow split S2
  • Mild Left Ventricular Failure
  • Early Aortic Stenosis

wide split fixed S2

  • Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Wide split variable S2

  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
  • Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB)

Paradoxical split S2
  • Left Bundle Branch Block
  • Severe Aortic Stenosis

Atrial Septal Defect:

  • Congenital, low-pressure, left to right shunt.
  • The right ventricle will have volume overloading.
  • Types of ASD: Ostium Secundum (most common), Ostium Primum, Sinus Venosus
  • On auscultation: Wide fixed split S2 sound
  • Chest x-ray: May show enlarged right atrial and right ventricular enlargement and increased pulmonary markings
  • Transthoracic echocardiogram: Gold standard imaging modality, helps to detect size and assess the direction of blood flow.

 

A ventricular septal defect (Option A) is another type of congenital heart defect where there is an abnormal opening in the septum between the two ventricles. It typically produces a harsh holosystolic murmur, rather than a wide fixed split S2 heard on auscultation.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C) is a congenital heart condition characterized by a combination of four heart defects: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and overriding aorta. The characteristic murmur in TOF is a systolic ejection murmur and not specifically associated with a wide fixed split S2.

Bicuspid Aortic Valve (Option D) can be associated with aortic stenosis or regurgitation, it is not specifically associated with a wide fixed split S2.

questions.text: What is the association of Rhino-cerebral Mucor mycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diabetic ketoacidosis

Explanation:

  • Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis is strongly associated with uncontrolled diabetes, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis, also known as zygomycosis, is a serious fungal infection caused by various species of fungi belonging to the class Mucorales. It primarily affects the nose, sinuses, and brain. Intravenous amphotericin B is the first-line antifungal treatment that targets the causative organisms, significantly improving the patient's chances of survival.

Infections in Diabetes Mellitus

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) increases susceptibility to opportunistic infections.
  • Focused infections:
    • Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis (RCM)
    • Acute emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Pyelonephritis

Rhino-Cerebral Mucormycosis (RCM)

Aspect

Details

Overview

Severe fungal infection affecting nasal passages, sinuses, and brain.

Causative Agent

Primarily caused by Rhizopus oryzae, associated with uncontrolled DM and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Pathophysiology

Begins in nasal turbinates; progresses rapidly due to angioinvasive nature, causing tissue necrosis and vascular thrombosis.

Clinical Manifestations

Fever, facial pain, swelling, nasal discharge, necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis

Imaging studies and histopathological examination.

Treatment

Immediate antifungal therapy (e.g., amphotericin B) and aggressive surgical debridement.

questions.text: Identify the given disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:A) Melanoma

Explanation:

  • The given image showing a lesion with irregular borders, asymmetry, and uneven distribution of colors in the lesion is suggestive of malignant melanoma.

 

Malignant melanoma:

  • Melanoma is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it is a rare skin cancer, it has a high mortality rate. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds.

Risk factors:

  • Positive family history.
  • Fair skin.
  • Genetics: CDKN2A (chromosome 9p21), MC1R, and TYR genes.
  • Nevus:
    • Congenital melanocytic nevi.
    • Junctional nevi.
    • Atypical nevi.
    • Dysplastic nevi.
  • Fitzpatrick Type 1 skin.
  • UV light.

Types of Melanoma:

Type

Site

Description

Image

Superficial spreading (M/C type)

Any (more common on the upper back and, in women, lower legs)

Brown mixed with bluish-red, bluish-black, reddish brown, and often whitish pink. The lesion border is often visibly and/or palpably raised

Lentigo maligna

Sun-exposed surfaces, particularly malar region and temple

In flat portions, brown and tan predominate, but whitish grey sometimes present; in nodules, reddish brown, bluish grey, bluish-black.

Acral lentiginous

Palm, sole, nail bed, mucous membrane

In flat portions, dark brown; in raised lesions (plaques), brown-black or blue-black.

Nodular

Any

Reddish blue, purple, or bluish-black; can be uniform or mixed with brown and black.

Investigations:

  • Clinical examination.
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

Breslow’s and Clarke’s Classifications of Malignant Melanoma:

Stage

Classification

Clarke

Breslow

I

Involvement of epidermis

≤ 0.75 mm

II

Involvement of epidermis + dermis

0.76-1.5 mm

III

Involvement of dermal papillae

1.5-4 mm

IV

Involvement of reticular dermis

>4 mm

V

Involvement of subcutaneous tissue

-

Management:

  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.

Incorrect Options:

Hyperpigmentation (Option B):

  • Generalized or localized increased skin pigmentation due to conditions like melasma, Addison’s disease, or post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
  • Does not present with an irregular, evolving lesion.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option C):

  • Pearly, translucent nodule with telangiectasia.
  • Slow-growing and rarely metastasizes.
  • May have central ulceration ("rodent ulcer").

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option D):

  • Scaly, erythematous plaque or ulcer with crusting.
  • Often seen in chronically sun-exposed areas.
  • More locally invasive, with some potential for metastasis.

questions.text: What would be the most suitable course of action for managing a 65-year-old male who presented with symptoms of weakness, lethargy, excessive cold intolerance, and slow ankle jerk? His thyroid function test (TFT) revealed a TSH level of 16 Mu/L (normal range: 0.4 - 4.0 mu / l), T4 level of 0.3 ng/dl (normal range: 0.6 - 1.6 ng / dl), and T3 level of 70 pg /dl.

choices.text: Start levothyroxine at 100 micrograms and decrease the dose gradually
Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and increase the dose gradually
Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and decrease the dose gradually
Give T3 and T4 drugs simultaneously

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and increase the dose gradually

Explanation:

  • Low T3 and T4 valves with high TSH and given clinical features suggests that this could be a case of hypothyroidism.
  • The most appropriate management for primary hypothyroidism is to initiate treatment with levothyroxine, a synthetic form of thyroid hormone. The initial dose of levothyroxine should be low and gradually increased until the patient reaches the optimal replacement dose. Starting with a dose of 25 micrograms is a common practice in such cases.

Clinical Features of Hypothyroidism:

  • Fatigue, weakness and increased sleep
  • Cold intolerance, Weight gain
  • Dry, coarse skin, Hair loss
  • Constipation
  • Depression and cognitive impairment
  • Menstrual irregularities and infertility
  • Bradycardia
  • Myxedema Hoarse voice
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome, Slow reflexes
  • Goiter, Anemia, Hypercholesterolemia

Thyroid Function Test :

  • TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
    • Normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L
  • Interpretation of Results:

Condition

TSH

Free T4

Free T3

Primary hypothyroidism

↑

↓

↓

Primary hyperthyroidism

↓ (<0.1 mIU/L)

↑

↑

Subclinical hypothyroidism

↑

Normal

Normal

Subclinical hyperthyroidism

↓

Normal

Normal

↓ or Approximately normal

↓

T3 thyrotoxicosis

↓

Normal

↑

Treatment of hypothyroidism:

  • Levothyroxine - 1.6 µg/kg to be started
  • Available as 25 µg / 50 µg / 88 µg / 100 µg
  • If the dose is >100µg, it increases O2 consumption resulting in angina. Hence, careful titration of dose increments should be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in W.P.W?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Treadmill test

Explanation:

  • Treadmill test is not done in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome because it does not reliably induce arrhythmias and may produce false-positive ST-segment changes, mimicking ischemia.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome:

WPW Syndrome

Most common type of ventricular preexcitation syndrome, characterized by preexcited QRS during sinus rhythm and episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

Mechanism

Abnormal conduction pathway from atria to the ventricle (Bundle of Kent) bypasses the rate-slowing AV node, causing partial early ventricular depolarisation.

ECG Findings

Delta wave with widened QRS complex and shortened PR interval.

Clinical Consequence

May lead to a reentry circuit, causing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

 

Electrophysiological studies (Option B): Used to assess conduction properties and locate the accessory pathway in WPW syndrome. It is particularly useful in risk stratification and guiding catheter ablation.

Oral beta blocker (Option C): AV nodal blocking agents, including beta-blockers, may be reasonable only in the setting of orthodromic AVRT or WPW pattern on ECG. However, they are contraindicated in WPW with atrial fibrillation, as they can promote conduction through the accessory pathway, leading to ventricular fibrillation.

Procainamide (Option D) is the pharmacologic treatment of choice for antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and atrial fibrillation with preexcitation, as it blocks conduction through the accessory pathway. It is also an accepted treatment for conversion of tachycardia in WPW.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with an itchy skin rash. Physical examination reveals flat-topped, polygonal, purplish papules with fine white lines on the surface. The lesions are primarily located on the inner wrists and forearms, as well as on the lower back. The patient reports that he has been experiencing oral discomfort and noticed white, lacy patches on the inside of his cheeks. There is no family history of similar conditions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by pruritic, violaceous, flat-topped papules. It frequently affects the flexor surfaces of the wrists, forearms, lower back, and mucosal surfaces.

Lichen Planus:

Clinical Features

  • 6 P’s → Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar Papules & Plaques
  • Mucosal involvement → Wickham striae (reticular white lines)
  • Koebner phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin
  • Histology → Sawtooth infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
  • Association → Hepatitis C

Treatment

Topical (First-line for mild cases)

  • Corticosteroids (Clobetasol, Betamethasone)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (Tacrolimus, Pimecrolimus) – for oral/genital LP
  • Antihistamines – for pruritus relief
  • Local anesthetics (Lidocaine gel) – for painful oral lesions

Intralesional (For hypertrophic LP)

  • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone injections)

Systemic (For severe, widespread, or refractory cases)

  • Oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone)
  • Dapsone
  • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQS)
  • Azathioprine, Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)

Phototherapy (For generalized LP, especially in children)

  • Narrow-band UVB (NBUVB) phototherapy

Incorrect Options:

Psoriasis (Option A):

  • Characterized by silvery-white scales on erythematous plaques, mostly on extensor surfaces.
  • Nail pitting and onycholysis are common.

Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis) (Option B):

  • Poorly demarcated, erythematous, weeping lesions with crusting and lichenification.
  • Typically affects flexural surfaces (e.g., antecubital, popliteal fossae).

Tinea Corporis (Option D):

  • Annular (ring-shaped) lesions with a central clearing and scaly border.
  • Fungal infection, confirmed by KOH preparation showing hyphae.

questions.text: The following patient has presented after chest trauma. On examination, crepitus is felt. The clinical diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Subcutaneous emphysema

Explanation:

  • The presence of crepitus after chest trauma suggests air leakage into the subcutaneous tissue, indicating subcutaneous emphysema.

Subcutaneous Emphysema:

  • Air accumulation in the subcutaneous tissue, which lies beneath the dermis.
  • Can spread into deeper tissues, leading to pneumomediastinum, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, or pneumoretroperitoneum.
  • Causes:
    • Traumatic: Blunt or penetrating injuries, barotrauma, bowel perforation, pulmonary blebs.
    • Iatrogenic:
      • Ventilator circuit malfunction or disruption.
      • Improper pop-off valve closure.
      • Valsalva maneuvres that increase thoracic pressure.
      • Trauma to the airway.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Crepitus on palpation (crackling sensation or sound).
    • Swelling in the chest, neck, or face; distorted facial appearance; vocal changes; dysphagia.
    • Severe cases: Hemodynamic or respiratory compromise due to extensive air spread.
  • Investigation:
    • X-ray: Shows radiolucent streaks, “ginkgo leaf sign” on chest radiograph.
    • CT scan: Detects deeper air pockets and the source of air leakage.
    • Ultrasound: May reveal hyperechoic scattered densities.
  • Management:
    • Mild cases: Observation, as resolution usually occurs within 10 days if the underlying cause is controlled.
    • Oxygen therapy: Helps nitrogen washout and promotes reabsorption of gas, especially in pneumothorax/pneumomediastinum.
    • Ventilated patients: Reduce tidal volume, PEEP, and avoid bronchospasm to minimize progression.
    • Surgical intervention (for severe cases):
      • Bilateral infraclavicular incisions (2 cm) to release air.
      • Subcutaneous drains in extreme cases.
    • Airway management: Consider tracheostomy if there is a tracheal tear with worsening subcutaneous emphysema.
    • Antibiotics: If mucosal injury is suspected to prevent mediastinitis.

 

Gas gangrene (Option B) is caused by Clostridium species and involves severe tissue destruction and infection, often in the context of deep wounds or surgical procedures. It typically leads to more systemic signs such as fever, shock, and tissue necrosis, which are not seen in this case. It is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus, making it an incorrect option.

Acute tubular necrosis (Option C) refers to kidney damage due to ischemia, toxins, or infection, leading to renal dysfunction. It does not present with crepitus or air trapped in the subcutaneous tissue, and is unrelated to chest trauma. Therefore, it is not relevant to this clinical scenario.

SVC syndrome (Option D): Superior vena cava syndrome results from partial or complete obstruction of the SVC, usually due to thrombus formation or tumor infiltration. It presents with symptoms such as face/neck swelling, distended neck veins, cough, dyspnea, orthopnea, and upper extremity swelling. However, SVC syndrome does not involve crepitus, which is the hallmark of subcutaneous emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Defibrillation?

choices.text: Only be used by a trained person
Decrease in success rate with delay in initiation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1 minute gap between 2 shocks

Explanation:

  • A 1-minute gap between 2 shocks is incorrect, as defibrillation should be delivered without delay to maximize the chances of successful resuscitation.

Defibrillation:

  • Indications:
    • Ventricular fibrillation (VF)
    • Pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT)
  • Personnel Involved: Defibrillation is typically performed by medical personnel trained in Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) or Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS). (Option A)
  • Preparation:
    • Resuscitation (CPR) continues while preparing the defibrillator.
    • Once available, the defibrillator should be used immediately, taking precedence over other measures.
  • Defibrillation Technique:
    • Manual defibrillator paddles or hands-free defibrillator pads are placed on the chest (right sternal border and cardiac apex, or in anteroposterior configuration).
    • The defibrillator is charged and set to the manufacturer’s recommended initial energy level (120-200 joules for biphasic defibrillators, 360 joules for monophasic).
    • A shock is delivered after confirming no one is in contact with the patient.
  • Post-Defibrillation:
    • CPR is resumed immediately for 2 minutes after the shock.
    • The pulse and rhythm are checked to assess if VF or pulseless VT has been terminated.
    • If VF or VT persists, defibrillation is repeated, with increasing energy as per guidelines.
  • Medications During Resuscitation:
    • Epinephrine (1 mg IV every 3-5 minutes) should be given after the first unsuccessful shock.
    • Amiodarone (300 mg IV bolus) may be administered if VT or VF persists, with additional doses (150 mg) as needed.
    • Lidocaine can be used in place of amiodarone in some cases, but epinephrine and amiodarone are preferred.
  • Clinical Significance: Early defibrillation increases the chances of survival in VF. After 10 minutes of VF, the chances of successful resuscitation decrease significantly. (Option B & C)
  • Contraindications: There are no contraindications for defibrillation in the presence of VF or pulseless VT.

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions, as shown in the image below, and later developed arthritis also. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • The patient has psoriasis (as indicated by the psoriatic plaque in the image) and later developed arthritis, suggesting psoriatic arthritis
  • The drug of choice used to treat Psoriatic arthritis is methotrexate
  • Methotrexate belongs to a class of drugs called disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARDs). It reduces inflammation and alleviates the symptoms of arthritis.

Treatment:

Medical:

  • NSAIDs
  • Immuno suppressive agents- methotrexate and TNF inhibitors
  • Local glucocorticoid injections
  • Physiotherapy

Surgery:

  • For unstable joints.
  • Arthrodesis procedure.

Incorrect Options:

PUVA (Option A):

  • PUVA does not work effectively in reducing the arthritic condition.
  • Methotrexate is preferred over PUVA for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis.

Steroids (Option B): Oral and topical corticosteroids can be used for short-term therapy but are not recommended for long-term use due to their many adverse effects.

Infliximab (Option D): Infliximab is preferred in moderate to severe cases of Psoriatic arthritis but is not the first drug of choice due to it being more expensive.

questions.text: When assessing a patient before anesthesia, the oral cavity should be examined. The image provided below displays the examined cavity. It illustrates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mallampati class III

Explanation:

The picture shows Mallampati Class III as only the base of the uvula is visible.

Modified Mallampati scoring

Class 0

Any part of the epiglottis is visible

Class I

Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate are visualized. (Option D ruled out)

Class II

Uvula and soft palate are visualized. Tip of uvula is not visualized. (Option B ruled out)

Class III

Only Soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

Predict difficult intubation

Class IV

Only hard palate is visible. (Option ruled A out)

questions.text: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie B virus

Explanation: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is associated with coxsackie B virus infection.

Fulminant Diabetes:

  • A rapidly progressing subtype of type 1 diabetes, leading to severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis within a short time.
  • Pathogenesis: Exact cause unclear but likely involves genetic factors (HLA genes, especially DR4-DQ4) and viral infections (coxsackieviruses A4, A5, A6, B1, rotavirus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, human herpes virus (HHV)-6, and HHV-7)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Rapid onset: Average duration of hyperglycemic symptoms is 4 days.
    • Preceding symptoms: Common-cold-like symptoms and gastrointestinal symptoms are frequent.
    • Near-normal glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c): Despite severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis.
    • Absent C-peptide levels: Indicating no residual insulin secretion.
    • No autoantibodies against pancreatic β-cells: Unlike classic type 1 diabetes.
    • Elevated pancreatic enzyme levels.
    • Possible association with pregnancy.
  • Diagnosis: Based on rapid progression of hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and the above clinical features.
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with:
      • Intravenous saline infusion.
      • Regular insulin therapy.
    • Long-term insulin therapy: Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) or multiple daily injections (MDI).
  • Prognosis:
    • Without immediate treatment, death can occur within 24 hours.
    • Early recognition and prompt intervention are critical for survival.

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option A) (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes, characterized by hyperglycemia, ketone production, and metabolic acidosis. However, it is a consequence rather than a cause of fulminant diabetes.

Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma (Option C) is a life-threatening complication of diabetes, marked by extremely high blood sugar and severe dehydration. Unlike fulminant diabetes, it is typically seen in type 2 diabetes.

Autoimmune pancreatitis (Option D) is a rare form of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction. While it can lead to endocrine dysfunction, it does not cause the rapid and severe destruction of β-cells seen in fulminant type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy with intellectual disability who has developed extensive warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet, along with severe fissuring and scaling on the soles of his feet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Norwegian scabies

Explanation:

  • Norwegian scabies (crusted scabies) is a severe, highly contagious form of scabies, seen in immunocompromised individuals, elderly patients, or those with neurological disorders (e.g., intellectual disability).

Feature

Classic Scabies

Crusted (Norwegian) Scabies

Prevalence

More common

Less common

Skin Lesions

Small erythematous papules, "knots on a rope"

Erythematous, scaling, crusting, and fissuring

Pruritus

Severe, worse at night

Usually mild or absent due to nerve damage

Onset

3-6 weeks after initial colonization, 1-3 days after reinfestation

Gradual but progressive

Risk Factors

No specific immunosuppression required

Occurs in immunosuppressed patients (HIV, elderly, cancer, etc.)

Mite Burden

Low mite burden

High mite burden

Transmission

Direct skin-to-skin contact

More commonly transmitted via fomites (objects)

Common Sites

Webs of fingers, axillae, areola, genitalia

Hands, feet, and scalp

 

Incorrect Options:

Scabies incognito (Option A):

  • Occurs due to misuse of topical steroids, modifying typical scabies lesions.
  • Presents as diffuse eczema-like plaques rather than thick crusts.

Animal scabies (Option B): It is usually seen in animals and is rarely transmitted to humans

Nodular scabies (Option C): a less common form of scabies that causes firm, itchy, red bumps. It's often found in the groin and genital area.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impetigo

Explanation:

  • The image shows honey-colored, crusted lesions around the mouth, characteristic of non-bullous impetigo.
  • Impetigo is a superficial bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Common in children and spreads via direct contact.

Impetigo

Feature

Details

Etiology

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes

Types

Non-bullous (crusted), Bullous

Lesion

Honey-colored crusts, vesicles, erosions

Common Sites

Face (perioral, perinasal), extremities

Treatment

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics if extensive

Bullous impetigo

Non-bullous impetigo/Impetigo contagiosa

Incorrect Options:

Chickenpox (Option B) - Incorrect because vesicles appear in crops and have a dew-drop on a rose petal appearance, unlike the honey-colored crusts seen in impetigo.

Herpes Simplex (Option C) - Incorrect because it presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, often with pain and recurrence, whereas impetigo shows crusted lesions.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option D) - Incorrect because it presents as pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, not crusted erosions.

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for a patient with cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Etomidate
 

Explanation:

  • It is an α2-receptors agonist therefore it maintains the vascular tone and myocardial contractility, thus maintaining cardiovascular haemodynamics which makes it an anesthetic of choice in cardiac disease.

General Anesthetics for Cardiac Patients

Intravenous Anesthetics:

  1. Thiopentone: Reduces myocardial contractility, preload, and blood pressure; administer slowly with caution.(Option D ruled out)
  2. Propofol: Significantly lowers blood pressure and heart rate; not ideal for patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) (Option C ruled out)
  3. Ketamine: Not suitable for ischemic heart disease (IHD) and valvular heart disease; useful in cardiac tamponade and cyanotic heart disease. Only IV agent to increase BP and HR. (Option A ruled out)
  4. Midazolam: Decreases mean arterial pressure and increases heart rate; provides excellent amnesia; safe for CAD patients.
  5. Etomidate: Causes minimal hemodynamic changes; good for patients with poor cardiac reserve. Agent of choice. (Option B)

Narcotics:

Preferred for cardiac stability and analgesia; newer agents like fentanyl and sufentanil also provide stability.

Inhalational Agents:

  1. Isoflurane: Recommended for patients with good myocardial contractility.
  2. Halothane: Causes myocardial depression and dysrhythmias; Not used.
  3. Nitrous Oxide: Maintains stable hemodynamics in cardiac patients.

Muscle Relaxants:

  1. Vecuronium: Minimal hemodynamic changes; short-acting, suitable for cardiac patients.
  2. Pipecuronium, Mivacurium, Doxacurium: Newer non-depolarizing agents with minimal cardiovascular side effects.

Anticholinergics:

  • Glycopyrrolate: Preferred over atropine for less tachycardia; use only as needed.

questions.text: An unresponsive patient in ambulance on attachment of monitors showed following rhythm. What should be done immediately?

choices.text: Put the patient in left lateral position

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chest compressions and defibrillation

Explanation:

  • The rhythm in the ECG image is ventricular fibrillation (VF).
  • This is a life-threatening arrhythmia characterized by chaotic and disorganized electrical activity in the ventricles, leading to the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively.
  • For an unresponsive patient with ventricular fibrillation, the immediate step is: Chest compressions and defibrillation.

Steps in Basic Life Support Skills:

 

Check for pulse and breathing (Option A):

  • While checking for pulse and breathing is crucial when assessing an unresponsive patient, in this case, the ECG already shows ventricular fibrillation, a shockable rhythm that implies cardiac arrest.
  • There is no need to check for a pulse if the patient is unresponsive with this rhythm because VF always requires immediate chest compressions and defibrillation.
  • Delaying treatment to check for a pulse could worsen outcomes.

Put the patient in the left lateral position (Option C):

  • The left lateral position is used to prevent aspiration in cases like unconscious patients with an intact airway or during pregnancy to reduce pressure on the inferior vena cava.
  • However, in a patient with ventricular fibrillation, there is no effective cardiac output, and this position provides no benefit. Immediate CPR and defibrillation are the only lifesaving actions.

Cardioversion (Option D):

  • Cardioversion is used for arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, or supraventricular tachycardia in a hemodynamically unstable patient. It is a synchronized procedure delivered at a specific point in the cardiac cycle.
  • Ventricular fibrillation requires unsynchronized defibrillation, not cardioversion, as there is no organized electrical activity to synchronize with.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding vasectomy?

choices.text: The procedure is done under local anaesthesia
Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure
A no-scalpel technique is being widely used now
The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure

Explanation:

Sterility post-vasectomy is achieved by 3 months (12 weeks), not 3 weeks.

Vasectomy is a safe, minimally invasive, and highly effective method of male sterilization.

  • The procedure is performed under local anesthesia to minimize discomfort. (Option A ruled out)
  • The no-scalpel technique, which involves a small puncture instead of a traditional incision, is now widely used and associated with fewer complications. (Option C ruled out)
  • The vas deferens, the tube responsible for transporting sperm, is divided during the procedure. (Option D ruled out)
  • Sperm present in the post-distal ligation area can lead to pregnancy, hence contraception is required for 3 months or 20 ejaculations, whichever is later.
  • Sterilization is confirmed by semen analysis, with at least 2 analyses showing azoospermia.
  • Studies show that 80% of men are sterile after 15 ejaculations or about 6 weeks, and 89% are sperm-free by 10 weeks. The remaining sperm is gradually cleared, making the safe time period approximately 3 months.

questions.text: A couple brought their son to doctor. They were worried because their son likes to eat foods from multinational companies. What will we call this shift from consumption of traditional natural food to western fast foods?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Acculturation

  • Acculturation refers to the process of cultural change and adaptation that occurs when individuals or groups come into contact with a different culture.
  • In this case, it describes the shift in food habits from traditional natural foods to the consumption of western fast foods.

Concepts in Sociology:

Term

Definition/Explanation

Social structure

Patterns of inter-relationships between persons in a society

Socialism

Economic doctrine that favours the use of property and resources of the country for public welfare; system of production and distribution based on social ownership

Socialization

Process by which an individual gradually acquires culture and becomes a member of a social group

Medical sociology

Includes studies of medical profession, relationship of medicine to public, social factors in disease prevalence, incidence, and interpretation

Society

A group of individuals who have organized themselves and follow a way of life, featuring a system of relationships between individuals

Community

A social group determined by geographical boundaries and/or common values or interests

Sociology

Study of individuals as well as groups in society, focusing on relationships and behavior

Culture

Learned behavior socially acquired

Acculturation

Cultural contact or mixing of two cultures through trade, industrialization, religion propagation, education, and conquest

Custom
  • Established patterns of behavior objectively verified within a particular social setting
  • Folkways: Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct
  • Mores: More stringent customs within society

 

Standard of Living

Refers to usual scale of expenditure, goods consumed, and services enjoyed, including income, occupation, housing, sanitation, nutrition, health, education, recreational services

Social Pathology

(Option B)

Study of social problems that undermine the social, psychological, or economic health of populations; describes the relationship between disease and social conditions

Food transition (Option A): might refer to the general change in diet, but it doesn't fully capture the cultural aspect.

Demographic (Option D): change refers to changes in population size or structure, which doesn’t relate to food habits.

questions.text: The following are non depolarizing muscle relaxants except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Suxamethonium

Explanation:

Suxamethonium (Succinylcholine) is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, while Pancuronium, Rocuronium, and Vecuronium are non-depolarizing muscle relaxants.

Neuromuscular Blocking Agents (NMBAs)

Type

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Duration

Reversal

Depolarizing NMBAs

Suxamethonium (Succinylcholine)

Binds to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, causing persistent depolarization and temporary paralysis

Ultra-short acting (5-10 min)

Not reversed by neostigmine; metabolized by plasma cholinesterase

Non-Depolarizing NMBAs

Pancuronium, Rocuronium, Vecuronium, Atracurium, Cisatracurium

Competitively inhibit ACh binding at nicotinic receptors, preventing depolarization and muscle contraction

Short (Rocuronium, Vecuronium), Intermediate, or Long-acting (Pancuronium)

Reversed by neostigmine or sugammadex (for steroidal NMBAs)

Pancuronium (Option A): Incorrect because it is a non-depolarizing, long-acting muscle relaxant.

Rocuronium (Option B): Incorrect because it is a non-depolarizing, intermediate-acting muscle relaxant.

Vecuronium (Option D): Incorrect because it is a non-depolarizing, intermediate-acting muscle relaxant.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy six months ago presents with persistent abdominal pain and distention symptoms. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated, and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gestational trophoblastic disease

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), specifically its malignant form called gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).
  • This diagnosis is supported by the history of molar pregnancy, persistently elevated beta-hCG levels, and characteristic "cannonball" metastases on chest X-ray.
  • GTN represents the malignant spectrum of GTD that can develop after a molar pregnancy.
  • The disease is characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation with the potential for local invasion and distant metastasis, particularly to the lungs where they appear as multiple, well-circumscribed "cannonball" lesions on chest imaging.

Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

Definition and Classification
  • Hydatidiform Moles (HM):
    • Complete Mole: No fetal parts, abnormal placental development
    • Partial Mole: Some fetal parts present, abnormal placental tissue
  • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN):
    • Invasive Mole: Deep penetration into uterine wall
    • Choriocarcinoma: Aggressive malignant form
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT): Rare variant
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT): Originating from implantation site

Risk Factors
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age >35 or <21 years
    • Previous molar pregnancy (1% recurrence risk)
    • Asian ethnicity
    • History of spontaneous abortion
    • Dietary deficiencies (vitamin A, animal fats)
    • Blood type A

Pathogenesis and Genetics
  • Complete Mole:
    • 46,XX (90%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • 46,XY (10%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • Empty egg fertilized by sperm that duplicates
    • Maternal mitochondrial DNA present
  • Partial Mole:
    • Triploid: 69,XXX, 69,XXY, or 69,XYY
    • Fertilization by two sperm
    • Contains both maternal and paternal DNA
  • Molecular Features:
    • p53 and MDM2 overexpression
    • HLA-G expression in choriocarcinoma
    • Altered NECC1 and growth factor expression

Clinical Presentation
  • First Trimester:
    • Vaginal bleeding (84% of cases)
    • Dark brown/prune juice-like discharge
    • Passage of grape-like vesicles
    • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Later Presentation:
    • Hyperthyroidism symptoms
    • Early pre-eclampsia (<20 weeks)
    • Respiratory distress
    • Theca lutein cysts
  • Physical Findings:
    • Uterine size-date discrepancy
    • Absent fetal heart tones (complete mole)
    • Adnexal masses

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Ultrasound: "Snowstorm" or "grape-like" pattern
    • Chest X-ray for metastasis (Cannonball foci in lungs)
    • ​​​​​​​
    • CT/PET for staging
    • MRI for atypical presentations
  • Laboratory Tests:
    • Quantitative β-hCG levels
    • Complete blood count
    • Coagulation studies
    • Liver and renal function
    • Thyroid function tests
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Complete Mole: Diffuse villous edema, trophoblastic hyperplasia
    • Partial Mole: Mixed normal and hydropic villi
    • Choriocarcinoma: Biphasic pattern with hemorrhage

Incorrect Options:

Endometriosis (Option B): Endometriosis typically presents with cyclic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. It would not explain the elevated β-hCG levels or pulmonary lesions. Endometriosis doesn't cause elevated beta-hCG or lung metastases

Ovarian cyst (Option C): Ovarian cyst can cause abdominal pain and distention, but it would not explain persistently elevated β-hCG levels or pulmonary metastases.

Asherman's syndrome (Option D): Asherman's syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions following D&C, causing amenorrhea and infertility. It would not cause elevated β-hCG or pulmonary lesions.

questions.text: Modified duke criteria are used for diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Infective endocarditis

Explanation:

  • Modified duke criteria are used for diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Modified Duke Criteria (2023 update):

I. Definite Endocarditis:

A. Pathologic Criteria

1. Microorganisms identified in the context of clinical signs of active endocarditis in a vegetation from cardiac tissue; from explanted prosthetic valve or sewing ring; from ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement); from an endovascular intra cardiac implantable electronic device (CIED) or from an arterial embolus OR

2. Active endocarditis in the same above mentioned locations.

  • Microorganisms identified in appropriate sample by PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing, or in situ hybridization

B. Clinical Criteria (mentioned below)

1. 2 Major Criteria OR

2. 1 Major and 3 Minor Criteria OR

3. 5 Minor Criteria

II. Possible Endocarditis:

A. 1 Major Criterion and 1 Minor Criterion OR

B. 3 Minor Criteria

III. Rejected Endocarditis:

A. Firm alternate diagnosis explaining signs/symptoms OR

B. Lack of recurrence despite antibiotic therapy for only < 4 days OR

C. No pathologic/macroscopic evidence of IE at surgery or autopsy with antibiotic therapy for less than 4 days OR

D. Does not meet criteria of possible IE

 

Clinical Criteria

I. Major Criteria

A. Microbiologic Major Criteria

(i) Positive blood cultures

Microorganisms that commonly cause IE isolated from 2 or more separate blood culture sets

OR

Microorganisms that occasionally or rarely cause IE isolated from 3 or more separate blood culture sets

(ii) Positive laboratory tests

Positive polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or other nucleic acid-based technique for Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species, or Tropheryma whipplei from blood

OR

Coxiella burnetii antiphase I immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody titer > 1:800 or isolated from a single blood culture

OR

Indirect immunofluorescence assays (IFA) for IgM and IgG antibodies to Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana with IgG titer ≥ 1:800

B. Imaging Major Criteria

(i) Echocardiography and cardiac computed tomography (CT) imaging

Echocardiography and cardiac CT showing vegetation, valve/leaflet perforation, valve/leaflet aneurysm, abscess, pseudoaneurysm, or intracardiac fistula

OR

Significant new valvular regurgitation on echocardiography as compared with previous imaging.

Worsening or changing of preexisting regurgitation is not sufficient

OR

New partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve as compared with previous imaging.

(ii) 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging

Abnormal metabolic activity involving a native or prosthetic valve, ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement), intracardiac device leads, or other prosthetic material

C. Surgical Major Criteria

Evidence of IE documented by direct inspection during heart surgery neither Major Imaging Criteria nor subsequent histologic or microbiologic confirmation

II. MINOR CRITERIA

A. Predisposition
  • Previous history of IE
  • Prosthetic valve
  • Previous valve repair
  • Congenital heart disease
  • More than mild regurgitation or stenosis of any etiology
  • Endovascular intracardiac implantable electronic device (CIED)
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
  • Intravenous drug use

B. Fever

Temperature greater than 38.0°C

C. Vascular Phenomena

Clinical or radiological evidence of arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, cerebral or splenic abscess, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, purulent pericardium

D. Immunologic Phenomena

Positive rheumatoid factor, Osler nodes, Roth spots, or immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis

E. Microbiologic Evidence (Falling Short of Major Criterion)

Positive blood cultures for a microorganism consistent with IE but not meeting the requirements for Major Criterion

OR

Positive culture, PCR, or other nucleic acid-based test (amplicon or shotgun sequencing, in situ hybridization) for organisms consistent with IE from a sterile body site other than cardiac tissue, cardiac prosthesis, or arterial embolus

F. Imaging Criteria

Abnormal 18F-FDG PET/CT within 3 months of implantation of prosthetic valve

G. Physical Examination Criteria

New valvular regurgitation identified on auscultation if echocardiography is not available.

questions.text: Preoperative assessment of oral cavity for endotracheal intubation in an adult is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mallampatti score

Explanation:

This score is used to evaluate the oral cavity preoperatively to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It is based on visualisation of the oropharyngeal structures (soft palate, uvula, and tonsillar pillars) when the patient opens their mouth widely without phonating. It is categorised into four classes, with higher classes indicating a more difficult airway. It is the standard tool for assessing oral cavity and airway accessibility.

Cormack-Lehane (option B): This grading system evaluates the laryngeal view during direct laryngoscopy, not during the preoperative oral cavity assessment. It is useful for classifying intubation difficulty once the laryngoscope is in place.

ASA grading (option C): The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) grading assesses a patient’s physical status to estimate perioperative risk, not specifically for airway assessment.

AHA grading (option D): This grading does not exist for airway or oral cavity assessment and is irrelevant in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators shall be seen with use of a small-sized BP cuff?

choices.text: Cancels the effects of calcified arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) False elevation of BP

Explanation:

  • False elevation of BP is observed when using a small-sized blood pressure cuff.

Errors in Blood Pressure Measurement Due to Improper Cuff Size:

  • Cuff Too Narrow:
    • Overestimates blood pressure.
    • Applies excessive pressure to a smaller area, leading to falsely high readings.
  • Cuff Too Wide:
    • Underestimates blood pressure. (Option B)
    • Distributes pressure over a larger area, resulting in falsely low readings.
  • Importance of Proper Cuff Size:
    • Ensures accurate blood pressure measurement.
    • Avoids misdiagnosis of hypertension or hypotension.

 

Cancels the effects of calcified arteries (Option C): A small-sized BP cuff does not negate the effects of calcified arteries. While arterial calcification can lead to inaccurate BP measurements, using the correct cuff size is essential for obtaining accurate readings.

Increases trans-arm impedance (Option C): A small-sized BP cuff does not directly increase trans-arm impedance. Trans-arm impedance refers to resistance encountered in certain BP measurement techniques, but it is not specifically affected by cuff size.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate course of action for managing a 17-year-old female who is experiencing primary amenorrhea but presents with monthly abdominal pain? Upon examination, she exhibits normal development of secondary sexual characteristics, an abdominal lump, and a blush bulge when the labia are separated. Given the suspected diagnosis, what treatment or intervention would be suitable?

choices.text: The cruciate incision on the hymen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The cruciate incision on the hymen

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate imperforate hymen with resulting hematocolpos, requiring surgical correction through a cruciate incision.

  • The hymen is a delicate membrane of stratified squamous epithelium guarding vaginal introitus.
  • Imperforate hymen occurs when hymen fails to break during nascent growth.
  • Clinical presentation varies by age, obstruction degree, and symptoms.
  • Cyclic monthly discomfort occurs due to hematometra (menstrual blood extending vaginal canal and uterus).

Treatment:

  • Cruciate hymenectomy is the standard treatment for imperforate hymen
  • Simple surgical procedure where hymen is cut along incision edges.

Incorrect Options:

Excision of the septum (Option A) is appropriate for treating vaginal septum but not imperforate hymen. The presence of a bulging membrane at the introitus indicates imperforate hymen rather than a septum.

Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty (Option B) is reserved for cases of vaginal agenesis or severe vaginal anomalies. This patient has a normal vagina with only hymenal obstruction.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Hysterectomy would be extremely inappropriate as this is a benign, easily correctable condition affecting only the hymen.

questions.text: Elderly male patient has presented with recurrent falls. Which of the following medicines is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prazocin

Explanation:

  • Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist that can cause orthostatic hypotension and syncope, leading to an increased risk of falls, particularly in elderly patients.

Prazosin:

  • Quinazoline derivative that acts as competitive alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
    • Smooth muscle relaxation → ↓ systemic vascular resistance → ↓ blood pressure
    • Affects various tissues (blood vessels, prostate, urethra, iris dilator muscle, brain)
    • Crosses the blood-brain barrier → contributes to cognitive effects (basis for PTSD use)
  • Metabolism: Hepatic (via CYP450 enzymes)
  • Half-life: ~2.5 hours (prolonged in chronic renal failure and congestive heart failure)
  • Uses:
    • FDA-approved Indication: Hypertension (alone or in combination with other antihypertensives) but not a first-line agent.
    • Non-FDA-approved Indication:
      • Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
      • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)-associated nightmares
      • Raynaud phenomenon
      • Pheochromocytoma
      • Scorpion envenomation
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Serious Adverse Effects:
      • First-dose hypotension (recommend initial dose at bedtime)
      • Orthostatic hypotension
      • Syncope
      • Intraoperative Floppy Iris Syndrome (IFIS)
      • Priapism
    • Common Adverse Effects:
      • Dizziness
      • Headache
      • Drowsiness
      • Lack of energy
      • Weakness
      • Palpitations
      • Nausea

 

Metformin (Option B) is used for managing type 2 diabetes. While it may cause gastrointestinal side effects like nausea and diarrhea, it does not directly contribute to falls.

Acarbose (Option C) is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor used to manage diabetes by delaying carbohydrate absorption. It can cause gastrointestinal issues but does not lead to falls.

Thiazide (Option D) diuretics can sometimes cause orthostatic hypotension, especially in elderly patients, but this side effect is less common and less pronounced compared to prazosin, which is more strongly associated with orthostatic hypotension and falls.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who has given birth twice and had two miscarriages comes to your clinic complaining of a strong-smelling discharge of blood from her vagina. She has been diagnosed with stage III B cervical cancer according to the FIGO classification. What is the recommended initial course of treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Radical hysterectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • In patients of FIGO Stage IIIB cervical cancer, the management protocol involves chemoradiation as the initial standard of care.

Stage

Surgical Management

Post-Surgical Management

IA1
  • Simple hysterectomy (Type I).
  • Conization if family not complete

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IA1 (with LVSI)
  • Modified radical hysterectomy (Type II) + pelvic lymphadenectomy (PLND).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND (consider SNLB) for selected patients desiring fertility

IA2
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumor <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.
  • If the specimen shows high-risk features - Adjuvant chemoradiation.
  • Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IB1
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumor <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.

IB2

 

Radical hysterectomy + PLND

IIA1

IB3 - IIA2

Chemoradiation

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears

IIB - IVA

Chemoradiation

IVB

Palliative chemotherapy and/or Palliative radiotherapy

  

Incorrect Options:

Radical hysterectomy (Option B): Radical hysterectomy suitable only for early-stage disease

Pelvic exenteration (Option C): Pelvic exenteration is reserved for cases involving metastasis to colon/rectum, and recurrence after radiation. It is not the initial treatment of choice for Stage IIIB disease.

Radical hysterectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection (Option D): is appropriate for earlier stages of cervical cancer (typically up to stage IIA) but not for Stage IIIB disease where tumor extends to the pelvic wall.

questions.text: What is the waist to hip ratio that is associated with an increased risk of heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) > 0.85 in females

Explanation:

  • The waist to hip ratio that is associated with an increased risk of heart disease is > 0.85 in females.

Waist-to-Hip Ratio:

  • Waist-to-hip ratio is a more accurate measure of obesity-related cardiovascular risk than BMI, with specific cut-offs of 0.83 for women and 0.9 for men significantly increasing the risk for myocardial infarction.
  • Physicians should prioritize measuring waist-to-hip ratio, along with waist circumference, to assess cardiovascular risk, particularly in specific ethnic groups.
  • Reducing abdominal obesity and increasing hip circumference, potentially through muscle mass development, may reduce cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: Best management of a hemodynamically stable patient with ECG showing Broad QRS complex with antidromic tachycardia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intravenous Procainamide

Explanation:

  • Intravenous procainamide is the best management for a hemodynamically stable patient with broad QRS complex antidromic tachycardia, as it terminates the arrhythmia by slowing conduction through the accessory pathway.

Atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT):

  • AVRT is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that occurs in patients with an accessory pathway, such as in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.
  • Pathology:
    • AVRT involves a reentrant circuit that includes the normal AV conduction system and the accessory pathway.
    • Two types exist:
      • Orthodromic AVRT (more common): Conduction travels down the AV node and up the accessory pathway.
      • Antidromic AVRT (less common): Conduction travels down the accessory pathway and up the AV node.

  • ECG Features:
    • Orthodromic AVRT:
      • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (QRS < 120 ms)
      • Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 150-250 bpm
      • Retrograde P waves often visible in the ST segment or early T wave
    • Antidromic AVRT:
      • Wide QRS complex tachycardia (QRS > 120 ms)
      • Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 170-240 bpm
      • Retrograde P waves may be obscured by the wide QRS

  • AVRT can be initiated by premature atrial or ventricular complexes that block one pathway and conduct through the other, setting up the reentrant circuit.
  • Management:
    • Acute Termination of Orthodromic AVRT:
      • Stable patients: Start with vagal maneuvers (Valsalva or carotid sinus massage).
      • If unsuccessful: IV adenosine (first-line pharmacologic treatment), IV verapamil, IV procainamide or IV beta-blockers.
    • Acute Termination of Antidromic AVRT:
      • If confirmed, avoid AV nodal blockers (adenosine, beta-blockers, verapamil, digoxin). (Option A & B)
      • IV procainamide is the preferred treatment.

 

Cardioversion (Option D): Reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients; unnecessary in a stable patient where pharmacologic management with IV procainamide is effective.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman with a history of Cesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen, and the fetal heart rate is weak. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine rupture

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate uterine rupture, a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by complete separation of the uterine wall with potential extrusion of fetal parts into the maternal abdomen.
  • The presence of previous cesarean section is the most significant risk factor, along with the characteristic presentation of sudden onset severe abdominal pain with hemodynamic instability.
