  • The clinical diagnosis is supported by palpable fetal parts through the maternal abdomen, abnormal fetal heart rate patterns or weak/absent fetal heart sounds, and signs of maternal shock including tachycardia and hypotension.

Pathophysiology:

  • Uterine rupture is a full separation of the uterus's three layers
  • Most commonly occurs when the uterus is gravid in the setting of a trial of labor after cesarean delivery

Incorrect Options:

Amniotic fluid embolization (Option A): Characteristic symptoms include bleeding from the uterus, C-section incision, or IV (intravenous) sites, shortness of breath or difficult breathing, sudden drop in blood pressure - which are not reported in this case.

Placental abruption (Option B): Characterized by vaginal bleeding, which is not present in this case.

Local anesthesia anaphylaxis (Option D): Anaphylaxis symptoms typically emerge within minutes of being exposed to an allergen. The case does not indicate the use of local anesthesia.

questions.text: In the radiological evaluation of a pregnant woman, it is observed that the pelvic inlet appears oval-shaped and has the largest diameter in the anteroposterior direction. According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification, the pelvis is likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anthropoid pelvis

Explanation:

  • According to Caldwell–Moloy anatomical classification of pelvis, the radiological findings indicate an anthropoid pelvis, which is characterized by an oval-shaped pelvic inlet with a greater anteroposterior diameter compared to the transverse diameter.

Anthropoid Pelvis:

  • Oval-shaped inlet with largest anteroposterior diameter (distance between the pubic symphysis and the sacral promontory)
  • Accounts for approximately 23.5% of female pelves
  • Limited anterior capacity
  • More often associated with delivery in the Occiput posterior position (the most common fetal malposition)
  • Caldwell–Moloy anatomical classification of the pelvis is based on the shape of the pelvis, which helps in understanding labor mechanisms.
  • Specifically, the greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into anterior and posterior segments are used to classify the pelvis as:
    • Gynecoid
    • Anthropoid
    • Android
    • Platypelloid

Incorrect Options:

Android pelvis (Option A) has a heart-shaped inlet with the greatest width of the transverse diameter positioned posteriorly near the sacrum. This is distinctly different from the oval shape described in the question. This type is more commonly found in males and comprises about 32.5% of female pelvis.

Gynecoid pelvis (Option C) appears round to slightly oval with the transverse diameter being slightly greater than the anteroposterior diameter. This is the opposite of the finding described in the question. This is the most common female pelvic type, found in about 41.4% of women.

Platypelloid pelvis (Option D) is characterized by a wide, flat inlet where the transverse diameter is significantly greater than the anteroposterior diameter, the exact opposite of the anthropoid type. This is the rarest type, occurring in only about 2.6% of women.

questions.text: Under which health organization are the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) implemented?

choices.text: United nations educational, scientific and cultural organisation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - United nations development programme

  • SDG's or Sustainable Development Goals are under the United Nations Development Programme and it comprises 17 goals and 169 targets for Agenda 2023.
  • The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030.

There are 17 goals:

1.

End poverty everywhere in all its forms.

2.

Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

3.

Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

4.

Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities.

5.

Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls.

6.

Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

7.

Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

8.

Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

9.

Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

10.

Reduce inequality within and among countries.

11.

Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

12.

Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns.

13.

Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts.

14.

Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources.

15.

Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity.

16.

Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions.

17.

Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

UNICEF (Option B): works around the world to strengthen health systems; immunize and treat children for pneumonia, diarrhea, malaria and other health conditions; help countries combat non-communicable diseases; and support children with mental health conditions, developmental delays and disabilities.

UNESCO's (Option C): mission is to contribute to the building of a culture of peace, the eradication of poverty, sustainable development and intercultural dialogue through education, the sciences, culture, communication and information

WHO works (Option D): worldwide to promote health, keep the world safe, and serve the vulnerable.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for the food poisoning experienced by the worker in the groundnut factory who consumed spoiled groundnuts that were stored in the facility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Aflatoxins

  • The likely reason for food poisoning in a worker who consumed spoiled groundnuts stored in the facility is: Aflatoxins
  • Aflatoxins are toxic compounds produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, fungi that grow on improperly stored food items such as groundnuts (peanuts), grains, and nuts in warm and humid conditions.

Aflatoxicosis:

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage

Beta oxalyl amino alanine (Option A): a neurotoxic compound in certain plants like Lathyrus sativus seeds, leads to Lathyrism when consumed excessively over time. It is not associated with groundnuts.

Smoke inhalation (Option B): While exposure to smoke may cause health problems, it does not explain the specific symptoms of food poisoning experienced by the worker.

Sanguinarine (Option C): is an alkaloid found in certain plants, including bloodroot and other members of the Papaveraceae family.

questions.text: During the standard delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, the intern prematurely removes the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine inversion

Explanation:

  • Pulling the cord without placental separation causes acute uterine inversion.
  • It is defined as turning the inside out of the fundus into the uterine cavity following childbirth.
  • Uterine inversion is a rare but grave complication during childbirth where the uterus turns partially or entirely inside out.
  • An inverted uterus can cause serious blood loss, shock, and even death due to hemorrhagic shock

Management of Uterine Inversion:

  1. Get IV/access
  2. Give rapid infusion of fluids, arrange Blood
  3. Try & Repost as soon as possible

Treatment Methods for Uterine Inversion:

  1. Manual Reposition:
    • The part that came out last should be reposited in first
    • This is the first line of management of acute uterine inversion
  2. Hydrostatic Reposition:
    • Also called as O'Sullivan's method, this can be tried if manual reposition fails
    • For repositioning, first, give a Tocolytic such as Inj Terbutaline
    • Following repositioning, Oxytocics such as Inj Oxytocin or Inj Methylergometrine are given
  3. Surgical Methods:
    • Huntington's Method → Traumatic clamps
    • Haultain Method → Resection of the constricting Bands

Incorrect Options:

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option A): The uterus partly outside the introitus is not suggestive of Amniotic fluid embolism. Also, the placenta is intact, so amniotic fluid embolism can be ruled out.

Postpartum hemorrhage (Option B): Postpartum hemorrhage, while present in this case, is a symptom rather than the primary diagnosis. The visible uterine fundus outside the introitus indicates a specific anatomical cause for the bleeding. (Option B ruled out) Simple postpartum hemorrhage would not present with an externally visible uterus.

Uterine rupture (Option D): A uterine rupture is a complete division of all three layers of the uterus, which is not the case mentioned here.

questions.text: A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhoea. The doctor, based on history, suspects that the child may be suffering from an infection due to Shigella over cholera and proceeds to give ciprofloxacin as the antibiotic. Which of the following points on history, apart from bloody stools, favour the doctor's suspicion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Presence of fever

  • Fever is more commonly associated with Shigella infection rather than cholera. Shigella infection can cause a systemic inflammatory response, leading to fever.
  • Cholera, on the other hand, typically does not cause a significant fever.
  • Therefore, the presence of fever supports the doctor's suspicion of a Shigella infection and favors it over cholera.

Clinical Presentation of Shigella:

Diarrhea:

  • Typically acute and often bloody (dysentery).
  • Incubation Period: 1-3 days after exposure.
  • Prodromal Period: 1-2 days after the incubation period.

Abdominal Pain:

  • Severe cramping.

Fever:

  • Often high-grade.

Tenesmus:

  • Painful straining with defecation.

Systemic Symptoms:

  • Malaise, headache, and sometimes vomiting.

Absence of rectal pain (Option A): Rectal pain is not a specific symptom that distinguishes between Shigella infection and cholera. Both conditions can cause diarrhea without necessarily causing rectal pain.

Presence of abdominal cramps (Option B): Abdominal cramps are commonly associated with both Shigella infection and cholera.

Presence of vomiting (Option C): While it can be present in both infections, it is not specific to Shigella and does not strongly favor one diagnosis over the other Learning objective

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, who is pregnant for the second time, with one living child, and is at 18 weeks of gestation. She presents with a complaint of PV bleeding for the past 4 hours. On examination, her membranes are ruptured, and she is experiencing uterine contractions. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a cervix that is shorter than 25 mm and funneling of the internal os by more than 1 cm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cervical incompetence

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate cervical incompetence due to the features such as leaking per vaginum, uterine contractions, short cervix <25 mm & funneling of the internal os >1 cm.

Cervical Incompetence:

  • Cervical incompetence is primarily a clinical diagnosis that indicates recurrent painless dilation and spontaneous mid-trimester birth, usually of a living fetus
  • Cervical incompetence, also known as cervical insufficiency, is a condition in which the cervix begins to efface and dilate painlessly during the second trimester, leading to premature cervical dilation and often resulting in late miscarriage or preterm birth

Cervical Incompetence:

Characteristics:
  • Painless dilation of the cervix in the 2nd trimester.
  • Characterised by spontaneous, painless dilation of the cervix followed by expulsion of products of conception.

Risk factors:
  • Past history of cervical surgeries such as LEEP, conization
  • Cervical trauma (during labour or instrumental delivery)
  • Congenital abnormality

Diagnosis:

History of pregnancy loss in 2nd trimester:

  • TVUS- investigation of choice
  • Normal shape and length of the cervix- T shaped and 3-4 cm
  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm with one 2nd trimester painless abortion, then diagnosed as cervical insufficiency

Non-pregnant women:

If Hegar no. 8 dilator can be passed through internal os without any resistance

Management:

Progesterone and cervical cerclage placement.

Incorrect Options:

Placenta previa (Option B): Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment, potentially covering the internal os of the cervix. A short cervix (25 mm) is not indicative of placenta previa. The predominant indication of placenta previa is bright red vaginal bleeding that is usually painless but is not associated with cervical shortening or funneling.

In abruptio placentae (Option C): The placenta partially or entirely separates from the uterine inner wall before birth. Abruptio placentae is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain, not necessarily associated with cervical changes.

A traumatic injury (Option D): Traumatic injury to the cervix can cause bleeding, but it is not consistent with the painless dilation and funneling seen on transvaginal ultrasound. Also, traumatic injuries are usually associated with a history of trauma or intercourse.

questions.text: Which disease is targeted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, with the insect depicted below acting as the vector?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Japanese encephalitis:

  • The insect shown in the figure above is Culex mosquito which is the vector for Japanese encephalitis.
  • Japanese encephalitis is a viral disease that affects the brain and is transmitted by infected mosquitoes, primarily Culex species.
  • It is targeted under the National vector-borne disease control programs in regions where the disease is endemic.

National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP):

  • Launched: 2002.
  • Includes all vector-borne diseases:

Vector

Disease

Anopheles
  • Malaria

Aedes
  • Dengue & chikungunya

Culex
  • Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans
  • Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui

Sandfly
  • Kala-azar

Images for adult mosquitoes:

 Anopheles

 Aedes

 Culex

Mansonoides

questions.text: What type of waste in the following bag is disposed of through incineration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Yellow

  • Used for disposing of infectious waste and items contaminated with blood, body fluids, or human tissue. This includes pathological waste, soiled dressings, bandages, and animal anatomical waste.
  • These items are incinerated to prevent infection and reduce contamination risk.

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red

(Option B)
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves.
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue

(Option C)
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste.
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts.
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

Black bags (Option D): are typically managed through landfill or other standard waste management methods.

questions.text: Determine the classification of the myoma denoted as '4' in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pedunculated submucosal myoma

Explanation:

  • The structure marked ‘4’ indicates Pedunculated Submucosal Myoma.

Key Features of Pedunculated Submucosal Myoma:

  • Pedunculated fibroids are noncancerous (benign) uterine growths
  • A stalk-like development called a peduncle attaches these fibroids to the uterine wall
  • The peduncle distinguishes pedunculated fibroids from other types of fibroids
  • These fibroids can grow both inside and outside of the uterus
  • This form of development is known as a pedunculated submucosal fibroid inside the uterus.

FIGO Classification of Fibroids:

  • Type 0: Pedunculated or intracavitary or submucosal
  • Type 1: <50% intramural and rest in cavity
  • Type 2: >50% intramural and a part in cavity or submucous
  • Type 3: 100% intramural but touches the cavity
  • Type 4: Intramural
  • Type 5: >50% intramural and rest in serosa (subserosal)
  • Type 6: <50% intramural and rest in serosa (subserosal)
  • Type 7: Subserosal Pedunculated
  • Type 8: Parasitic fibroid (Detached fibroid that may be stuck to the diaphragm or omentum) and cervical fibroid
  • Type 2-5: Part of the fibroid is present both in the cavity (Type 2) and in the serosa (Type 5), and this is known as Hybrid Fibroid

Subserous myoma (Option B): A subserosal fibroid grows on the outside of the uterus and is almost always benign. Some subserosal fibroids are pedunculated. While subserosal fibroid is rarely hazardous, it can cause discomfort and interfere with surrounding organ activities.

Parasitic myoma (Option C): Parasitic fibroids are extrauterine benign tumors. They are known as wandering fibroids or ectopic fibroids because they lack a myometrial link and feed on other abdominopelvic structures to which they are related.

Submucous myoma (Option D): Submucous leiomyomas primarily project into the endometrial cavity and lack a peduncle, as shown in the image.

questions.text: Orthotolidine test is used to determine

choices.text: Free and combined chlorine in water

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Free and combined chlorine in water

  • The orthotolidine-arsenite test (OTA) is used to determine the amount of free chlorine residual.
  • When orthotolidine reagent is added to water containing chlorine, a greenish-yellow colour will appear.

Nitrates (Option A): are typically measured using other specific methods, such as colorimetric tests involving reagents specific to nitrate detection.

Nitrites (Option B): can be detected using different tests, such as the Griess reagent test, which produces a different color change than the OTA test.

Ammonia (Option D): is typically measured using specific ammonia testing methods, such as the Nessler's reagent test or ion-selective electrodes, which produce distinct color changes or electrical signals in the presence of ammonia.

The OTA test:

  • is a colorimetric method commonly used to measure the concentration of free chlorine in water.
  • This test is often used to assess the effectiveness of water treatment processes, particularly those involving chlorination.
  • In the OTA test, orthotolidine reagent is added to a water sample containing free chlorine.
  • If free chlorine is present, a greenish-yellow color will appear, indicating the presence of free chlorine.
  • The intensity of the color change is proportional to the concentration of free chlorine in the water sample. This allows for a quantitative measurement of the chlorine residual.

questions.text: A young woman experiencing amenorrhea, who has a previous history of spontaneous abortion, has a current FSH level of 6 mIU/ml. What is the potential cause for the given manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Asherman syndrome

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations point towards Asherman syndrome, indicated by presentation of amenorrhea in a young woman with normal FSH levels and a history of spontaneous abortion (which may have required uterine curettage). This indicates amenorrhea resulting from mechanical factors rather than hormonal dysfunction (normal FSH levels)

  • Asherman syndrome is the formation of scar tissue (also called adhesions or intrauterine adhesions) in the uterine cavity.
  • The problem most often develops after operative hysteroscopy, Dilation and Curettage (D&C) and Cesarean section, as a side effect of cancer treatment or infection.
  • The adhesions may cause amenorrhea (lack of menstrual periods), hypomenorrhea, repeated miscarriages, and infertility.
  • FSH levels are not high or low (6 mIU/ml is normal), indicating a case of typical Ashermann Syndrome

Incorrect Options:

Sheehan's syndrome (Option A) presents with hypopituitarism following severe postpartum hemorrhage, leading to low FSH levels and other pituitary hormonal deficiencies. The normal FSH level, in this case, rules out this condition.

Premature ovarian failure (Option B): For the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure, the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) should be > 20 IU/l.

PCOS (Option C): PCOS typically presents with irregular menses, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. While FSH levels may be normal, the absence of hyperandrogenic symptoms point away from this diagnosis. Also, PCOS patients typically have oligomenorrhea rather than complete amenorrhea.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines do not follow open vial policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Measles

  • Measles vaccine do not follow open vial policy

Open vial policy

  • States that “vaccine vials, once opened, can be reused in subsequent sessions for up to 28 days, provided that they are maintained in appropriate cold chain conditions to reduce the wastage of vaccines.
  • All liquid vaccines follow open-vial policies.
    • Eg: Hepatitis B, DPT, Pentavalent, OPV, IPV, PCV, Td.
  • Reconstituted vaccines such as MMR, BCG, JE, Yellow fever vaccine along with Rotavirus vaccine do not follow open vial policy

questions.text: A public health worker is going out into the community once every 15 days for collection of blood smears for malaria surveillance. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Active

  • Active surveillance involves proactive efforts to collect data. In the scenario, the worker regularly collects blood smears for malaria surveillance, indicating proactive data collection.

Surveillance is the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data to plan, implement, and evaluate public health practice.

Types:

  • Passive Surveillance: relies on routine reporting from healthcare providers or institutions without additional efforts to enhance reporting (Option C)
  • Active Surveillance involves proactive data collection, where health authorities actively search for cases of diseases.

The 4 diseases that are actively screened in India:

  • Polio: AFP (Acute Flaccid Paralysis) by SMO (Senior Medical Officer)
  • Malaria: By MPW (Multipurpose Worker)
  • Kala Azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis): Depending on the region or program specifics, various healthcare personnel may be involved in the surveillance and reporting.
  • Tuberculosis: By ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) worker

Sentinel Surveillance involves monitoring a specific subset of the population or healthcare facilities representing the larger population. E.g., HIV/AIDS screening done in ANC, Blood banks, and STD Clinics (Option A)

Syndromic surveillance monitors non-specific health indicators or syndromes (e.g., fever surveillance for malaria, cough for 2w for TB, Flu symptoms for COVID) to detect potential outbreaks or public health emergencies early, analyzing symptom data patterns.

questions.text: A couple visited the outpatient department due to their inability to conceive. The husband's semen analysis came back as normal. The wife complained of excessive menstrual bleeding, and a hysterosalpingogram revealed the presence of distal tube dilatation resembling a "tobacco pouch appearance." What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tubal salpingitis

Explanation:

The clinical findings indicate Tubal salpingitis, indicated by the characteristic "Tobacco pouch" appearance on hysterosalpingogram.

  • Tubal Salpingitis causes granulomas to grow in the mucosa and on the surface of the tubes at first.
  • These granulomas undergo caseous ulceration leading to mucosal irregularity, which manifests as the ragged contour of the lumen of the tubes and diverticular outpouchings (salpingitis isthmica nodosa [SIN] appearance on hysterosalpingography [HSG]).
  • Tobacco pouch appearance occurs because of the version of the fimbria secondary to adhesions, with a patent orifice producing the tobacco pouch appearance

Appearance of the Tubes:

  • The tubal infection starts as endosalpingitis and is usually bilateral
  • Calcific, rigid, and beaded in appearance
  • Tubes are mostly blocked, causing hydrosalpinx
  • Tobacco pouch shaped
  • Retort shaped hydrosalpinx

Incorrect Options:

Tubal endometriosis (Option B): The appearance of the tobacco pouch on the hysterosalpingogram is not indicative of tubal endometriosis.

Tubal polyp (Option C): HSG can reveal abnormalities on the inside of the uterus, such as polyps, fibroids, adhesions, and/or a uterine septum. However, tubal polyps appear as smooth, rounded, or oval fillings.

Tubal spasm (Option D): The tubal spasm occurs when the tubal muscles contract and therefore block the tubes, which is not seen in the radiological image. It is often caused when the HSG dye is forcefully injected.

questions.text: What is the predominant factor leading to consumptive coagulopathy in the field of obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placental abruption

Explanation:

  • Placental abruption, a serious obstetric emergency where the placenta separates from the uterine wall before delivery, can lead to DIC due to the release of tissue factor into the maternal circulation. This triggers the coagulation cascade, leading to widespread clotting and consumption of clotting factors.

Key Causes of Consumptive Coagulopathy:

Cause

Description

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

DIC is a condition characterized by widespread activation of blood clotting mechanisms, leading to the formation of small clots throughout the body

Preeclampsia

Preeclampsia is a hypertensive disorder that can lead to organ damage, including liver dysfunction, which may trigger consumptive coagulopathy

HELLP syndrome

HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

This rare condition affects liver function and may result in a consumptive coagulopathy due to liver dysfunction

Septic abortion

Septic abortion refers to an infection of the products of conception, which can cause inflammation and abnormal clotting

Placenta percreta/increta/accreta

These conditions involve abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall, which can lead to significant bleeding and coagulation abnormalities

Incorrect Options:

Intrauterine death (Option A): Intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) can lead to DIC in the mother. When the fetus dies in utero, products of fetal tissue breakdown enter the maternal circulation, activating the coagulation cascade. While IUFD can cause DIC, it is not the predominant factor.

Sepsis (Option C): Sepsis, especially severe cases, can lead to DIC in obstetric patients. While sepsis is a potential cause of consumptive coagulopathy, it is not the predominant cause.

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option D): AFE is a serious obstetric emergency that occurs when amniotic fluid enters the maternal bloodstream, triggering an immune response and leading to a systemic inflammatory reaction, coagulopathy, and cardiovascular collapse. However, it is an uncommon cause in obstetrical patients.

questions.text: What phase of the demographic cycle is the low stationary phase of demographic cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Phase 4

  • Phase 4 of the demographic cycle is known as the Low Stationary phase. In this phase, both birth rates and death rates are low, resulting in a stable or slow-growing population.

According to the demographic transition model, a country goes through 5 phases.

Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

I. High stationery (Option A)

 

High

High

Population is stable

II. Early expanding (Option B)

 

High

Starts declining

Population grows at faster rate . Also called demographic trap

III. Late expanding (Option C)

 

Starts declining

Keeps declining

Population grows at slower rate (birth > death)

IV. Low stationery

Low

Low

Stable population

V. Declining

Low

Lower

Population declines (death rate > birth rate)

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

Explanation:

  • Patients who have undergone heart valve replacement with a prosthetic mechanical valve require lasting anticoagulation.
  • Warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy as it can cause birth defects (teratogenicity) during the first trimester and hemorrhagic complications during about 2 to 4 weeks before delivery.
  • LMWHs don't pass the placenta and are safer for the developing fetus.

Teratogenicity of Anticoagulants:

Medicine

FDA category

Adverse effects

Teratogenic

Use during lactation

Remark

Vitamin K antagonists (warfarin)

X

Teratogenicity, fetal bleeding complications

Yes

Allowed: Small amounts of metabolites pass into breast milk

-

Heparin (UFH)

C

Bone demineralization, osteoporosis, fractures in mother, risk of HIT

No

Allowed

-

LMWH

B

Lower risk of HIT and osteoporosis than UFH

No

Allowed

-

Danaparoid

B

-

No

Allowed

-

Incorrect Options:

Heparin anticoagulants (Option B) are less effective than VKAs for anticoagulation with mechanical heart valves, leaving the pregnant patient more vulnerable to a thrombotic event.

Continuing warfarin use (Option C) in early pregnancy can increase the chance of miscarriage and bleeding in the baby's brain. Warfarin use in early pregnancy can affect the baby's bones and development of the face.

Combining LMWH and aspirin (Option D) can increase the risk of bleeding complications in the patient; hence, it should be avoided.

questions.text: The average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in her age group is called as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Total fertility rate

  • Total Fertility Rate (TFR) estimates the average number of children per woman during reproductive years.

The Total Fertility rate (TFR):

gives the average number of children a woman will have throughout her reproductive age group (15-49 years).

  • TFR indicates average family size.
  • Family size is the number of children a woman has at a particular age within her reproductive years (15-49).
  • Complete family size is the total number of children a woman has throughout her reproductive lifespan (until she is 49 years old).
  • TFR is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates across all age groups. If 5-year age groups are used, then the sum of rates is multiplied by 5.

TFR = 5 ×15-1945-49ASFR/1000

General Fertility Rate (Option A) : The general fertility rate (GFR) measures live births per 1,000 women but doesn't estimate total children.

Gross reproduction rate (GRR) (Option B): GRR measures daughters born to a hypothetical cohort if they experience age-specific fertility rates.

Net Reproduction Rate (Option D): Net reproduction rate (NRR) estimates the daughters a woman has over her lifetime, considering mortality, not the total number of children.

questions.text:
What is the diagnosis for a 23-year-old female who has been experiencing fever for the past week and displays the following rhythm on the monitor?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atrial fibrillation

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Atrial fibrillation
  • Atrial fibrillation is a cardiac rhythm disorder characterized by rapid, irregular electrical impulses in the atria.
  • This results in a rapid and irregular ventricular response, leading to an irregular heart rate on the monitor.

 

Atrial flutter (Option B): typically appears as a regular, sawtooth pattern on the monitor, rather than the irregular pattern seen in this case.

 

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmia (Option C):

  • is a broad term that encompasses various rapid heart rhythms originating from above the ventricles.
  • It includes conditions like atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and other supraventricular tachycardias. While atrial fibrillation is a type of supraventricular tachyarrhythmia, it is more specific than the general term used in this option.

 

Ventricular tachyarrhythmia (Option D): refers to abnormal rapid rhythms that originate in the ventricles. This rhythm disorder is characterized by a wide QRS complex on the monitor, unlike the narrow QRS complex typically seen in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: What is the most reliable indicator of recent malaria transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Infant parasite rate

  • The Infant parasite rate refers to the proportion of infants or young children who are infected with malaria parasites.
  • Infants are particularly susceptible to malaria infection, and their infection rates can be a reliable indicator of recent malaria transmission within a community.

The infant parasite rate (IPR) is the most sensitive indicator of recent malaria transmission in a population.

If the IPR remains 0 for 3 consecutive years, the population can be considered free from malaria transmission.

Note: The vectors responsible for previous malaria transmission in a population will not be included in the IPR results.

Spleen rate (Option A): The spleen rate is an indicator of chronic or long-term malaria infection.

Parasite density index (Option C): The parasite density index reflects the intensity of infection in individuals but may not be as sensitive for assessing recent transmission on a population level.

Slide positivity rate (Option D): is commonly used as an indicator of malaria prevalence and can provide insights into ongoing transmission. However, the Infant parasite rate is considered to be a more sensitive index for recent transmission.

questions.text: What is the adverse effect linked to intravenous bolus administration of oxytocin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypotension

Explanation:

  • Oxytocin is given to women during caesarean section to decrease blood loss. When given as a rapid I.V. bolus, it can cause hypotension and tachycardia.

Different Uses and Recommended Doses of Oxytocin:

  1. Induction of Labor:
    • Initial: 0.5-1 milliunits/min IV infusion, gradually increasing by 1-2 milliunits/min every 15-60 min
    • Adverse Effects: Uterine hyperstimulation, fetal distress, water intoxication
  2. Augmentation of Labor:
    • Similar dosing to induction
    • Adverse Effects: Uterine hyperstimulation, fetal distress
  3. Prevention/Management of Postpartum Hemorrhage:
    • IV infusion: 10-40 units in 1000 mL of solution at 20-40 milliunits/min
    • Adverse Effects: Uterine hyperstimulation, postpartum hemorrhage (with excessive doses)

Different Side Effects Of Oxytocin And Their Causes

Side Effects

Causes

Uterine Hyperstimulation
  • High dosage or rapid increase in Oxytocin infusion rate
  • Prolonged administration of Oxytocin

Fetal Distress

Uterine hyperstimulation leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the fetus

Water Intoxication

Prolonged high-dose administration of Oxytocin

Nausea and Vomiting

Direct stimulation of the vomiting center in the brain by Oxytocin

Headache

Vasodilation and changes in cerebral blood flow caused by Oxytocin

Hypotension

Oxytocin-induced vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance

Postpartum Hemorrhage

Rarely, high doses of Oxytocin may contribute to uterine atony or excessive uterine contractions

Allergic Reactions

Hypersensitivity or allergic response to Oxytocin or other components of the medication

Cardiac Arrhythmias

Direct effects of Oxytocin on cardiac electrical activity

Maternal Fluid Overload

Oxytocin-induced antidiuretic effect leading to fluid retention

Uterine Rupture (Rare)

Excessive uterine contractions or hyperstimulation of the uterus

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which of the following immunoglobulins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IgE

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of facial swelling, itching, and hypotension suggest anaphylaxis, an allergic reaction mediated by IgE antibodies that trigger the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils upon exposure to an allergen, such as a bee sting.

Type I hypersensitivity reactions involve an immediate (early) and a late-phase reaction.

 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin).

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock.

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

IgA (Option A) primarily involves mucosal immunity and protects against pathogens at mucosal surfaces (e.g., in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts), not in allergic reactions.

IgM (Option C) is the first antibody produced in response to infection but is not involved in allergic reactions like those caused by bee stings.

IgG (Option D) plays a crucial role in immunity and neutralising toxins, but it is not the primary immunoglobulin involved in allergic reactions, which are driven by IgE.

questions.text: In the Ayushman Bharat scheme, what is the annual health insurance coverage offered to a qualifying family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 5 lakhs per family per year:

  • In the Ayushman Bharat scheme, also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), the health insurance package provided for an eligible family is 5 lakhs per family per year.
  • This means that eligible families can avail medical treatment and hospitalization services up to a maximum coverage of 5 lakhs (Indian Rupees) per year.

Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana.

  • Launched in 2018
  • Aim: To achieve Universal Health Coverage in India.
  • It is a flexible scheme.
    • It is not rigid or mandatory for all states to follow.
    • The States can opt to choose.
  • Private Hospitals that have up to 10 beds can provide services under Ayushman Bharat Scheme.
  • It comes under the National Health Protection Scheme Modi Care.
  • Provides insurance coverage - 5 lakh per family, per year.
  • There is no restriction on number of family members.

questions.text: After 18 hours of which peak in the provided image is associated with the occurrence of ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:

Ovulation occurs during Luteinizing hormone peak, which stimulates egg release (ovulation), which usually occurs 16 to 32 hours after the surge begins.

  • The process of ovulation begins when the hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).
  • GnRH causes the pituitary gland to secrete follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
  • The ovulatory phase begins with a surge in luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone levels.

Hormonal Changes During Menstrual Cycle

Menstrual Phase

Follicular Phase

Ovulation

Luteal Phase

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Increased levels

    

Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

  

Surge in LH levels

  

Estrogen

Low levels

Increased levels

High levels

Progesterone

    

Increased levels

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother delivered an Rh-positive baby, and Coomb’s test was positive for the baby. What is the mechanism of hypersensitivity seen in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity

Explanation:

  • This scenario involves Type II hypersensitivity, where the Rh-negative mother’s immune system produces IgG antibodies against her fetus's Rh-positive red blood cells.
  • These antibodies cross the placenta and bind to the fetal red blood cells, initiating their destruction by activating immune cells through antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).
  • This leads to hemolytic disease in the newborn and results in a positive Coomb's test, which detects antibodies bound to the fetal red blood cells.

Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
  • Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation rather than phagocytosis or cell lysis.
  • The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, attracting neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors.
  • Activated leukocytes release enzymes, causing tissue damage.
  • Goodpasture syndrome.
  • Acute rheumatic fever.

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
 

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).
  • Graves disease
  • Myasthenia gravis

Note: Myasthenia gravis and Graves disease are now classified as Type V hypersensitivity (Type V > Type II)
Type V hypersensitivity reaction: Antibodies against cellular receptors.

Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

 

Type II hypersensitivity (Antibody-mediated)

Opsonisation and complement activation→Phagocytosis

Transfusion reaction, erythroblastosis fetalis, AIHA, ITP.

Complement, Fc receptor-mediated →Inflammation.

Goodpasture syndrome, Acute Rheumatic fever, vascular rejections, vasculitis.

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunctions.

Myasthenia gravis, Pemphigus Vulgaris, Graves disease, Pernicious Anemia, Insulin-resistant diabetes, Hemolytic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branch filaments like a ‘Spaghetti and meatball appearance’ as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Malassezia

Explanation:

Tinea Versicolor (Pityriasis Versicolor)

  • A superficial fungal infection of the stratum corneum (outer skin layer)
  • Mostly asymptomatic but may lead to visible skin discolouration
  • Prevalent in tropical climates, commonly affecting young adults
  • Causative agent: Malassezia furfur (previously called Pityrosporum orbiculare)
  • Appearance:
    • Presents as discrete or confluent macular lesions
    • Affected areas show pigmentation changes (hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation)
  • Commonly affected sites:
    • Chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back

Diagnostic Tools:

Test/Tool

Findings

Microscopy (Skin Scrapings)

Abundant yeast cells and short, branched filaments (yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments)

Spaghetti and meatball appearance under KOH microscopy

Culture

Grown on Sabouraud agar with an olive oil overlay.

Wood’s Lamp Exam

Infected areas fluoresce golden-yellow under UV light.

Trichophyton (Option B) is a genus of fungi, which includes the parasitic varieties that cause tinea, including athlete's foot, ringworm, jock itch, and similar infections of the nail, beard, skin, and scalp. Trichophyton is white and cottony on the surface, and the underside is usually red. Microscopically pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped macronidia are seen

Chlamydospores (Option C) are produced by candida and represent enlarged, thick-walled vegetative cells with varied forms and condensed cytoplasm that forms within hyphae or at hyphal tips. Chlamydospores cause diseases like Aspergillosis, Blastomycosis, Coccidioidomycosis, and Histoplasmosis.

Candida (Option D) species are opportunistic yeasts that cause infections such as cutaneous candidiasis and oral thrush. Candida appears as budding yeast with pseudohyphae.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps in the adhesion of the leukocyte to the endothelium during inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) VCAM-1

Explanation:

  • VCAM-1 (Vascular Cell Adhesion Molecule-1) is involved in the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium during inflammation. It binds to integrins on the surface of leukocytes, facilitating their migration through the endothelium to the site of injury or infection.

Leukocyte Adhesion to Endothelium:

  • In normal blood flow, leukocytes are pushed to the edges of the vessel.
  • In inflammation, stasis causes leukocytes to slow down and interact with endothelial cells. This interaction involves selectins and integrins, which mediate the rolling and firm adhesion of leukocytes.

 

 

  • Selectins: These are responsible for the initial rolling interactions. There are three types:
    • L-selectin on leukocytes
    • E-selectin on endothelial cells
    • P-selectin (Option A) on both platelets and endothelial cells

The ligands for selectins are sialylated oligosaccharides on mucin-like glycoproteins. Cytokines like TNF and IL-1 upregulate the expression of selectins, promoting leukocyte rolling along the vessel wall.

  • Integrins: After rolling, leukocytes bind more firmly to the endothelium via integrins, such as VLA-4 and LFA-1 (CD11a & CD18), which interact with endothelial ligands like VCAM-1 and ICAM-1. This firm adhesion halts the rolling process and allows leukocytes to flatten and spread on the endothelial surface.

 

Migration: Once firmly adhered, leukocytes migrate through the endothelial layer (transmigration), facilitated by adhesion molecules like PECAM-1 (CD31). After exiting the vessel, they follow the chemotactic gradient toward the site of inflammation.

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) (Option B) is a potent mediator of inflammation, influencing various processes like platelet aggregation, vasodilation, and immune cell activation, but it does not directly contribute to leukocyte adhesion to the endothelium.

Complement (Option D) proteins are part of the immune system and are involved in opsonisation, lysis of pathogens, and inflammation. However, they do not directly mediate the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic. The findings of the microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic and the microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Vivax

Malariae

Ovale

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm)

Fills the RBC

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form
