Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.text: The current approach for the initial screening of women for cervical cancer at a primary health center is-

choices.text: Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution:

  • Visual inspection after the application of a 5% acetic acid solution, also known as VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid)
  • is a widely used and effective method for the initial screening of cervical cancer in resource-limited settings.

Visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA):

  • is a simple and cost-effective method that involves the application of 5% acetic acid to the cervix.
  • The acid causes any abnormal areas to turn white, which can be visually detected.
  • VIA is a suitable screening method in primary health centers as it does not require sophisticated equipment or extensive training.
  • If an abnormal area is detected, further diagnostic tests such as colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be recommended.

Colposcopy (Option B): Is not typically used as an initial screening method in primary health centers due to the need for specialized equipment and trained personnel.

Cervical biopsy (Option C): Is an invasive procedure and is not typically performed as part of the initial screening process.

High vaginal biopsy (Option D: Is not a specific screening method for cervical cancer and is not commonly used as an initial screening strategy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a pillar of primary health care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Health education

  • Health education, while not explicitly listed as a pillar of primary health care, is an essential component of comprehensive primary health care.
  • It plays a vital role in empowering individuals and communities to make informed decisions about their health, prevent diseases, promote healthy behaviors, and enhance overall well-being.

Four Pillars of Primary Health Care:

Equitable distribution (Option D)
  • Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status.

Intersectoral coordination (Option B)
  • Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc.
  • Maintains good health.

Appropriate technology (Option C)
  • Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community
  • Eg:
    • ORS
    • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label
    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation

  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.
  • Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community.

questions.text: What is the most probable tumour that a 22-year-old woman with a sizable growth in her right ovary, which has been determined to originate from all three germ layers based on histopathology, is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Teratoma

Explanation:

  • Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries.
  • They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers.

Immature teratoma:

  • Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary.
  • They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy.
  • They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components).

Mature teratoma

  • Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases.
  • They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Grossly, they are unilocular cysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands.

 

Monodermal teratoma:

  • Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy.

 

Dysgerminoma (Option A) is also a type of germ cell tumour (GCT) that typically secretes beta hCG.

 

Thecoma (Option C) is a rare benign tumour originating from the ovarian stroma, accounting for less than 1% of all ovarian tumours. It is most commonly found in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.

 

Theca lutein cysts (Option D) are rare benign cystic lesions caused by hypertrophy of the theca interna layer due to excessive stimulation by hCG.

questions.text: What is the current ideal total fertility rate in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 2.1

  • The desirable fertility rate that will result in relative stability of total population numbers is 2.1 for India and is the replacement rate for the population.
  • As per 2023, the fertility rate is 2.139 births per woman.

The Total Fertility rate (TFR) gives the average number of children a woman will have throughout her reproductive age group (15-49 years).

  • TFR indicates average family size.
  • Family size is the number of children a woman has at a particular age within her reproductive years (15-49).
  • Complete family size is the total number of children a woman has throughout her reproductive lifespan (until she is 49 years old).
  • TFR is calculated by summing the age-specific fertility rates across all age groups. If 5-year age groups are used, then the sum of rates is multiplied by 5.

TFR = 5 ×15-1945-49ASFR/1000

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an 18-year-old male with gum bleeding, fever for two months, pallor, low haemoglobin (3 gm/dL), low TLC (1500/microL), low platelet count (15000/microL), macrocytes on peripheral smear, 0.5% reticulocyte count, and bone marrow examination showing fatty streaks and a lack of megakaryocytes but no immature cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with gum bleeding, prolonged fever, pallor, and pancytopenia. Bone marrow examination shows fatty streaks, a lack of megakaryocytes, and no immature cells, suggesting idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, where bone marrow failure leads to hematologic abnormalities.
  • Aplastic anaemia is a condition of primary hematopoietic failure resulting in pancytopenia (anaemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia), often due to autoimmune mechanisms or inherited/acquired abnormalities in hematopoietic stem cells.

Etiology:

  • Common causes:
    • Chemical and drug exposure (e.g., chemotherapy, benzene)
    • Viral infections (e.g., hepatitis, linked to 5% of cases)
    • Radiation exposure (e.g., therapeutic or nuclear accidents)
  • Genetic causes:
    • Fanconi anaemia: Rare autosomal recessive disorder with congenital anomalies (kidney, spleen hypoplasia, bone anomalies).
    • Telomerase defects: Found in 5-10% of adult-onset cases, causing premature exhaustion of hematopoietic stem cells.
  • Idiopathic cases: No identifiable cause in ~65% of cases.

Morphology:

  • Bone Marrow:
    • Hypocellular marrow with fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes/plasma cells.
    • "Dry tap" on marrow aspirates (due to lack of hematopoietic cells).
  • Peripheral Blood:
    • Macrocytic, normochromic red cells with reticulocytopenia.
    • Granulocytopenia (leading to infections) and thrombocytopenia (leading to bleeding).

Clinical features:

  • Onset: Insidious, with progressive pancytopenia.
  • Anaemia: Weakness, pallor, dyspnea.
  • Thrombocytopenia: Petechiae, ecchymosis.
  • Neutropenia: Frequent infections, chills, fever.
  • Splenomegaly: Generally absent.
  • Red Cells: Slightly macrocytic and normochromic.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on bone marrow biopsy, showing hypocellularity.
  • Must differentiate from other causes of pancytopenia, like leukaemia or myelodysplastic syndrome, where the marrow is typically hypercellular.

 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) (Option B) is a rare acquired disorder where red blood cells are destroyed by complement. It often presents with hemolysis and episodes of dark urine, especially at night. The peripheral smear in PNH shows evidence of hemolysis and pancytopenia, but bone marrow findings would not show fatty streaks with a lack of megakaryocytes, as in this case.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) (Option C) typically presents with cytopenias and abnormal blood cell morphology. Bone marrow findings in MDS often show dysplastic changes in blood cells, which would not correlate with the lack of immature cells seen here. Additionally, the absence of megakaryocytes and the presence of fatty streaks suggest aplasia rather than dysplastic hematopoiesis.

Tuberculosis (TB) (Option D): While TB can cause systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss, it is not typically associated with pancytopenia, macrocytic anaemia, and bone marrow findings of fatty streaks with a lack of megakaryocytes. TB may affect bone marrow in disseminated forms, but the presentation and lab findings here point more to an intrinsic hematopoietic failure like aplastic anaemia.

questions.text: The most effective approach to educating an urban slum community about oral rehydration solution (ORS) is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Demonstration

  • The best method is to tell them the technique by showing them the technique.
  • The demonstration is also known as two-way or Socratic communication.
  • It relies on the principle of "Seeing is believing and learning by doing."
  • It is one of the most efficient behavior change methods because it involves 'community participation.'

Demonstration:

  • is the best method for teaching practical skills, especially in low-literacy or semi-literate communities. It allows individuals to see how ORS is prepared and used, making it easy to understand and replicate.
  • Visual and hands-on learning are highly effective for retention, especially when dealing with health practices like mixing the correct proportions of water, salt, and sugar for ORS.

Reasons why the Demonstration method is highly effective in health education:

(a) dramatizes by arousing interest

(b) persuades the onlookers to adopt recommended practices

(c) upholds the principles of "seeing is believing" and "learning by doing", and

(d) can bring desirable changes m the behavior about the use of the new practice.

Lecture (Option A): Less engaging, especially in communities with lower literacy or interest in theoretical teaching.

Roleplay (Option B): Useful for Life saving skills, but less practical for teaching step-by-step processes like preparing ORS.

Flashcards (Option C): Limited effectiveness in communities with low literacy and may not adequately convey the exact preparation technique.

questions.text: What is the primary risk factor for the disease in a patient who exhibits symptoms of a black, malodorous nasal discharge, along with the presence of a black, necrotic mass that fills the nasal cavity and causes erosion of the septum and hard palate during examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diabetes

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of black, necrotic mass that fills the nasal cavity and causes erosion of the septum and hard palate is suggestive mucormycosis. Rhizopus Arrhizus also known as R. oryzae is the most common causative organism of mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients.

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

 

 

Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.

Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.

Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features

Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:

Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.

Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.

Pulmonary Zygomycosis:

Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:

Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.

Medical control of diabetes is required.

Hypothyroidism (Option A) does not predispose to fungal infections, can cause fatigue, weight gain, and dry skin, but does not lead to tissue necrosis or black nasal discharge.

Hypertension (Option C) not a risk factor for mucormycosis. Hypertension is associated with cardiovascular diseases.

Foreign body (Option D) can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge, especially in children.

questions.text: A middle-aged man working in the sandblasting industry developed hemoptysis and a productive cough. A chest x-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Silicosis

Explanation:

  • Silicosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like sandblasting.
  • It is associated with a higher risk of developing tuberculosis due to the impairment of the immune response in the lung

Silicosis:

  • It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease in the world.
  • Cause: Inhalation of proinflammatory crystalline silicon dioxide (silica).
  • After decades of exposure, it usually presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • Occupations at risk:
    • Foundry work.
    • Sandblasting.
    • Hard rock mining.
    • Stone cutting.
    • Jewellers using chalk moulds.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Phagocytosis of inhaled silica crystals by macrophages activates the inflammasome and stimulates the release of inflammatory mediators, particularly IL-1 and IL-18.
    • This, in turn, recruits additional inflammatory cells and activates interstitial fibroblasts, leading to collagen deposition.
  • Forms of silica:
    • Amorphous.
    • Crystalline (quartz, cristobalite, and tridymite)- more fibrogenic.
  • Forms of silicosis:
    • Acute
      • Heavy exposure in closed spaces
      • Associated with Silico-tuberculosis and Secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis ( SPAP)
      • Can present within 2 years.
    • Chronic (simple):
      • Long-term (10-30 years)
      • less intense exposure.
      • Chronic Complicated: Chronic cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion.
  • Morphology:
    • Discrete nodules in hilar nodes and upper zones of lungs.
    • Hard collagenous scars.
    • Fibrotic lesions in nodes and pleura (pleural thickening).
    • Eggshell calcification (thin sheets of calcification in lymph nodes; calcium surrounding a zone lacking calcification).
    • Progressive massive fibrosis (1-10 cm).
    • Lung cancer (2-fold risk).
    • Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis infection.
    • Histological hallmark: Central collagen with a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages.
    • Polarized microscopy: Weakly birefringent silicate particles.
    • CT scan: Crazy pavement pattern and interstitial fibrosis.

 

Asbestosis (Option A) is caused by inhaling asbestos fibres, primarily leading to lung fibrosis and increasing the risk of lung cancer and mesothelioma. However, it is not directly linked to an increased risk of tuberculosis.

 

Anthracosis (Option C), or "coal miner’s lung," results from inhaling coal dust. It can cause chronic bronchitis or emphysema but does not have a direct association with tuberculosis.

 

Siderosis (Option D) is caused by inhaling iron oxide dust, typically seen in occupations like welding. It can lead to pulmonary fibrosis but does not significantly increase the risk of tuberculosis.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 48-year-old patient who came with scrotal swelling, had elevated LDH levels but normal AFP levels on tests for testicular tumours, and exhibited a specific histological picture after orchidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Seminoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological findings suggest testicular seminoma.
  • Seminomas elevate LDH levels, while AFP remains normal.
  • Histology shows large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli.

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG.
  • Morphology: Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Histology of seminoma:
    • Sheets of monomorphic cells.
    • The sheets are divided into poorly demarcated lobules by the septa of the fibrous tissue.
    • The septa show lymphocytic infiltration (T lymphocytes).
    • The classic seminoma cell is large and round to polyhedral with a distinct cell membrane and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli.
    • The cytoplasm is clear or watery appearing and contains glycogen.
    • The arrows in the image below show seminomatous tumour cells.

Source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Testis_seminoma_3.jpg

 

Testicular Tumour

Corresponding Tumor Markers

Seminoma
  • Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP)
  • HCG
  • LDH
  • Newer markers: Oct 3/4, Nanog, CD117, SALL4

Embryonal Carcinoma
  • CD-30

Yolk sac tumour
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Choriocarcinoma
  • Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG)

Teratoma
  • Cytokeratin

questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HFE

Explanation:

  • Hereditary hemochromatosis is due to an HFE gene mutation on chromosome 6p that causes excess iron absorption, leading to increased iron deposition. This results in the classic triad of cirrhosis, secondary diabetes mellitus, and bronze skin.

Hereditary Hemochromatosis:

  • Laboratory findings: High ferritin, high serum iron and low TIBC.
  • Liver biopsy: Golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in periportal hepatocytes that appear blue with a Prussian blue stain followed by a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis.
  • Other findings: dilated cardiomyopathy (M/C cardiac manifestation).
  • Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma
  • In Hemochromatosis, skin colour changes due to the deposition of excessive melanin >> iron in the skin.
  • It is also known as "bronze diabetes" due to skin discolouration and associated pancreatic disease & typically manifests after 20 g of stored iron has accumulated in the body.

Organs affected

Clinical features

Liver

Hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, risk of HCC

Pancreas

Iron-induced damage of beta cells - diabetes mellitus

Heart

Cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, congestive heart failure

Skin

Hyperpigmentation (bronze skin due to melanin and iron deposition)

Joints

Arthropathy and joint pain

CNS

Rarely - Memory issues, depression and fatigue

Hemochromatosis is of two types:

Types of hemochromatosis

Features

Hereditary hemochromatosis

  • HFE-related: It is the classic form of hereditary hemochromatosis that is inherited in an autosomal recessive (chromosome 6p)
  • HAMP gene mutation-related
  • HJV gene mutation (juvenile hemochromatosis

Acquired/secondary hemochromatosis

  • Repeated blood transfusion
  • Excessive oral intake or iron

 

PTEN (Option B) is a tumour suppressor gene linked to certain cancers and is not associated with hemochromatosis.

ATP7B gene (Option C) mutations cause Wilson's disease, which involves copper accumulation, not iron overload, as in hemochromatosis.

MRP2 protein (Option D) is involved in bile excretion and is related to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, not hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Erythema infectiosum

Explanation:

Parvovirus

Morphology

  • Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size).
  • Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry.
  • Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA.
  • Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication.

Pathogenesis
  • Exclusively infects humans.
  • Transmission:
  • Primarily through the respiratory route.
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Transplacental transmission.
  • Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver.
  • Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface.
  • Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.

 

 

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A )
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: Condyloma acuminata is most commonly caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HPV 6, 11

Explanation:

Condyloma acuminata means anogenital warts characterized by small, light brown, gray, or skin-colored bumps caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). They are usually painless but can grow large and cause itching and bleeding. The most common strains of HPV that cause anogenital warts are 6 and 11. The virus can infect the skin of the genitals, anus, mouth, and throat.

Condyloma accuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential. Caused by HPV 6,11.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Appearance: They are generally pink and project out from the surface of the skin. Size may vary; they usually appear small but can merge into large masses.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17
  • Anogenital warts
  • Laryngeal papilloma
  • Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling, and his jaw is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mumps

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week, testicular swelling and jaw swelling is indicative of Mumps.
  • Mumps is a paramyxovirus. It presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, myalgia, and anorexia, and specific symptoms:
    • Bilateral parotitis, the most common presentation, is characterized by acute non-suppurative enlargement of the gland.
    • Second most common manifestation - unilateral orchitis (male) and oophoritis (female), develops in 15–30% of cases in postpubertal males. Orchitis is unilateral in most of the cases.

 

Complications of Mumps

Orchitis (Option B)

The most common extra salivary gland manifestation of mumps in post pubertal patients.

Common among adolescents and is usually unilateral.

Oophoritis

Most common among adolescents and is mostly unilateral.

Pancreatitis

Mumps is the leading cause of pancreatitis in children.

Aseptic Meningitis

The most common complication of mumps.

Sensorineural Deafness

Mumps is one of the most common infectious causes of sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Croup (Option A) is a common respiratory illness of the trachea, larynx, and bronchi that can lead to inspiratory stridor and barking cough. The parainfluenza virus and H. influenza.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option C) aka kissing disease is most frequently caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), characterized by fever, sore throat, arthralgia, lethargy, and organomegaly (splenomegaly).

Herpangina (Option D) is an acute febrile fever accompanied by tiny ulcerative or vesicular lesions in the pharynx caused by Coxsackie A virus, and enterovirus 71.

questions.text: What steps should be taken to manage the case of a 24-year-old male who was hit by a motorbike while crossing the road, leading to abdominal injuries and bruising, with a blood pressure of 88/60 and IV fluids already administered, along with a positive FAST examination?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Exploratory laparotomy

Explanation:

  • Exploratory laparotomy indicated in patients with a positive FAST assessment to avoid further bleeding in the abdomen.
  • Hemodynamically unstable patients (BP <90 mmHg, signs of shock) with positive FAST should undergo emergency exploratory laparotomy to identify and control the source of bleeding.

CT scan (Abdominal/Pelvic) (Option A) is indicated only for hemodynamically stable patients. Since this patient is unstable, CT is not appropriate.

Abdominal MRI scan (Option B) MRIs are usually preferred for investigation of Soft tissue pathology, bone pathology, and head trauma.

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage (DPL) (Option D) is rarely used now, as FAST is the preferred modality for detecting intra-abdominal bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37°C, and motile at 25°C. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Listeria

Explanation:

Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults can lead to meningitis, particularly in elderly individuals or those who are immunocompromised.

 

Listeria monocytogenes

Mode of Transmission
  • Contaminated food
  • Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth)

Common Food Sources
  • Contaminated coleslaw
  • Milk, Soft cheeses
  • "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs)

Age Groups at Risk
  • Neonates
  • Elderly individuals

Increased Risk Factors
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors
  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Survival in Food
  • Survives refrigeration (4°C)
  • Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads)

Infection Type
  • Sporadic
  • Outbreaks can occur

Psychrotrophic
  • L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC.

Motility
  • Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C)

Pathogenesis
  • Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O)
  • Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach)
  • Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods)

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease
  • Pregnant women:
    • Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester
    • Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery)
    • Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis)
  • Adults:
    • Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years)
    • Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy)
    • Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant)
    • Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads)

Streptococcus (Option B) Streptococcus pneumoniae is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis but is not motile at any temperature.

Staphylococcus (Option C) Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis can cause meningitis, but they are non-motile and does not exhibit temperature-dependent motility.

Giardia lamblia (Option D) a protozoan parasite that causes giardiasis (diarrheal disease), not meningitis..

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves, and a blood culture was performed. The organism in the culture showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus sanguis

Explanation:

The patients presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis

Alpha Hemolytic Streptococcus:

  • Part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Exhibits alpha-hemolysis on blood agar, leading to a partial or greenish discoloration around colonies.
  • Includes multiple species such as S. mitis, S. mutans, S. sanguinis (leads to SABE), and S. salivarius.

Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the symptoms experienced by a 70-year-old woman who was hospitalized for 3 days due to right leg cellulitis and later developed diarrhea, abdominal pain, and an elevated temperature? Her blood reports indicate a hemoglobin level of 12 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm³, and a C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 160 mg/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Clostridium coli

Explanation:

  • The patient has a history of cellulitis, diarrhea and abdominal pain after being discharged from the hospital, are suggestive of Clostridium coli infections.
  • Clostridium coli is a gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacillus.
  • It is a common inhabitant of the human gut, but it can also cause infections in other parts of the body, such as the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and bloodstream.
  • Clostridium coli infections are usually treated with antibiotics.
  • Clostridium coli can cause gastrointestinal infections, and it is also a common cause of diarrhea in people who have been taking antibiotics.

 

Escherichia coli (Option B) (abbreviated as E. coli) are bacteria found in the environment, foods, and intestines of people and animals. Some kinds of E. coli can cause diarrhea, while others cause urinary tract infections, respiratory illness and pneumonia, and other illnesses. Norovirus (Option C) is a very contagious virus that causes vomiting and diarrhea. Norovirus is sometimes called the “stomach flu” or “stomach bug”. The most common symptoms are Diarrhea, Vomiting, Nausea, and Stomach pain.

Rotavirus (Option D) causes diarrhea, early symptoms are a fever and vomiting, followed by three to seven days of watery diarrhea. Rotavirus is present in an infected person's stool two days before symptoms appear and for up to 10 days after symptoms lessen.

questions.text: In a patient with liver cirrhosis, what is the primary cause of mortality when esophageal varices are present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Hypovolemic shock

Explanation:

  • Hypovolemic shock is circulatory failure due to loss of intravascular volume by variceal bleed.
  • This loss of intravascular volume loss will lead to tissue hypoperfusion and tissue hypoxia.
  • In cirrhosis, the blood flow to the liver is cut down, leading to more flow of blood through the veins of the oesophagus, leading to haemorrhage.

Cardiogenic shock (Option B) is characterised by the impaired ability of the heart to pump blood. (especially by the left ventricle)

Obstructive shock (Option C) is a condition wherein blood and oxygen fail to reach the organs. Examples include blood clots, collapsed lungs, tension pneumothorax, and pericardial Tamponade.

Distributive shock (Option D) This leads to poor tissue perfusion due to excessive vasodilation and poor distribution of blood flow to the heart, brain, and kidneys.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg, and he was tachycardic with cold, clammy skin. An ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. Which of the following conditions most likely caused the patient to suffer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypovolemic shock

Explanation:

Hypovolemic shock occurs due to significant blood or fluid loss, leading to reduced blood volume and inadequate tissue perfusion. This patient’s low blood pressure, tachycardia, cold, clammy skin, and metabolic acidosis suggest shock caused by blood loss from the ruptured spleen.

  • Shock is a state of circulatory failure that impairs tissue perfusion and leads to cellular hypoxia. Initially, cellular injury is reversible, but prolonged shock can cause irreversible tissue damage and may be fatal.
  • It can result from various conditions, such as severe haemorrhage, extensive trauma, burns, myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and microbial sepsis. The causes of shock can be categorised into three main types:
    • Cardiogenic shock: (Option A)
      • Caused by low cardiac output due to myocardial pump failure.
      • This may result from intrinsic myocardial damage (e.g., infarction), ventricular arrhythmias, extrinsic compression (e.g., cardiac tamponade), or outflow obstruction (e.g., pulmonary embolism).
    • Hypovolemic shock:
      • Occurs due to low blood volume, often from massive haemorrhage or fluid loss (e.g., severe burns).
      • This leads to reduced cardiac output and impaired tissue perfusion.
    • Septic shock: (Option B)
      • Sepsis: Life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.
      • Septic Shock: A subset of sepsis with profound circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities that increase mortality risk.
      • Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS): A sepsis-like condition triggered by non-microbial insults, such as burns, trauma, or pancreatitis. Both SIRS and septic shock are marked by a massive release of inflammatory mediators, causing arterial vasodilation, vascular leakage, and venous blood pooling, leading to tissue hypoperfusion, cellular hypoxia, and organ dysfunction.
  • Neurogenic Shock (Option D): Occurs following spinal cord injury, leading to acute vasodilation and hypotension.
  • Anaphylactic Shock: Caused by an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, resulting in acute vasodilation, hypotension, and tissue hypoperfusion.

questions.text:
A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over the tonsils, which bleeds on scraping. A sample is taken from the exudate, and a Gram stain is performed. What is the organism associated with the disease?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms and clinical findings are suggestive of diphtheria.
  • Primarily caused by toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Characterized by the hallmark "bull's neck" presentation due to severe neck swelling from infection and inflammatory response to the diphtheria toxin.

 

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Pseudomembrane formation in the throat
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

Staining of Corynebacterium diphtheriae:

 


Albert stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria shows bacilli with metachromatic granules.

Albert Stain

Principle: Albert's stain causes the metachromatic granules of C. diphtheriae to appear bluish-purple upon staining.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheria shows chinese letter/ cuneiform appearance
  • Diphtheroids show regular and palisading appearance with lesser number of granules

 

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

Procedure:

  1. Stain the smear with Albert I stain, then drain and wash it.
  2. Apply Albert II stain to cover the smear, then drain it.

Application:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes, characterized by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli.
  • Albert's, Neisser's, and Ponder's stains help stain these distinctive granules in the bacteria.
  • These granules are also Found in Spirillum, Gardnerella, Yersinia pestis, yeast, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DiGeorge syndrome

Explanation:

  • DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is caused by a deletion on the long arm of chromosome 22. It is characterised by hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, and cardiac abnormalities and occurs in 1 in 4000 births. The condition is often overlooked due to its variable clinical features.

 

These features include:

  • Congenital heart defects
  • Abnormalities of the palate
  • Facial dysmorphism
  • Developmental delay
  • T-cell immunodeficiency
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Key features:
    • Thymic hypoplasia leading to T-cell immunodeficiency
    • Parathyroid hypoplasia causing hypocalcemia
    • Cardiac malformations affecting the outflow tract
    • Facial anomalies (e.g., mild facial dysmorphology)

Diagnosis: The condition is suspected clinically but confirmed by FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridisation) testing. Around 90% of DiGeorge syndrome and 80% of velocardiofacial syndrome cases show the 22q11.2 deletion. This test can also identify deletions in individuals with conotruncal cardiac defects but no other features of the syndrome.

 

Williams Syndrome (Option A) is a genetic disorder caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, not 22q11.2. It is characterised by cardiovascular problems, developmental delays, and distinctive facial features, but it does not involve thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, or hypocalcemia.

Pitt Syndrome (Option B) is a rare genetic condition linked to mutations in the FLNA gene, leading to developmental and cardiac abnormalities. It doesn’t involve the same chromosome 22q11.2 deletion or the associated features of thymic hypoplasia, immunodeficiency, or hypocalcemia seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

Cri-du-chat Syndrome (Option D) is caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. The main features include a distinctive high-pitched cry, intellectual disability, and certain facial features, but it does not include the hallmark features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as thymic hypoplasia, cardiac defects, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Meigs syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dysgerminoma of the ovary

Explanation:

  • Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumour and is not part of Meigs syndrome.

Meigs Syndrome: Meigs syndrome is a condition characterised by a triad of:

  • Ovarian fibroma (fibrothecoma)
  • Ascites
  • Hydrothorax (pleural effusion)

questions.text: What are the primary referral centers in India's healthcare system?

choices.text: Primary health centres and district hospitals
Community health centres and medical colleges
Sub-district hospitals and community health centres

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 50-year-old male who worked in the dye industry and had exposure to aniline dyes, and is now experiencing bladder problems?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Transitional cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months. On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers, as shown below. Investigation showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Buerger’s disease

 

Explanation:

Buerger’s Disease (Thromboangitis Obliterans)

Feature

Details

Definition

Non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory vasculitis affecting small & medium-sized arteries and veins.

Etiology

Strong association with tobacco use (smoking or chewing). Exact cause unknown (likely immune-mediated).

Epidemiology

Young males (20–45 years), most commonly smokers.

More common in Middle East, South Asia.

Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation leads to thrombosis and vascular occlusion.
  • Sparing of proximal arteries (unlike atherosclerosis).
  • Segmental involvement (skip lesions).

Clinical Features
  • Claudication, rest pain (foot, hands).
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon (vasospasm causing colour changes in fingers/toes).
  • Ulcers & gangrene (especially in fingers/toes).
  • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflamed veins).

Diagnosis
  • Clinical diagnosis (no specific lab tests).
  • Doppler & Angiography → Corkscrew collateral vessels (pathognomonic).
  • Exclusion of other causes (diabetes, atherosclerosis, vasculitis).

Management
  1. Complete smoking cessation (most important).
  2. Vasodilators (e.g., calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s).
  3. Antiplatelets & anticoagulants (limited benefit).
  4. Pain management (NSAIDs, opioids if needed).
  5. Amputation (for non-healing ulcers or gangrene).

Prognosis

Poor if smoking continues but stabilises with smoking cessation.

Diabetic ulcers (Option B) Occurs more commonly among patients(both males and females) with diabetes. It is seen more commonly in the foot.

Acute paronychia (Option C) This is the most common infection of the hand. It is often caused by careless nail trimming or picking the skin around the nail fold. The pus is trapped beside the nail.

Raynaud’s phenomenon (Option D) This phenomenon causes the blood vessels in the extremities to narrow, and it restricts the blood flow. This usually affects the fingers and toes.

questions.text: Based on Globocan 2020 data, which cancer type is the most prevalent among males in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Lip and oral cavity

  • According to Globocan 2020, the most common cancer in males in India is lip and oral cavity cancer.

According to the Global Cancer Observatory (GLOBOCAN),

Most common cancer worldwide (Both Genders):

  1. Absolute numbers, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022 (World Wide)- Lung Cancer.
  2. Age-Standardized Rate (World) per 100 000, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022- Breast Cancer.

Most common cancer in India in terms of absolute numbers, incidence:

  1. Lip/Oral Cancer in Males
  2. Breast cancer in females

According to the National Cancer Registry, the most common cause of cancer in

  1. Males in India – Lung cancer.
  2. Females in India - Breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with TB and while testing for resistance, he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and Levofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB)

Explanation:

Classification of TB Patients Based on Drug Testing

Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR) (Option A)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option D)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi drug resistant (MDR) (Option B)

Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR) (Option A)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR) (Option C)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrived at the emergency department following an incident where she was scratched by a stray dog while walking on the streets one hour ago. She has only suffered minor abrasions without any bleeding. What course of treatment should be provided to her?

choices.text: No treatment as she is pregnant now
Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine:

  • The patient falls under Category II according to WHO since there is no bleeding therefore she has to be administered rabies vaccine along with local wound cleaning.
  • Rabies being a lethal disease, there is no contraindication for post exposure prophylaxis.

Management of rabies wound:

Category

Exposure

Management

Class I

(Option B)

Licks and touch on intact skin (skin integrity not broken)
  • Local wound management: soap, running water, iodine tincture for 15-20 min.

Class II
 

Abrasion, laceration (skin integrity broken)
  • Local wound management
  • Immediate Rabies vaccination

Class III
(Option D)

Bleeding, licks on mucosa/ broken skin, deep tissue injury, all wild animal or bat bite
  • Wound management (avoid suturing)
  • Rabies vaccination
  • Rabies immunoglobulin

No treatment as she is pregnant now (Option A): Rabies is a lethal disease and hence has no post exposure prophylaxis contraindication, not even pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the probable medical condition for an 80-year-old male who experienced pain and swelling in the calf muscle on the right side after being immobilized due to a fracture in the right inter-trochanteric region?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Deep vein thrombosis

Explanation:

  • The scenario of a patient being immobilised and exhibiting symptoms such as calf swelling and pain strongly indicate the likelihood of DVT.
  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) occurs when a blood clot forms in a deep vein, typically in the lower leg, thigh, or pelvis.
  • Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and tenderness in the calf or thigh, along with warm and red skin.
  • Virchow's Triad components - endothelial injury, stasis, and hypercoagulable state - increase the risk of DVT.

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option A) The intraosseous blood vessels thrombose, and bone infarcts. Pus lifts the periosteum. To treat osteomyelitis, all dead tissue needs to be removed. If a fracture exists, it needs to be stabilized.

Compartment syndrome (Option C) A compartment syndrome develops at any time during the first 48 hours after the accident or surgery. The patient usually complains of severe pain with some numbness in the foot. The foot may be cold still with pulses.

Arterial claudication (Option D) Claudication is usually a symptom of peripheral artery disease, in which the arteries that supply blood, usually the legs, are narrowed.

questions.text: An intern has to study the relationship between ordering food online and development of obesity using a case-control study. What are the best study groups to be selected?

choices.text: Online food eaters and non-online food eaters

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Obese and non-obese persons:

  • In a case-control study, the cases are those with the condition of interest (in this case, obesity), and the controls are those without the condition (non-obese persons).
  • After selecting these groups, the researcher would look retrospectively to assess the exposure to the risk factor (in this case, ordering food online).
  • This design is ideal for studying the association between a specific exposure and an outcome.

Salient Features of Case-control study

  • Case-control study is an observational, analytical study.
  • Both exposure and outcome have occurred before the start of the study.
  • Control group who do not have the disease and Case group who have contracted the disease.
  • Study precedes backwards from effect to cause, i.e. Outcome is used to determine the cause.

 

Only obese persons, Only online food eaters (Options A and B): do not include a comparison group

Online food eaters and non-online food eaters (Option D): focuses on exposure groups rather than outcome groups, which is not the correct approach for a case-control study.

questions.text: The term demographic bonus is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Decline in dependency ratio

  • Demographic bonus occurs when a country's working-age population (15-64 years) grows larger relative to the dependent population (children under 15 and elderly above 65).
  • This results in a decline in the dependency ratio, meaning fewer dependents for every working individual.
  • It provides an opportunity for economic growth if the working-age population is productively employed.

Dependency ratio is the average number of economically dependent individuals per 100 economically productive individuals in a specific country, territory, or geographic area at a given time.

To calculate the dependency ratio, we use the formula:

  • Total dependency ratio: 48.27%
  • Young age dependency ratio: 38.89%
  • Old dependency ratio: 9.8% (increased due increased life expectancy, initially 8%)

Demographic Gift

Demographic Liability

The demographic gift occurs when the working-age population is high relative to dependents.

The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability.

Represents a potential demographic dividend due to a larger workforce contributing to economic growth.

Represents potential economic challenges due to increased dependency ratios and healthcare costs

Contributors include higher productivity, increased savings, and economic growth

Dependents include retirees, elderly individuals, and those requiring significant healthcare

 

  • Demographic Burden
    • Refers to the increase in the proportion of the dependent population relative to the economically productive population.
    • It signifies the societal challenge of supporting a larger dependent population, which typically occurs due to ageing demographics.
  • Demographic Bonus
    • A phase in a nation's demographic evolution in which the proportion of the dependent population relative to the working-age population declines.
    • This is often associated with economic growth opportunities as more people are in the workforce than dependents.
  • Demographic Window: Refers to a period in a nation's demographic structure when the proportion of the population in the working-age group is at its highest.
  • Demographic Dividend: An increase in economic growth driven by a growing proportion of working-age individuals in the population

Options B, C, and D are unrelated to the concept of the demographic bonus.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ziehl-Neelsen stain

Explanation:

Ziehl Neelsen stain (Acid Fast stain):

  • Principle: Acid fastness is due to the high content and variety of lipids, fatty acids, and higher alcohols in tubercle bacilli.
  • Primary Stain: Carbol Fuschin (red colour)
  • Mordant: Heat
  • Decolorizing Agent: Acid/Acid-alcohol (commonly sulphuric acid). The concentration of sulfuric acid may vary depending on the acid fastness of the structure to be demonstrated.

  • Counterstaining: The smear is counterstained with a contrasting dye such as methylene blue.
  • Result: Acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin (red) colour. Non-acid-fast bacteria take the counterstain colour (blue).

 

COLD ZN Stain (Kinyoun Stain/Gabbet Stain): Modified ZN stain where intermittent heating is not required with increased phenol concentration in carbol fuchsin, used for coccidian parasites.

Gomori Methenamine Silver (Option A)This stain is commonly used for the identification of fungi and pneumocytis jirovecii.

Prussian Blue (Option B) This stain is used to detect iron (hemosiderin) in tissue sections. For example, hemosiderin heart failure cells and ferruginous bodies in asbestosis.

Masson-Fontana Stain (Option D) This stain is utilized to detect melanin in tissues and to stain the pigmented fungi.

questions.text: In a hospital setting, the management seeks to determine the average duration of doctor-patient interactions in order to assess the need for adjusting the number of doctors. This adjustment is aimed at enhancing the quality of care provided. Which management technique would be most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Work sampling

  • Work sampling is a management technique used to measure the proportion of time spent on different tasks or activities in a workplace setting.
  • In the context of a hospital, it can be used to estimate the average duration of doctor-patient interactions by observing a random sample of interactions over time.
  • This data helps in identifying patterns and making informed decisions about resource allocation, such as adjusting the number of doctors to improve the quality of care.

Work Sampling:

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement.
  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities.
  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique.

Health Management Techniques

Qualitative (Based on behavioural sciences)

POCIMon

Quantitative

Personal management

Cost-benefit analysis

Organizational design

Cost-effective analysis

Communication

Cost-accounting

Information system

Decision making

Management by objectives

PPBS - Planning, Programming, and Budgeting System

 

Work sampling

 

Network analysis

 

System analysis

Model (Option A): does not help in the above case.

Decision making (Option B): one should consider the lower level needs and decisions, for example: Differential diagnosis in medical practice.

Personnel management (Option C): includes looking after incentives and promotions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, the fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Incision and drainage

Explanation:

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision. (Option A)
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews of culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics only (Option B) Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for an established abscess.

Breast conservation surgery (Option C) is not required, as it is an infective condition, not malignancy.

Punch biopsy (Option D) Not necessary unless malignancy is suspected (which is unlikely in a lactating mother with classical abscess signs).

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with a malar rash, recurrent oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. She has a relevant past history and does not take any medication. Upon further investigations, thrombocytopenia was seen, and the anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disorder that commonly affects young women and presents with features such as:

  • Malar rash (butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and nose),
  • Recurrent oral ulcers,
  • Joint pain (often non-erosive arthritis),
  • Thrombocytopenia,
  • Positive anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies, which are highly specific for SLE.
    • While scleroderma, Sjögren syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis share overlapping symptoms, the positive anti-Sm antibody is most specific to SLE, confirming the diagnosis.

SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease with the production of many antibodies like antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), and anti-Smith (Sm).

  • These autoantibodies form immune complexes that deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and damage.
  • It is more common in women.

Clinical Manifestations of SLE:

  • Skin: Malar rash (butterfly rash), photosensitivity, discoid lesions, and mucosal ulcers.
  • Joints: Non-erosive arthritis commonly affects the hands, wrists, and knees.
  • Renal: Lupus nephritis ranging from asymptomatic proteinuria to severe kidney failure. The major cause of morbidity and mortality in SLE.
  • Cardiovascular: Pericarditis, myocarditis, increased risk of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.
  • Pulmonary: Pleurisy and pleural effusion, pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung.
  • Neurologic: Neuropsychiatric symptoms ranging from headaches and cognitive dysfunction to seizures and psychosis.
  • Hematologic: Anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The risk of thrombotic events is increased.

Marker/Antibody

Clinical Significance

Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients)

Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)

Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE

Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies

Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus

Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies

Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE

Anti-histone antibodies

Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE

Complements C3 and C4

Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity

questions.text: Examine the provided graphs depicting various occupational groups and their likelihood of developing fever. Identify the group with the greatest probability of experiencing fever.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - White-collar jobs

  • The above image shows a component bar graph(A) and a pie chart(B).
  • The highest chance of developing a fever is around 90%, which is seen among white-collar jobs as evident from the component bar graph.
  • The pie chart shows the different groups and their percentage among the total workers, whereas the component bar graph shows the chance of them developing a fever.

Types of bar diagrams:

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups

 

​​

Compound Bar Diagram

  • There are gaps (discrete data) represented with multiple bars.
  • It is qualitative in the first quarter.
  • It is a Multiple bar diagram/Compound bar diagram.

 

Component Bar Diagram

  • Same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency.
  • It is a frequency of discrete variables.
  • It is known as the Component bar diagram.

 

Histogram

  • It is not a bar diagram.
  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

A pie chart displays the proportions of different categories using slices of a circle.

  • Used to represent variables in percentages and proportions.
  • Represents qualitative variables.
  • Entire pie chart is 100%
  • Maximum divisions: 6 - 7 parts

Fig. Pie chart

Industrial workers (Option A): are 50% prone to developing fever.

Farmers (Option B): are 50%prone to developing fever.

Housewives (Option D): are 20% prone to developing fever.

questions.text: What is the maximum population size observed in relation to reproductive programs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - UNFPA

  • UNFPA is the largest found for population and reproduction related problems.
  • UNFPA is the United Nations sexual and reproductive health agency.
  • Its mission is to deliver a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every childbirth is safe and every young person's potential is fulfilled.

UNFPA: Stands for the United Nations Population Fund. It is an international organization primarily focusing on reproductive health and population issues.

United Nations Fund for Population Activity (UNFPA):

  • Headquarters - New York
  • Established in 1967
  • Addresses population and development issues
  • Develops national capability for the manufacture of contraceptives

The World Bank Group (Option A): is one of the world's largest sources of funding and knowledge for developing countries.

UNESCO (Option C): is the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. It contributes to peace and security by promoting international cooperation in education, sciences, culture, communication and information

UNICEF (Option D): works around the world to strengthen health systems; immunize and treat children for pneumonia, diarrhoea, malaria and other health conditions; help countries combat non-communicable diseases; and support children with mental health conditions, developmental delays and disabilities.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump, which she noticed on a self-breast examination 3 weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. FNAC is characterized by stromal and epithelial elements with no signs of malignancy. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Reassurance and follow-up

Explanation:

In a young woman with a mobile, firm breast lump and FNAC ruling out malignancy, the best approach is reassurance and regular follow-up, as fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

Common ANDI by age group:

  • 15–25 years: Fibroadenoma
  • 25–40 years: Fibroadenosis
  • >40 years: Fibroadenosis, followed by duct ectasia

Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumors arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast"

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring
  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision

Prognosis
  • Benign, do not increase risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas

Mammography (Option A) is not the first-line imaging in young women due to dense breast tissue, making it less sensitive; ultrasound is preferred.

Surgical Excision (Option C) is only indicated if the fibroadenoma is >5 cm, rapidly growing, painful, or causing significant anxiety; otherwise, conservative management is preferred.

Start Tamoxifen (Option D) is not used for fibroadenomas, as they are benign tumors, and Tamoxifen is reserved for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers.

questions.text: In India, which organization is responsible for promoting health awareness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Central health education bureau

  • The Central Health Education Bureau or CHEB is responsible for promoting health awareness in India.
  • They develop efficient methodologies and training tools.
  • Train critical health and community welfare personnel in health education and research approaches.
  • They assist educational institutions for teachers and schools in their efforts to educate students about health.

Central Health Education Bureau or CHEB:

Has 5 divisions which are as follows:

  • Media and editorial division
  • Health promotion and education
  • School health education division
  • Training division
  • Administrative division

Central Bureau of Health Intelligence (CBHI) (Option A): is the health intelligence wing of the Directorate General of Health Services in the Ministry of Health & FW, Government of India.

The Indian Council of Medical Research (Option B): (ICMR), New Delhi, the apex body in India for the formulation, coordination and promotion of biomedical research, is one of the oldest medical research bodies in the world.

National Health Library (Option D): is not responsible for promotion of health awareness in India.

questions.text: The false statement about cystic masses of the neck is:

choices.text: Type 3 branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus
Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph
Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing, and tongue protrusion
Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst

questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Type 3 branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus:

Explanation:

  • A branchial fistula can appear on one side or both sides and likely indicates a persistent second branchial cleft.
  • The opening is typically found in the lower part of the neck near the front edge of the sternocleidomastoid muscle externally and internally; it's situated behind the tonsil on the front aspect of the posterior faucial pillar.
  • In Type III cases, the passage runs between the internal and external carotid arteries, possibly reaching the pharynx's lateral wall or the base of the skull.

Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph (Option B): Cystic hygroma lymphangioma is a birth defect with a large fluid-filled sac around the head and neck. The cyst comprises lymphatic tissues and white blood cells.

Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion (Option C): Thyroglossal duct cysts move upwards on swallowing and notably with tongue protrusion but this may occur with other midline cysts.

Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst (Option D): Branchial cyst is a fluctuant swelling that may transilluminate and is usually soft at its early stages, which makes it difficult to palpate.

questions.text: Which organization is not involved in providing funding for India's national TB program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - UNICEF

  • The World Bank, The Global Fund, and Domestic Budgetary Sources are the main funding sources used to purchase anti-tuberculosis medications, tools like microscopes, and diagnostics like CBNAAT cartridges for this programme.
  • Through funding from DBS and the World Bank, the Central Medical Services Society (CMSS), an independent and autonomous organisation under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, purchases the medicines and other supplies.
  • The Global Drug Facility, which is run and maintained by the United Nations Office for Project Services, uses The Global Fund.

Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) to Control TB

  • Aim- to eliminate TB by 2030.
  • Target- set by WHO
    • To reduce mortality of TB by 90%. (Option B)
    • To reduce incidence of TB by 80%. (Option D)

Global targets under SDG :

  • To reach 90% of all people with TB.
  • To reach 90% of all key populations (Slum dwellers, prisoners, difficult to reach, occupational exposures-silicosis).
  • To achieve 90% treatment.

End TB

  • Launched by WHO in 2015.
  • Frameline- 2015- 2035
  • Aim- Eliminate TB by 2035. (Option A)
  • Target- 95-90-0
    • Reduce mortality of TB by 95%
    • Reduce incidence of TB by 90%
    • Zero out of pocket expenditure - Government should look after the treatment.

Stop TB

  • It was in alignment with Millennium development goals.
  • Target: To reduce mortality & incidence of TB by 50%. (Option C) And Eliminate TB by 2050.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh presents with the following lesions on his teeth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Fluorosis

  • The images given above is that of fluorosis
  • Andhra Pradesh is an endemic zone for the same.
  • Dental fluorosis is also known as mottled enamel and is characterised by hypomineralization of enamel due to drinking of excessive fluoride during the formation of enamel.
  • Happens when the fluoride content in water is more than 1.5 mg/l of drinking water.

Fluorine content in water

Related symptoms

<0.5mg/L

Dental caries

>1.5mg/L

Dental fluorosis

3-6mg/L

Skeletal fluorosis

 

>10mg/L

Crippling fluorosis

In selenosis (Option A): there is mottling as well as loss of teeth.

Burton's lines (Option B): are seen in plumbism along with dental caries.

Lathyrism (Option D): is a neurological disorder due to consumption of Lathyrus sativus and is characterised by paralysis of lower limbs.

questions.text: What are the potential health risks faced by workers in a sugarcane factory?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Bagassosis

  • Bagassosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of moldy sugarcane dust.
  • Sugarcane bagasse is the fibrous residue left after extracting juice from sugarcane, and it can become moldy in certain conditions.
  • Workers in sugarcane factories who handle or process bagasse are at risk of developing bagassosis due to inhalation of mold spores.

Bagassosis

  • Caused by - Inhalation of sugar cane fibers, cardboard industry and paper industry.
  • Infested by a fungus known Thermoactinomyces sacchari.
  • Reported in India by two people- Ganguly and Pal.
  • X-ray findings: Mottling of lung fields.
  • Bagasse control: Keep the moisture content more than 20% and also spray the bagasse with 2% propionic acid.

Anthracosis (Option A): is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of coal dust.

Siderosis (Option B): is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of iron dust or particles.

Byssinosis (Option D): also known as "brown lung disease," is primarily associated with exposure to dust from textile materials such as cotton, flax, or hemp.

questions.text: What is the preferred management of angular dermoid cyst?

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision

Explanation :

  • Angular dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.
  • The formation of an angular dermoid is due to the sequestration of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development, which gives rise to a cyst containing dermal elements like hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands.
  • Angular dermoids are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.
  • They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.
  • Diagnosis and Treatment:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.
    • Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms. Careful dissection is required to ensure that the cyst is fully removed and to avoid recurrence.
    • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

Wait and watch (Option B) This is not recommended for angular dermoids, as they can grow or become infected. Surgical excision is the definitive treatment.

Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin (Option C) A wide excision is unnecessary. Angular dermoids are benign, so simple surgical excision without wide margins is sufficient.

Laser ablation (Option D) is inappropriate for treating angular dermoids. Surgical excision ensures complete removal of the cyst, preventing recurrence.

questions.text: What treatment should be administered to a patient diagnosed with P. Falciparum malaria from a North-Eastern state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Artemether plus lumefantrine

  • P. falciparum malaria in India, especially in regions like the North-Eastern states, is often chloroquine-resistant.
  • The recommended treatment for P. falciparum malaria is a combination therapy with Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) to prevent resistance and ensure effective treatment.
  • Artemether plus lumefantrine is one of the ACT regimens recommended

Treatment of severe/complicated malaria:

Initial parenteral treatment (48 hours)

Follow-up treatment

Quinine

  • Loading dose: 20 mg/kg
  • Maintenance dose : 10 mg/kg TDS

Quinine 10 mg/kg TDS +

  • Doxycycline 3 mg/kg (or)
