  • Clindamycin 10 mg/kg (if pregnant / children < 8 years)

Total treatment duration: 7 days
  • Artesunate: 2.4 mg/kg loading dose, then at 12th and 24th hour followed by once a day.
  • Artemether: Loading dose of 3.2 mg/kg; maintenance dose of 1.6 mg/kg per day.
  • Arteether: 150 mg per day for 3 days.

ACT therapy

  • North-eastern states: Age & weight adjusted ACT-AL for 3 days + primaquine on second day.
  • Other states: ACT-SP (Option B) (sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) for 3 days + primaquine on second day.

Chloroquine (Option C): Is mainly used in treatment of infection by P. vivax and P. ovale with dosage of 25 mg/kg body weight (Mnemonic - VOC i.e. For Vivax and ovale → Chloroquine is used).

Mefloquine (Option D):

  • This is an alternative ACT but is not the first-line recommendation in this scenario.
  • Is effective against chloroquine-resistant forms of P. falciparum.
  • Also used for chemoprophylaxis of malaria.

questions.text: Escherichia coli can be grown best in which of the following media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MacConkey agar

Explanation:

Laboratory Techniques for E.coli Diagnosis:

Microscopy

  • Gram Staining:
    • E. coli appears as Gram-negative rods.
    • Useful for preliminary identification in cases of septicemia and meningitis.

Culture Methods

  • General Media:
    • MacConkey Agar:
      • E. coli typically produces pink colonies due to lactose fermentation.
  • Selective and Differential Media:
    • Eosin Methylene Blue (EMB) Agar:
      • E. coli shows a characteristic green metallic sheen.
    • Sorbitol-MacConkey (SMAC) Agar:
      • Differentiates E. coli O157 (colorless colonies) from other E. coli strains (pink colonies).

E. coli on EMB agar

Sorbitol fermenting and non-fermenting colonies of Escherichia coli on sorbitol MacConkey agar.

Biochemical Tests

IMViC Tests

Test

Result

Indole Production

E. coli is typically indole positive.

Methyl Red (MR) Test

E. coli shows a positive result.

Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test

E. coli is typically negative.

Citrate Utilization

E. coli usually does not utilize citrate (negative result).

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar

Shows fermentation of glucose, lactose, and production of gas.

Urease Test

E. coli is urease negative.

questions.text: In a resource-limited setting, what diagnostic method can be utilized to identify the condition when there is a visible painless hardened genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity, as reported by a truck driver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark field microscopy

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of a painless, indurated genital ulcer with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum

  • It can be seen in a low-resource setting by examining clinical specimens from the ulcer under dark field microscopy. It enables the direct viewing of the spirochetes in the samples, which is especially helpful when an active ulcer is present.
  • Using a dark field microscope, which illuminates the material with tangential or oblique light, the motile spirochetes can be observed as dazzling, silver-white, or golden-yellow corkscrew-like structures on a dark backdrop.

 

Leptospira Culture media and Serological test:

Culture Media:

  • Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium is commonly used for culturing Leptospira species showing Dinger’s ring.

 

  • It is a semi-solid or liquid medium that supports the slow-growing leptospires, often requiring incubation for weeks.
  • Specimen Sources: Blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples are often used, depending on the stage of infection.
  • Other culture media are Korthoff and Fletcher.

Serological tests:

  • Non-Treponemal Tests:
    • VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) and RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin): These tests are used for screening. They measure nonspecific antibodies that may indicate syphilis but can also be positive in other conditions (like pregnancy, lupus, or infections).
  • Treponemal Tests:
    • TP-PA (Treponema pallidum particle agglutination), EIA (Enzyme Immunoassays), and FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption): These tests are more specific to syphilis and confirm the diagnosis. They detect antibodies specific to the syphilis bacterium.

Other Investigations:

  • CSF Analysis
  • Darkfield Microscopy: In the presence of a chancre or other lesions, a sample may be taken to observe the organism directly under a microscope, which can confirm syphilis.

Treatment:

  • Treatment in this stage typically involves a course of antibiotics, most commonly penicillin. Benzathine penicillin G is the recommended treatment. A single intramuscular injection (2.4 million units) is typically sufficient.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergies: Doxycycline (100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days) or tetracycline can be used for those allergic to penicillin, but penicillin is preferred.
  • For pregnant patients allergic to penicillin, desensitization may be considered as it is the only effective proven treatment effective for preventing transmission to the fetus.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment of primary syphilis are vital. If left untreated, the infection can progress to secondary, latent, and tertiary stages.

 

Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) (Option B) is a serological test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It is not used for direct visualization of the organism and requires a laboratory setup for testing.

Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test (Option C) The VDRL test is also used to detect syphilis. It works by detecting antibodies that the body makes in case of Treponema pallidum infection and requires a laboratory setup for the test.

Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test (Option D) A specialized serological test called the TPI test is performed to validate the presence of Treponema pallidum antibodies in the blood and requires a laboratory setup for the test.

PMI004

questions.text: Besides NK cells, what other types of cells are capable of identifying and lysing target cells that have specific antibody-bound membrane surface antigens as part of their effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neutrophils and eosinophils

Explanation:

Antibody-dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC)

  • Neutrophils
  • Macrophages
  • Eosinophils
  • NK cells
  • Mechanism: IgG antibodies bind to target cells via the Fab region, while the Fc region binds to Fc receptors on effector cells (e.g., NK cells), leading to target cell destruction.
  • Target: ADCC targets cells that are too large for phagocytosis, such as parasites, tumor cells, or transplanted tissue.
  • Antibody Types: Primarily mediated by IgG antibodies; in some cases, such as eosinophil-mediated killing of parasites, IgE antibodies are involved.

Basophils are primarily involved in allergic responses and do not play a role in ADCC.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella granulomatis

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of beefy red painless vulval lesion is indicative of Donovanosis or granuloma inguinale

  • Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacteria, is the causative organism for granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis.
  • Granuloma inguinale is a chronic sexually transmitted disease in which painless, beefy-red ulcers develop in the genital and inguinal regions.

 

Klebsiella granulomatis

Granuloma inguinale

Symptoms: Painless, beefy-red genital or anal ulcers, tissue granulation, bleeding from lesions

Microscopy: Donovan bodies are seen, they are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in macrophages and are a diagnostic feature of this condition.

 

Chlamydia Trachomatis (Option A) can causes diseases like trachoma, ophthalmia neonatorum, non-gonococcal urethritis, and lymphogranuloma venereum.

Haemophilus Ducreyi (Option C) causes chancroid, which is painful genital ulcers.

Herpes Simplex Virus 2 (Option D) causes painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, meningitis, and encephalitis.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting, diarrhea, and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wayson’s stain

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of high fever, severe inguinal lymphadenopathy, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension, as well as a history of a flea bite suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis.

Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions
  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production]
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Recombinant R1F1v Vaccine: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis
  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

Neisser Stain (Option A) It is used for staining the volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, spirillum, and Gardnerella.

Albert's Stain (Option C) It is also used for staining the volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, spirillum, and Gardnerella.

McFadyean's Reaction (Option D) It is a reaction characterized by an amorphous purple capsule surrounding blue bacilli (polychrome methylene blue stain)used for the diagnosis of anthrax.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a young girl who presents with continuous dribbling of urine despite voiding normally, as reported by her parents, who mention her never being completely dry since birth?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Ectopic ureter

Explanation:

  • In females, an ectopic ureter opens below the sphincter into the urethra or vagina. It presents as continuous urinary dribbling despite normal voiding.
  • Diagnosis is based on history and confirmed by excretory urography.
  • An intravenous dye, such as indigo carmine, can help visualise the ectopic orifice.

Ureterocele (Option B) Would present with recurrent UTIs, voiding difficulty, and bladder outlet obstruction rather than continuous dribbling.

Congenital megaureter (Option C) Typically presents with hydronephrosis and recurrent UTIs, not continuous dribbling.

Vesicoureteric reflux (Option D) Causes recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis but does not cause continuous dribbling from birth.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease lasting a few days at a time, slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, and a diagnosis of Mollaret’s meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus:

  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis)
    • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)

Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.

 

Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.

Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler’s herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.

Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)

  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection)

​​​​​​​Recurrent herpes labialis

  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers
  • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
  • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
  • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

Measles virus (Option A) can cause subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) but does not cause recurrent meningitis.

Mumps virus (Option B) is a common cause of viral meningitis, but it is typically non-recurrent and occurs after parotitis.

Rubella virus (Option D) is associated with congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Reinfection with which of the following viruses can lead to more severe disease with complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dengue

Explanation:

Dengue virus:

  • Dengue virus (DENV) is the most common arbovirus in India, belonging to the Flaviviridae family.
  • It is an enveloped virus with single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • DENV has four serotypes (DEN-1 to DEN-4), with a fifth serotype (DEN-5) discovered in 2013 in Bangkok.

Vector:

  • Vectors: Aedes aegypti (main) and Aedes albopictus; both bite during the day.

Pathogenesis:

  • Primary Dengue Infection: Occurs upon first infection with any one dengue serotype.
  • Secondary Dengue Infection: Results from infection with a different serotype than the one involved in the primary infection.

The secondary infection is more severe and can lead to Dengue hemorrhagic fever or Dengue shock syndrome.

Antibody Response Against Dengue Virus:

  • Dengue virus infection induces both neutralizing and non-neutralizing antibodies.
  • Neutralizing Antibodies: Protective and produced against the infective serotype (lasting for life) and other serotypes (temporary cross-protection).
  • Protection Duration: Lifelong protection against the infective serotype, while cross-protection to other serotypes diminishes over a few months.
  • Non-Neutralizing Antibodies: Last for life and are heterotypic, produced against other serotypes but not the infective ones. During a secondary dengue infection, antibodies produced from the first serotype can bind to the second serotype but fail to neutralize it. Instead, these antibodies enhance the infection by inhibiting immune responses, preventing B cell activation against the second serotype.
  • Antibody-Dependent Enhancement (ADE): This phenomenon leads to the recruitment of mononuclear cells and cytokine release, contributing to increased severity of secondary dengue infections.

Dengue fever (DF): It is characterized by:

  • Abrupt onset of high fever (also called biphasic fever, break bone fever or saddleback fever)
  • Maculopapular rashes over the chest and upper limbs
  • Severe frontal headache
  • Muscle and joint pains
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Retro-orbital pain
  • Loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting

Rabies (Option B) is a viral infection transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal. It is almost always fatal once the symptoms develop.

Measles (Option C) is a highly contagious viral infection. Although reinfection with measles is possible, it does not typically lead to more severe disease or complications.

Mumps (Option D) is a viral infection that primarily affects the parotid gland and salivary glands, leading to swelling and pain. Reinfection with mumps is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with destruction of bacteria and viruses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lysosomes

Explanation:

Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain digestive enzymes capable of breaking down a variety of substances, including bacteria, viruses, and cellular debris. They play a crucial role in the destruction of pathogens as part of the immune response, especially in phagocytic cells like macrophages and neutrophils.

Peroxisomes (option A): Peroxisomes are involved in the breakdown of fatty acids and detoxification of harmful substances (like hydrogen peroxide), but they do not directly participate in the destruction of bacteria and viruses.

Golgi complex (option C): The Golgi complex is responsible for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids, not for pathogen destruction.

Ribosomes (option D): Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis, not the destruction of pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Taenia solium?

choices.text: Eggs are not infective to man
The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
Correct answer C) The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution:

Explanation:

Taenia solium eggs are heavier and do not float in saturated salt solution during stool examination. Instead, they settle at the bottom, requiring sedimentation techniques for diagnosis.

Eggs are not infective to man (Option A): Taenia solium eggs are infective to humans and cause cysticercosis when ingested. Humans can act as both definitive and intermediate hosts for Taenia solium.

Hooks are absent (Option B) Taenia solium has a scolex (head) with hooks and suckers, which helps in attachment to the intestinal wall. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) lacks hooks.

Intermediate host is cow (Option D): The intermediate host for Taenia solium is the pig (pork tapeworm). Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) has cows as intermediate hosts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL, and thus, she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146 mg/dl, and HbA1c was 7.6%. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Maturity onset diabetes of the young

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Overt diabetes

Explanation:

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is defined as hyperglycemia first recognized during pregnancy that meets the diagnostic threshold of diabetes in non-pregnant adults.

Diagnostic Criteria for Overt Diabetes (ADA Guidelines): The diagnosis can be made in a woman with any of the following:

  • A fasting plasma glucose value ≥126 mg/dl (7.0 mmol/L)
  • 2-h plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l)
  • Random plasma glucose value ≥200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l) in the presence of symptoms
  • HbA1c ≥6.5% (48 mmol/mol)

Maturity onset diabetes of the young (Option A): While MODY can present during pregnancy, it typically has a strong family history and presents at a younger age. The absence of family history details and typical age of presentation make this diagnosis less likely.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (Option C): GDM and overt diabetes differ in severity. GDM is a less severe form of hyperglycemia (Fasting Plasma <92mg/dl and HbA1c ≥5.7-6.4%).

Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (Option D): The case does not talk of pancreatic antibodies, and the significant hyperglycemia early in pregnancy is more consistent with overt type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for lipoma 5 weeks ago and now presents with a scar at the incision site, which is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypertrophic scar

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is a hypertrophic scar, characterised by a raised scar confined to the original wound boundaries, unlike keloids that extend beyond the wound.
  • It is marked by excess collagen, rapid growth, and the presence of myofibroblasts.
  • Hypertrophic scars tend to regress over time and recur less frequently than keloids.

 

Keloid: (Option A)

  • Scar grows beyond the original wound boundaries and doesn’t regress.
  • More common among African Americans.
  • Develops after deep dermal injuries.

 

Exuberant Granulation Tissue: (Option B)

  • Excessive granulation tissue above skin level.
  • Blocks reepithelialisation (also called "proud flesh").
  • Requires cauterisation or surgical excision for healing

Contractures:

  • Abnormal tightening of the wound and surrounding tissues.
  • Common in palms, soles, and chest.
  • Seen in severe burns, it may impair joint movement.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument/procedure?

choices.text: It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks
Can be done on an OP basis
The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml
It created a negative pressure of 600 mmHg

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml

Explanation:

A manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) device is a cheap and non-invasive method well-established for surgical abortion in the first trimester of pregnancy. The manual vacuum aspirator is a 60-mL syringe in which suction of around 600 mm Hg is created manually.

  • It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks. (Option A ruled out)
  • It can be performed on an outpatient basis under local anesthesia. (Option B ruled out)
  • It generates a negative pressure of approximately 600 mmHg manually. (Option D ruled out)

Uses of MVA Syringe

Use

Description

Pregnancy Termination
  • MVA syringes are commonly used for the termination of early pregnancies (up to 12 weeks).
  • The syringe is used to aspirate and remove the contents of the uterus.
  • It is a safe and effective method for induced abortion in appropriate settings.

Uterine Evacuation
  • MVA syringes are utilized for uterine evacuation in cases of incomplete miscarriage.
  • The syringe is used to remove retained products of conception from the uterus.

Endometrial Sampling
  • MVA syringes can be employed for endometrial sampling or biopsy procedures.
  • The syringe is used to collect a small sample of the endometrial tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • It is commonly done to investigate abnormal uterine bleeding or to evaluate fertility issues.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with fatigue for the past year. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings:


	Anemia
	Total leukocyte count (TLC): 150,000/microliter
	Peripheral smear: 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes
	Myeloid to erythroid ratio: 18:1


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)

Explanation:

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) is the most likely diagnosis due to:

  • Massive splenomegaly, which is a hallmark of CML.
  • Marked leukocytosis (TLC of 150,000/microliter) with a predominance of neutrophils and the presence of immature myeloid cells (myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) on the peripheral smear. These are key features of CML.
  • Basophilia (6%) and the myeloid-to-erythroid ratio of 18:1, characteristic of CML, further support this diagnosis.

 

Here is the revised table:

Aspect

Details

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene causes overactive tyrosine kinase activity and is associated with radiation exposure.

Clinical Features
  • Common in adults, presenting with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to a blast crisis with acute leukaemia features.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis
  • FISH to detect BCR-ABL fusion gene product

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., Imatinib)

 

The 3 phases of CML and their characteristics are:

1) Chronic phase:
  • Leukocytosis, < 10% blast cells, basophils <20% and monocytosis < 3%

2) Accelerated phase:
  • 10%-19% blasts, ≥ 20% basophils in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 10^9/L) and splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 10^9/L), unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 10^9/L) unrelated to therapy
  • This phase often leads to the terminal blast crisis within 6-12 months.

3) Blast Crisis:
  • ≥20% blasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • In 50% of patients, the blast crisis occurs abruptly without an accelerated phase.
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs to compensate for CML and leads to significant splenomegaly.
  • Transformation into AML is more predominant than ALL.

 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

 

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

3. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time, currently at 25 weeks gestation, and experiencing pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, along with nausea and vomiting for the past two days? Her blood pressure is 104/72 mm Hg, heart rate is 72 bpm, and she has generalized swelling. A peripheral smear shows hemolysis, and the following lab values are provided:Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3 Platelet count: 62000/mm3 Hematocrit: 26% AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HELLP syndrome

Explanation:

The syndrome of hemolysis with a microangiopathic blood smear, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets, as seen in the given pregnant patient, is known as HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a severe variant of preeclampsia that can occur without significant hypertension.

The clinical manifestations supporting the diagnosis are:

  • Hemolysis evidenced by peripheral smear findings
  • Elevated liver enzymes with AST of 90 IU/L
  • Low platelets at 62,000/mm³
  • Right upper quadrant pain suggesting liver involvement
  • Normal blood pressure does not exclude diagnosis

Criteria for Diagnosis of HELLP Syndrome:

Tenesse Classification:

Haemolysis
  • Abnormal peripheral blood smear (Hemolysis)
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH > 600 IU/L)
  • Elevated bilirubin (≥ 1.2 mg/dL)
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin

Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Elevated (AST & ALT > 70 IU/L)

Low Platelet Count
  • Platelets < 100,000/μL

Another criterion, namely the Mississippi Triple Class System, further classifies HELLP Syndrome based on the platelet counts.

Mississippi Triple Class System

Class I (severe)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets <50 x 109 /L

Class II (moderate)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 50-100 x 109 /L

Class III (mild)
  • AST & ALT > 40 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 100-150 x 109 /L

Hepatitis B (Option B): While hepatitis B can cause elevated liver enzymes during pregnancy, it does not explain the thrombocytopenia or hemolysis. Additionally, hepatitis typically presents with jaundice and would not cause such levels of platelet reduction.

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (Option C): AFL can be differentiated from HELLP syndrome by the presence of leucocytosis, hypoglycemia, more pronounced hyperbilirubinemia, an initial lack of hemolysis, and thrombocytopenia (100 G/l), lower antithrombin levels (65%) and prolonged prothrombin times. Since these features are not present, AFL can be ruled out.

Obstetric cholestasis (Option D): The diagnosis of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) presents primarily with pruritus and elevated bile acids, without thrombocytopenia or hemolysis.

Condition

HELLP Syndrome

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP)

Main Characteristics

Hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells), Elevated liver enzymes, Low Platelet count

Buildup of fat in the liver, liver dysfunction

Impaired bile flow, elevated bile acids, itching

Occurrence

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can also occur postpartum

Typically occurs in the third trimester

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can occur earlier

Symptoms

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, edema

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, malaise

Intense itching, especially on palms and soles

Risk to Mother

Can lead to serious complications such as liver rupture, liver failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Can lead to liver failure, coagulopathy, and other complications

Generally uncomfortable but usually does not pose a significant threat to the mother's overall health

Risk to Fetus

Can lead to fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, stillbirth, placental abruption

Can lead to fetal distress, preterm birth, and stillbirth

Increased risk of adverse fetal outcomes, such as preterm birth or stillbirth

Management

Immediate medical attention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Urgent medical intervention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Symptom relief, monitoring of bile acid levels, early delivery may be considered

Complications

Liver rupture, liver failure, DIC, maternal and fetal mortality

Liver failure, coagulopathy, maternal and fetal mortality

Increased risk of preterm birth, fetal distress, stillbirth

questions.text: What is the most accurate test for evaluating the effectiveness of treatment in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RT PCR

Explanation:

RT-PCR is the most sensitive test for monitoring treatment response in chronic myeloid leukemía (CML).

  • It accurately detects and quantifies the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, allowing for precise assessment of treatment response and minimal residual disease (MRD) status in CML patients.
  • Regular monitoring with RT-PCR guides treatment decisions for optimal patient outcomes.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia:

  • It occurs due to the translocation of Philadelphia chromosome t (9:22) (q34.1, q11.2).
  • BCR-ALB1 is a hybrid gene. It is a translocation with respect to the long arm of chromosome no. 9 to the long arm of chromosome no. 22
  • BCR: Breakpoint cluster region
  • ALB1: Abelson leukemia
  • BCR-ALB1 results in the production of novel oncoproteins (Molecular weight: 210 kilodaltons)

 

CBC (Complete Blood Count) (Option A): While CBC indicates changes in blood cell levels, it may not detect MRD or early treatment failure as sensitively as RT-PCR.

Cytogenetic Test (Option B): Although cytogenetic tests reveal chromosomal abnormalities like the Philadelphia chromosome, they may not detect low levels of disease or MRD as effectively as molecular techniques like RT-PCR.

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) (Option D): While FISH detects genetic sequences like the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, it may not quantify residual disease or assess treatment response as accurately as RT-PCR.

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management for this child?

choices.text: Surgical exploration within the next 2 weeks
Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.

questions.solution:
Correct answer D) Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months

Explanation:

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Causes and Associated Conditions
  • Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent.
  • Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes.
  • Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent.

Complications

(SATHI Mnemonic):

  • S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated.
  • A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional.
  • T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes.
  • H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia.
  • I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions.

Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis.

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration.
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilized to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option D)

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

Surgical exploration within 2 weeks (Option A) is not the first step. Karyotyping is needed before surgery to rule out a disorder of sexual development.

Perform orchidopexy now (Option B): Orchidopexy is performed between 6-12 months, but this case requires karyotyping first to rule out DSD before any surgical decision.

Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months (Option C): Spontaneous descent may occur in unilateral cryptorchidism, but bilateral cases require urgent evaluation due to the risk of DSD.

questions.text: What is the most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kimmelstiel Wilson Nodules

Explanation:

  • Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules (aka Nodular glomerulosclerosis) are a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy.
  • They are ovoid or spherical, PAS-positive nodules found in the mesangial core of glomeruli.
  • They are often accompanied by mesangiolysis and sometimes surrounded by dilated capillary loops.

 

Armanni Ebstein change (Option B) refers to glycogen accumulation in renal tubular epithelial cells, seen in severe or poorly controlled diabetes, but it is not specific to diabetic nephropathy.

Aschoff nodule (Option C) is a histological hallmark of rheumatic fever, typically found in the myocardium.

Anitschkow cell (Option D) is a macrophage with a characteristic caterpillar-like nucleus, seen in rheumatic fever, not diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours, and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sedation and waiting

Explanation:

The clinical presentation indicates prodromal (false) labor rather than active labor, given the lack of cervical change despite prolonged mild contractions.

Sedation and waiting is the appropriate management because:

  1. The patient is not in active labor despite having contractions
  2. The lack of cervical effacement suggests this is prodromal (false/early) labor
  3. Rest and observation is appropriate since:
    • The pregnancy is term
    • The mother and baby are not in distress
    • This is a common situation among first-time mothers
  • When the cervix is 1 cm dilated, it indicates that the body is preparing for labor or is in the early stages of labor. It could be a matter of hours, or it could take several days or even weeks.
  • Preterm labor is the labor that starts before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy. Drugs called tocolytics can be given to pregnant women with symptoms of preterm labor.

Augmentation with oxytocin (Option B): Oxytocin augmentation is inappropriate when the cervix is unfavorable and the patient is not in active labor. Using oxytocin in this situation could lead to increased risk of fetal distress.

Cesarean section (Option C): An emergency cesarean is not indicated in this scenario as there are no signs of fetal compromise or maternal indication.

Amniotomy (Option D): Artificial rupture of membranes is contraindicated when the cervix is unfavorable and the patient is not in active labor. Early amniotomy can increase the risk of infection and cord prolapse without improving labor progress.

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks ago now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Hypertrophic scar

Explanation:

Comparison of Hypertrophic Scar, Keloid, Exuberant Granulation, and Granulation Tissue

Feature

Hypertrophic Scar

Keloid

Exuberant Granulation ("Proud Flesh")

Granulation Tissue

Definition

Excess collagen deposition leading to a raised scar within wound boundaries.

(Option D ruled out )

Excess collagen deposition extending beyond the wound. (Option A ruled out )

Overgrowth of granulation tissue above skin level. (Option B ruled out )

Early vascularized tissue forming during wound healing. (Option C)

Wound Boundaries

Confined to the original wound.

Extends beyond the wound margins.

Protrudes beyond the skin level.

Confined to wound, but not raised.

Onset

Weeks after injury.

Months after injury.

Early post-injury phase.

Forms within days of injury.

Resolution

May regress over time.

Persists and grows continuously.

Requires treatment (cauterization or excision).

Normal component of healing.

Common Locations

Areas of high tension (joints, chest, back).

Earlobes, shoulders, chest, upper arms.

Open wounds, surgical sites.

Any healing wound.

Histology

Collagen organized parallel to skin surface.

Disorganized, excessive collagen deposition.

Excess granulation tissue, rich in capillaries.

Fibroblasts, capillaries, and inflammatory cells.

Treatment

Pressure therapy, steroids, laser therapy (if symptomatic).

Intralesional steroids, cryotherapy, excision (high recurrence).

Silver nitrate cautery, surgical trimming.

No treatment needed (normal part of healing).

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased prolactin secretion

Explanation:

Elevated prolactin levels during lactation lead to suppression of normal menstrual cycling through interference with hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian function. Lactation is a physiological state of hyperprolactinemia with associated amenorrhea.

Lactational Amenorrhea:

  • During breastfeeding, prolactin levels are elevated.
  • High prolactin levels cause:
    • Suppression of GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) release from the hypothalamus
    • Disruption of the pulsatile release pattern of GnRH
    • Reduction in LH (Luteinizing Hormone) pulses from the pituitary
  • Without proper LH pulses:
    • Ovulation doesn't occur
    • Regular menstrual cycles don't resume (amenorrhea)

 

Hormones that favor milk production

Hormones that inhibit milk production
  • Prolactin
  • Insulin
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Growth hormone
  • Thyroxine
  • Estrogen
  • Progesterone

Increased progesterone (Option A): Progesterone levels are low during lactation because ovulation does not occur, and no corpus luteum forms to produce progesterone.

Increased GnRH secretion (Option B): Prolactin inhibits GnRH secretion; thus, GnRH levels are decreased, not increased.

Decreased prolactin secretion (Option C): Decreased prolactin would lead to the resumption of GnRH pulsatility, ovulation, and menstrual cycles, which contradicts the physiology of lactational amenorrhea.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cat scratch disease

Explanation:

  • Stellate granulomas are irregular star-shaped granulomas commonly found in Cat Scratch Disease (CSD), caused by Bartonella henselae.
  • Causative agent: Bartonella henselae (transmitted via cat scratches/bites).
  • Histology: Stellate-shaped granulomas with central necrosis and neutrophilic infiltrate.
  • Symptoms: Painful lymphadenopathy (axillary, cervical) with fever. Resolves spontaneously in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Leprosy (Option B) granulomas contain foamy macrophages (Virchow cells) and Langhans giant cells, not stellate granulomas.

Coccidiomycosis (Option C) forms caseating granulomas, not stellate granulomas.

Histoplasmosis (Option D) forms well-defined granulomas with caseation commonly found in the lungs.

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Graft across species

Explanation:

Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option C ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option D ruled out)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option B ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option A)

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shown below has a false positive Barr body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Klinefelter's syndrome

Explanation:

  • Barr bodies are formed by the inactivation of one X chromosome in individuals with more than one X chromosome. The number of Barr bodies can be calculated as:
    Number of Barr bodies = Number of X chromosomes - 1.
  • Individuals with Klinefelter syndrome have an extra X chromosome (47, XXY karyotype). The presence of two X chromosomes in a male results in the formation of one Barr body, despite the individual being genetically male (XY). This leads to a false positive Barr body, as it is not typically expected in males.

Turner's syndrome (Option B): In Turner’s syndrome, there is only one X chromosome, and no Barr bodies are present.

Down's syndrome (Option C): Down syndrome does not affect the number of X-chromosomes; a female with this syndrome will have one Barr body. This is because the human female has two X chromosomes.

Edward's syndrome (Option D): Edwards syndrome is trisomy of chromosome 18 & does not affect the number of X-chromosomes. It is a disorder of a non-sex chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of differentiation

Explanation:

  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation of cells.
  • It is a characteristic feature of malignant tumours and is associated with the loss of normal tissue organisation and cellular features.
  • Anaplastic cells often exhibit pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and increased mitotic activity.

 

Loss of cohesion between cells (Option A) is a characteristic feature of malignancy.

Change of epithelium type (Option C): Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Benign and fully reversible (Option D): Anaplasia is typically seen in malignant tumours and is not fully reversible.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She has had fibroids for a long time. The radiological investigation is shown below. What is the type of degeneration that occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Calcific degeneration

Explanation:

Pelvic X-ray showing calcified mass and clinical presentation showing symptoms of lower abdominal pain and long-standing fibroids is indicative of calcific degeneration of fibroid.

Uterine leiomyomas, the most frequent solid benign tumor of the female genital tract, occur in 20-40% of pregnant women.

Clinical history:

  • Fibroids often undergo calcification at the end of their life cycle
  • This is especially common after menopause
  • It's a degenerative process where calcium deposits form within the fibroid

Radiological Appearance:

  • The X-ray shows dense, well-defined calcified masses in the pelvic region
  • These appear as bright white, radio-opaque structures

Fatty degeneration (Option A): Long-crossing bundles of bland, smooth muscle cells are admixed with nests of mature fat cells and fibrous tissue in fatty degeneration. It would not appear as dense, radio-opaque masses on X-ray.

Hyaline degeneration (Option B): Hyaline degeneration is characterized by the appearance of homogeneous eosinophilic bands or plaques in the extracellular space, which signifies proteinaceous tissue buildup. Not visible on plain X-ray.

Cystic degeneration (Option D): Would appear as lucent areas rather than dense calcifications.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent condition that leads to the occurrence of heartburn and chest pain in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer D) Esophagitis

Explanation:

Esophagitis, characterized by inflammation of the esophagus, presents symptoms such as chest pain, heartburn, acid regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing.

Treatment typically involves Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs).

Barrett's esophagus (Option A) In the lower part or distal oesophagus, the Squamous mucosa is replaced by columnar mucosa, and there is a long history of heartburn.

Pneumonia (Option B) Pneumonia is an infection that affects one or both lungs. The air sacs/alveoli of the lungs are filled up with fluid or pus.

Myocardial infarction (Option C) is caused by decreased supply of blood flow to a portion of the myocardium. Clinical features include chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck, dyspnea, sweating, heartburn, fatigue, and weakness.

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is not seen 12 hours after an ischemic injury to the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyper-eosinophilia of myocytes

Explanation:

  • Hyper-eosinophilia invasion of myocytes is observed 1-3 days after injury.

Time

Gross Features

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Reversible Injury

0– 1/2 hour

None

None

Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

Irreversible Injury

1/2 –4 hours

None

Usually none; variable waviness of fibres at the border; myocyte vacuolisation

Sarcolemmal disruption;

mitochondrial amorphous densities (Calcium in mitochondria)

4–12 hours
 

Occasional dark mottling

Early coagulative necrosis, oedema, haemorrhage

 

12–24 hours

Dark mottling

Ongoing coagulative necrosis; pyknosis of nuclei; myocyte hypereosinophilia; marginal contraction band necrosis; early neutrophilic infiltrate

 

1–3 days
 

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct

centre

Coagulative necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations; brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils (Acute inflammation)

 

 

3–7 days

Hyperemic border; central

yellow-tan softening

Beginning disintegration of dead myofibers, with dying neutrophils; early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border (Chronic inflammation)

 

7–10 days
 

Maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins

Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins (Repair)

 

10–14 days

Red-gray depressed infarct borders

Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition.

 

2–8 weeks
 

Grey-white scar, progressive from the border toward the core of the infarct

Increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity.

 

>2 months

Scarring complete

Dense collagenous scar

questions.text: What is the causative agent of the sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chlamydia trachomatis

Explanation:

The sago grain appearance of the follicles in conjunctiva is seen in the active stage of trachoma and the organism responsible is Chlamydia trachomatis.

Clinical features of Trachoma:

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis: Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis: due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with left eyelid drooping and experiencing double vision. Upon examination, it was observed that the pupil in the affected eye was dilated. The following eye movement examination was conducted. Which nerve is most likely injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oculomotor

 

Explanation:

Given image is suggestive of Paralytic Strabismus of a patient with down and out left eye with ptosis on primary gaze with diplopia, inability to elevate, adduct completely is suggestive of Oculomotor (Third) nerve palsy.

Features of third nerve palsy

  • Ptosis: Due to paralysis of the LPS (levator palpebrae superioris) muscle
  • The eyeball is deviated down and outwards (due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles).
  • The pupil is fixed and dilated (due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle)
  • Ocular movements are restricted
  • Accommodation is completely lost (due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle)
  • Crossed diplopia is elicited by raising the eyelid.
  • Absence of Both direct and consensual reflexes in the affected eye
  • These compensatory head postures are motor adaptations used to minimise the effects of double vision
    • Horizontal Diplopia: The patient often tilts the head downward
    • Vertical Diplopia: The head is positioned with the chin either raised or lowered
    • Torsional Diplopia: The head is tilted sideways

Optic nerve injury (Option A): Injury to the optic nerve would cause visual disturbances.

Trochlear Nerve injury (Option C): This pertains to a neurological disorder where damage to the fourth cranial nerve, or trochlear nerve, results in vertical diplopia when the patient looks down and inability to DEPRESS the eye completely .

Abducens Nerve injury (Option D): This is a disorder marked by the impairment of the sixth cranial nerve, resulting in lateral gaze palsy.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Oropharyngeal airway

  • The patient's presentations are suggestive of choanal atresia and the next best step in management is establishing an oropharyngeal airway.
  • Choanal atresia is the most common congenital anomaly of the nose characterized by the blockage of the nasal passages due to the complete or partial persistence of the buccopharyngeal membrane or failure of the oronasal membrane to rupture.

Clinical features:

  • Unilateral obstruction:
    • Asymptomatic till the first respiratory infection
    • Unilateral nasal discharge
    • Persistent nasal obstruction
  • Bilateral obstruction:
    • Difficulty in mouth breathing
    • Vigorous attempts to inspire (sucking in of lips)
    • Cyanosis
    • Crying relieves cyanosis
    • Difficulty in feeding
    • Cyanotic while feeding

Management of choanal atresia:

  • Establish an oropharyngeal airway keeping the mouth open or intubate
    • An oropharyngeal airway tube or a feeding nipple with large holes is used
  • Feeding by gavage till the ability to breathe and eat without assistance is gained
  • Bilateral choanal atresia is managed by intubation and sometimes needs tracheotomy
  • Transnasal repair is the treatment of choice and is done for neonates who are otherwise stable

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Explanation:

  • On Chest Xray foreign body in the oesophagus is characterized by -
    • On PA view: Flat surface of the coin
    • On Lateral view: Edge of the coin

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) Tracheal foreign bodies are usually seen in the sagittal orientation on AP view due to the airflow pattern. It presents with cough, stridor, or wheezing rather than pure dysphagia.

Foreign body in lungs (Option C) More common in aspiration, affecting the right main bronchus. Symptoms include sudden onset cough, wheezing, respiratory distress, or asymmetric breath sounds. It may show air trapping on expiratory films.

Foreign body in pleura (Option D) Foreign bodies do not typically enter the pleural space unless there is penetrating trauma. Pleural foreign bodies would cause pneumothorax or hemothorax, not dysphagia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ebstein anomaly

  • Lithium intake by the pregnant mother can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus.

Ebstein's Anomaly:

  • Associated with lithium exposure during pregnancy.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Downward displacement/prolapse of the tricuspid valve.
    • Part of the right ventricular volume becomes part of the right atrium (atrialization of the right ventricle).
  • Consequences:
    • Tricuspid Regurgitation: Prolapsed valve → Blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium.
    • RVOT (Right Ventricular Outflow Tract) Obstruction: Prolapsed valve partly occludes blood flow towards the pulmonary artery → Cyanosis.
  • Features:
    • Cyanosis at birth or during the neonatal period.
    • Pansystolic murmur: Due to tricuspid regurgitation.
    • Quadruple Rhythm: Irregular blood flow in the right heart, RVOT obstruction, and tricuspid regurgitation → Multiple added sounds and ejection clicks.
  • X-Ray Findings:
    • Right atrial enlargement due to regurgitation from the right ventricle and atrialization of the right ventricle.
    • RA forms the right heart border, which displaces laterally and appears on X-ray as a box-shaped heart.
  • ECG: Himalayan P Waves

VACTERL (Option B) is a broad spectrum of congenital anomalies including vertebral anomalies, anorectal anomalies (anal atresia), cardiac anomalies, tracheoesophageal fistula or atresia, renal anomalies, and limb anomalies. Lithium is not a cause of this condition.

Coarctation of the Aorta (Option C): Varying degrees of coarctation occur at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation. It is associated with Kabuki syndrome and Turner syndrome. It is not associated with Lithium exposure.

Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option D) is a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease associated with William’s syndrome and is not associated with lithium exposure.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain with tachycardia and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Bile leak

Explanation:

The given findings are highly suggestive of a bile leak, which is one of the most common early complications of laparoscopic cholecystectomy, occurring when bile escapes from an injured cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct.

Infection (Option A) Would take more time (5–7 days post-op) to develop and is less likely to cause localized fluid collection early.

Surgical Site Pain (Option B) Would not cause fever, tachycardia, or fluid collection on imaging.

Retained Gallstones (Option D) Can cause biliary colic or cholangitis, but does not usually present this early with localized fluid collection; more common after weeks to months.

questions.text: What could be the probable diagnosis for the eye lesion observed in a 21-year-old male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bitot’s spots

Explanation:

The provided image illustrates Bitot spots belonging to the X1B classification of xerophthalmia.

Classification of Xerophthalmia:

 

Stage

Description

XN

Night blindness: Difficulty seeing in low light or at night.

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis: Dryness of the conjunctiva without foamy patches (Bitot spots).

X1B

Bitot spots: Presence of foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva (Option A)

X2

Corneal xerosis: The cornea's dryness makes it appear dull and hazy.

X3A

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (<1/3rd of the cornea)

X3B

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (>1/3rd of the cornea)

XS

Corneal scar: Scarring of the cornea resulting from the healing of ulcers or keratomalacia.

XF

Xerophthalmic fundus: Retinal changes associated with chronic Vitamin A deficiency.
  • The stages from X1A to X2 are reversible.

Pterygium (Option B): Pterygium is a degenerative, subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. May cause visual disturbances.

 

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option C): Type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like bacterial antigens, staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigens. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near the limbus and conjunctival congestion.

Pinguecula (Option D): Pinguecula is a yellowish-white mound near the limbus formed by elastotic degeneration of conjunctival stroma. Only a cosmetic defect, does not cause any vision problems.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Occlusion of the left eye

Explanation:

For treating amblyopia, it is typically recommended to occlude the stronger eye (in this case, the left eye) for 4-6 hours per day.

Treatment of amblyopia:

Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible (younger the child, better the prognosis). Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprise:

Occlusion therapy (Option C): Occlusion of the sound (normal) eye to force use of amblyopic eye is the main stay in the treatment of amblyopia. Following methods are deployed,

  • Full-time occlusion: Up to 2 years, the occlusion should be done in 2:1, i.e. 2 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye; at the age of 3 years, 3:1; at the age of 4 years, 4:1; At the age of 5 years, 5:1; and after the age of 6 years 6:1.
  • Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day, as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion.
  • Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age.
  • Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy.

Other Methods:

  • Penalization: Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses.
  • Computerized Home Vision Therapy: Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
  • Pharmacologic Manipulation
    • Levodopa/Carbidopa: Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
    • Other agents: Citicoline and omega fatty acids
  • Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now.

questions.text: What would be your approach in managing a patient who is a 40-year-old woman with a 5 mm gallbladder polyp detected on abdominal ultrasound, but no gallbladder stones? The patient is overall healthy and shows no symptoms.
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Regular follow-up every 2 months:

Explanation:

Management Approach for Gallbladder Polyps

Polyp Size

Management

<6 mm

Regular follow-up (USG every 6–12 months for 2 years)

6–9 mm

Follow-up every 3–6 months, consider cholecystectomy if growth or risk factors

≥10 mm

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (higher malignancy risk)

Any size + symptoms or high-risk features

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

Polypectomy (Option B) Not feasible since the gallbladder lacks mucosal resection capability like the colon.

Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy (Option C) Only indicated if:

  • Polyp ≥10 mm
  • Rapid growth (>2 mm/year)
  • High-risk features (PSC, age >50, sessile polyp, associated gallstones)

Open Cholecystectomy (Option D) Only needed if there’s suspicion of malignancy or difficult laparoscopic access.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common association with Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Down’s syndrome

  • The most common association with Tetralogy of Fallot is for Down’s syndrome.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is also associated with Alagille syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.
  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.
  • The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Comorbidities associated with Down syndrome:

  • Congenital Heart Disease:
    • 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases)
    • They are: AVSD, Ventricular Septal Defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Patent Ductus Arteriosus, and Tetralogy Of Fallot.
    • Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.
  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.
  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.
  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.
  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.
  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.
  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

Klinefelter syndrome (Option A) involves mitral valve prolapse, ASD, partial atrioventricular canal defect, and patent ductus arteriosus.
Edwards syndrome (Option B) (trisomy 18) involves ventricular septal defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and polyvalvular dysplasia.
In Turner’s syndrome (Option D), the cardiac abnormalities seen are coarctation of the Aorta and bicuspid aortic valve. TOF is not a part of this condition.

questions.text:
Match the given images to their descriptions:


	
		
			
			1. 
			
			
			A. Posterior subcapsular cataract
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			B. Sunflower cataract
			
		
		
			
			3. 
			
			
			C. Morgagnian cataract
			
		
		
			
			4. 
			
			
			D. Snowflake cataract
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1B 2C 3D 4A

Explanation:

Correct match: 1B 2C 3D 4A

1.

B) Sunflower cataract:

  • Deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens.
  • Cause: Wilson's disease

 

2.

C) Morgagnian cataract:

  • Seen in hypermature senile cataract
  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

3.

D) Snowflake cataract:

  • Also known as snowburst cataract
  • Cause: Diabetes mellitus

 

4.

A) Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • Opacity below the capsule in the central part of the posterior cortex.
  • Causes:
    • Complicated cataract
    • Blunt trauma
    • Myotonic dystrophy (Christmas tree cataract)
    • Glactosemia (Oil droplet cataract)
    • Drugs: Steroid, chloroquine, busulfan

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Steatorrhea

Explanation:

Complications of Cholecystectomy

Category

Complication

Description/Features

Early (Intraoperative & Immediate Postoperative)

Bile Duct Injury

Accidental damage to the common bile duct (CBD) leads to bile leakage or strictures (More common in laparoscopic cholecystectomy).

Hemorrhage

Bleeding from the cystic artery or liver bed; managed with hemostasis or blood transfusion if severe.

Bowel Injury

Unintended injury to the duodenum or colon, is rare but serious.

Anesthesia-related Complications

Aspiration, respiratory depression, hypotension, and arrhythmias.

Early Postoperative (0–7 Days)

Infection (Wound/Port-Site Abscess)

Fever, erythema, tenderness at the incision site. More common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients.

Bile Leak (Biloma)

Fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and localized fluid collection on imaging. Often from cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct injury.

Subhepatic Collection (Abscess)

Fever, RUQ pain, and tachycardia; requires percutaneous drainage.

Retained Gallstones

Residual gallstones in the bile duct can cause biliary colic or cholangitis postoperatively.

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) & Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Due to prolonged immobilization, leading to leg swelling or sudden dyspnea (Prevent with early ambulation, anticoagulation).

Late Postoperative (>7 Days – Months/Years)

Steatorrhea (Fatty Stools)

(Option C)

Most common long-term issue due to continuous bile secretion, leading to fat malabsorption.

Post-Cholecystectomy Syndrome (PCS)

Persistent dyspepsia, bloating, diarrhea, or RUQ pain due to bile reflux or remnant stones.

Biliary Strictures

Chronic narrowing of the CBD, leading to jaundice and cholangitis.

Chronic Diarrhea

Related to altered bile acid metabolism, may require bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine).

Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer (Debatable)

Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but evidence is weak.

Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) (Option A) Not a common direct complication of cholecystectomy; it could occur due to severe infection or intraoperative hypotension, but it is rare.

Osteoporosis (Option B) No direct link; chronic fat malabsorption (as in severe bile acid diarrhoea) can lead to vitamin D deficiency, but this is uncommon in routine cholecystectomy cases.

Colorectal Cancer (Option D) Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but it is not a direct or common consequence of cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Vitamin K supplementation is given to neonates to prevent:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn

Vitamin K and Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn

  • Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (VKDB).
  • VKDB has three forms: early, late, and drug-induced.
  • Early VKDB, occurring within the first 1-14 days of life, is typically seen in breastfed infants due to insufficient vitamin K at birth (very low placental transfer), as well as limited intake in the first days and the sterile newborn gut that lacks vitamin K production.
  • Late VKDB usually develops between 2-12 weeks, mostly in breastfed infants, and can be exacerbated by malabsorption conditions like cystic fibrosis or liver disease.
  • The third form results from maternal use of medications such as warfarin that affect vitamin K function.
  • In older children and adults, vitamin K deficiency may arise from fat malabsorption disorders or the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Prophylaxis with vitamin K supplementation is critical to preventing these conditions, especially in infants.

Prevention of Early VKDB:

  • Administer oral or parenteral vitamin K shortly after birth.

Prevention of Late VKDB:

  • A single intramuscular (IM) dose of 1 mg of vitamin K is most effective.
  • Oral vitamin K does not effectively prevent late VKDB.

VKDB due to Maternal Medications:

  • Discontinue maternal medications before delivery, if possible.
  • If discontinuation is not possible, administer vitamin K to the mother.
  • Neonate should receive IM vitamin K immediately after birth.
  • If coagulopathy persists, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may be needed.

High-risk children (e.g., malabsorption):

  • Provide supplemental vitamin K.
  • Monitor prothrombin time (PT) periodically.

Breast milk jaundice (Option A) occurs due to substances in breast milk (FFA and beta glucouronidase) that decrease bilirubin conjugation or glucuronidase action. It usually requires no treatment.
Keratomalacia (Option C) is an eye disorder that involves drying and clouding of the cornea due to vitamin A deficiency.
Scurvy (Option D) is due to vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-year-old woman who is experiencing long-term mucopurulent discharge from her left eye and swelling near the inner corner of the eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dacryocystorhinostomy

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of mucopurulent discharge from her left eye along with presence of a swelling , i.e., mucocele at inner canthus is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis. The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) which helps in lacrimal drainage.

Acute and Chronic Dacryocystitis:

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later. (Option C)
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage. (Option A)
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age (>60y). (Option B)

questions.text: The characteristic appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below, is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse oesophageal spasm

Explanation:

  • The barium swallow image in diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) classically shows a "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance due to uncoordinated, simultaneous esophageal contractions. This condition presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain, often mimicking cardiac conditions.

Radiological Features of Esophageal Conditions

Condition

Barium Swallow Appearance

Key Features

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)

Corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus

Uncoordinated contractions, chest pain, intermittent dysphagia

Esophageal carcinoma

Irregular filling defect, apple-core lesion

Progressive dysphagia, weight loss

Esophageal ulcer

Niche or crater-like defect

Associated with reflux or malignancy

Achalasia cardia

Bird’s beak appearance

Failure of LES relaxation, progressive dysphagia

 

Esophageal carcinoma (Option B): Incorrect because it shows an irregular filling defect or apple-core lesion, not a corkscrew pattern.

Esophageal ulcer (Option C): Incorrect because it presents as a localized crater-like defect in the esophagus, unlike diffuse spasm.

Achalasia cardia (Option D): Incorrect because it shows a bird’s beak appearance due to failure of lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation.

questions.text:
Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Left Atrium

Explanation:

  • In cardiac CT imaging, the left atrium is best visualized posteriorly, near the esophagus. It receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins and is located at the posterior aspect of the heart, superior to the left ventricle.

Cardiac Chambers on CT Imaging

Chamber

Location on CT

Key Features

Right Atrium

Anterior, right side

Receives deoxygenated blood from IVC/SVC

Right Ventricle

Most anterior chamber

Lies close to the sternum, pumps blood to pulmonary artery

Left Atrium

Posterior aspect

Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins

Left Ventricle

Left, inferior

Thickest-walled chamber, pumps blood into aorta

 

Right Atrium (Option A): Incorrect because it is anterior and right-sided, whereas the left atrium is posterior.

Right Ventricle (Option B): Incorrect because it is the most anterior chamber, located near the sternum.

Left Ventricle (Option C): Incorrect because it is larger and more inferior, with thick muscular walls for systemic circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?

choices.text: Infants born to an HbsAg-positive mother

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Classic galactosemia in the infant

  • Classic galactosemia in the infant is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding Contraindications

Maternal Contraindications

Infectious Diseases:

 

Active Tuberculosis

Mothers with active tuberculosis should delay breastfeeding until they have completed at least two weeks of appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of transmission.

Active Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Lesions on the Breast:

Breastfeeding is contraindicated if a mother has active herpetic lesions on her breast to prevent transmission to the infant.

Varicella-Zoster Infection

If the mother has active chickenpox lesions, breastfeeding should be avoided to prevent direct contact between the lesions and the infant. The infant should also receive appropriate immunoglobulin.

Medications and Treatments:

Chemotherapy, Radiopharmaceuticals and Certain Medications
  • Breastfeeding is usually contraindicated during maternal treatment with chemotherapy or radiopharmaceuticals due to the potential harm to the infant.
  • Specific medications, such as some anticoagulants, anti-tuberculosis drugs, and anticonvulsants, may require mothers to avoid breastfeeding.

Substance Use: Alcohol and Smoking

(Option A)

  • While not a strict contraindication, alcohol consumption should be limited to less than 0.5g/kg/day.
  • Cigarette smoking is strongly discouraged.

Maternal Health Conditions:

  • Severe Illness or Surgery
  • Breast Conditions
