  • Maternal issues like mastitis or breast engorgement may complicate breastfeeding and require temporary cessation but are not absolute contraindications.

Fetal Contraindications

Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia

Infants with galactosemia, a condition where they cannot process galactose, should not be breastfed. Instead, they require specialized formulas.

Anatomical Challenges: Oral or Facial Anomalies

Conditions like cleft palate that affect the infant's ability to suckle may necessitate alternative feeding methods.

Prematurity or Low Birth Weight: Support Needs

Premature or low-birth-weight infants may initially require supplemental feeding methods until they can effectively breastfeed.

A mother with HIV infection (Option C) is not an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding and continues normally with the mother on antiretroviral therapy.

Infants born to an HbsAg-positive mother (Option D) can be breastfed as usual once the baby receives the hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth.

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dacryocystorhinostomy

Explanation:

The instrument shown is Bone Punch, composed of a sturdy spring handle and two blades that are joined at a right angle. The upper blade features a sharp cutting edge and a small hole, while the lower blade has a cup-shaped indentation. This tool is utilized in DCR (dacryocystorhinostomy) surgery to expand the bony opening by punching the bone from the edges of the opening.

Types of DCR:

External Dacryocystorhinostomy (External DCR) procedure is performed through an incision near the inner corner of the eye, providing direct access to the lacrimal sac and nasal mucosa. The lacrimal sac is accessed via the Bone punch used to expand the opening (Option D). It is widely regarded as the gold standard due to its high success rate, which exceeds 90%. However, it leaves a visible scar and may result in greater blood loss compared to other methods.

External DCR

 

Endonasal Dacryocystorhinostomy (Endonasal DCR): involves using an endoscope inserted through the nasal cavity to create a drainage opening, thus avoiding any external incision. While it has the advantage of being scarless and typically involves less bleeding, its success rate is slightly lower, ranging between 70-90%.

Endocanalicular Laser Dacryocystorhinostomy (Laser DCR): This method utilizes a laser passed through the tear duct to create a drainage opening. It is minimally invasive and can be performed quickly under local anaesthesia. However, its success rate is lower than external or endonasal DCR, around 70%, and patients often require additional surgery if the initial procedure fails.

Conjunctivodacryocystorhinostomy (CDCR): CDCR is specifically used when both the canaliculi and the nasolacrimal duct are blocked. It is a more specialized procedure compared to standard DCR and is not typically the first choice for isolated nasolacrimal duct obstruction. CDCR involves creating a passage directly from the conjunctival sac to the nasal cavity, often using a Jones tube and is reserved for more complex cases where the canaliculi are also involved.

questions.text: In the case presented, can you identify the imaging technique employed and the specific diagnosis related to the kidneys?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI of Polycystic Kidney Disease

Explanation:

  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a preferred modality for diagnosing Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) due to its superior soft tissue contrast and ability to visualize multiple cysts without ionizing radiation.

Imaging of Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)

Imaging Modality

Findings

Indications

Ultrasound (USG)

Enlarged kidneys, multiple cysts

First-line screening in suspected PKD

CT Scan

Multiple cysts, hemorrhage, infection

Detects complications like rupture or infection

MRI

High-resolution imaging of cysts, no radiation

Preferred for assessing renal function and disease progression

MRI is particularly useful in young patients and those requiring long-term follow-up.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

  • Familial disorder with autosomal dominant inheritance, classified as a ciliopathy.
  • Kidneys are progressively replaced by multiple cysts in the cortex and medulla, with initial preservation of intervening parenchyma.
  • ADPKD is typically diagnosed between ages 30 and 50, when symptoms first appear, thus being named "adult PKD”.
  • Typically presents in adults with hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure.
  • It is associated with other conditions namely intracranial aneurysms, heart valve dysfunctions, colonic diverticula, aortic dissection and cystic lesions in other organs like the liver, spleen and pancreas.

Imaging

Plain Radiograph
  • Enlarged, multilobulated renal outlines with bowel displacement.
  • Multiple calcifications, sometimes with multiple ring appearance.
  • Intravenous urography: "Swiss cheese nephrogram" (due to multiple renal cysts), "Spiderleg pyelogram" (stretched pelvicalyceal system).

Ultrasound
  • Simple cysts: Anechoic with thin walls, posterior acoustic enhancement, and lateral shadowing.
  • Complicated cysts (haemorrhage/infection): Echogenic material within the cyst, possible wall calcification, absence of internal blood flow.
  • CEUS: Demonstrates enhancement

CT
  • Simple cysts: Rounded with near-water attenuation and thin walls.
  • Complications (haemorrhage/infection): Higher attenuation and wall calcification.

CT showing ADPKD

 

MRI
  • T2 MRI- The most sensitive imaging modality
  • Both enlarged kidneys have multiple cysts

MRI showing ADPKD

 

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD):

  • It is a hereditary condition seen in infants.
  • There is dilatation of renal tubules.
  • Several tiny cysts (<2mm) are seen scattered throughout the renal parenchyma giving the kidney a striated appearance.
  • X-ray: Bilateral flank masses due to nephromegaly (enlarged kidneys).
  • USG: Kidneys are predominantly hyperechoic with loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • CT imaging: Shows smooth, enlarged kidneys with a striated pattern of contrast excretion. The striated pattern signifies the collection of contrast in dilated renal tubules.

 

CT of Polycystic Kidney Disease (Option B): Incorrect because MRI provides better cyst delineation and avoids radiation exposure.

MRI of Horseshoe Kidney (Option C): Incorrect because horseshoe kidney is a congenital fusion anomaly and does not present with numerous cysts as seen in PKD.

CT of Horseshoe Kidney (Option D): Incorrect because CT primarily evaluates vascular anomalies and stones, but does not provide the best cyst visualization for PKD.

questions.text: In what situation is popcorn calcification observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pulmonary Hamartoma

Explanation:

  • Popcorn calcification is a characteristic finding on imaging, particularly CT scans, seen in pulmonary hamartomas. These are benign tumors of the lung, typically composed of cartilage, fat, and connective tissue. The calcifications often appear as popcorn-like due to the presence of calcified nodules or cystic components within the tumor.

Pulmonary hamartoma

  • Hamartomas are the most common benign lung tumors,
  • Generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally
  • Radiographic Features:
    • Typically present as a solitary peripheral pulmonary nodule or mass.
    • Size usually ranges from 1 to 4 cm.
    • Well-circumscribed, round or oval shape with smooth or lobulated margins.
    • Internal calcifications, often with a "popcorn" appearance
    • CT scans effectively reveal internal fat, which is pathognomonic for hamartomas.
  • Hamartomas may be multiple, grow slowly, and do not cavitate or invade adjacent structures.

 

Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option A): Incorrect because Hodgkin’s lymphoma may cause mediastinal masses but does not exhibit popcorn calcifications typically. Calcifications in lymphoma are more uniform and fine.

Metastasis (Option C): Incorrect because metastatic lesions usually present as irregular nodules with variable densities. They do not typically show popcorn-like calcifications.

Fungal Ball (Option D): Incorrect because fungal balls can calcify, but these calcifications are not typically of the popcorn type. They are more likely to appear as heterogeneous or mottled calcifications.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency room, with a fever for 2 days, dyspnea, drooling and inspiratory stridor. Lateral x-ray neck findings were as seen below. Which is the most common organism (in India) that causes this condition in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Haemophilus influenza B

  • The given Lateral neck X-ray shows thumb-sign (swollen, rounded epiglottis that resembles a thumb). This sign is highly indicative of epiglottitis, along with symptoms like drooling, high fever, and severe sore throat and the most common organism causing it is Hemophilus influenza B

Acute epiglottitis

Acute Epiglottitis

Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest.

Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Post-vaccine Era:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae (Option B), and Staphylococcus aureus (Option C)
    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination

Clinical Features
  • High fever
  • Sore throat
  • Dyspnea
  • Respiratory obstruction
  • Respiratory distress
  • The child appears toxic
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Labored breathing
  • Drooling
  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway
  • Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)
  • Stridor is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction
  • Cyanosis
  • Coma

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis
  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:
    • Secure the airway with endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, with tracheostomy.
    • Intubation is generally for 2-3 days.
    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.
    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.
  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

RSV (Resoiratory syncytial virus) (Option D) is incorrect as it is not the most common causative agent of epiglottitis.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows a ‘colon cut-off sign’. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

Acute Pancreatitis

Feature

Description

Definition

Acute inflammation of the pancreas due to premature enzyme activation, leads to autodigestion.

Common Causes (Mnemonic: "I GET SMASHED")

Idiopathic, Gallstones (most common), Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion sting, Hyperlipidemia/hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs (thiazides, azathioprine).

Clinical Features

Severe epigastric pain (radiates to back, worsens after food), nausea, vomiting, fever. Severe cases: Cullen’s Sign (periumbilical bruising), Grey Turner’s Sign (flank bruising), Colon Cutoff Sign (gas-filled, distended transverse colon with abrupt cut-off at splenic flexure due to inflammation).(Option B)

Diagnosis (Atlanta Criteria)

≥2 of 3 criteria: (1) Lipase >3x ULN (more specific than amylase), (2) Epigastric pain, (3) Imaging (CT/USG/MRI) evidence. CT scan (best for complications), Ultrasound (detects gallstones).

Severity Classification

Mild: No organ failure, Moderate: <48 hrs organ failure, Severe: >48 hrs organ failure.

Management

IV Fluids (Ringer’s lactate), NPO (Bowel Rest), Pain Control (IV opioids), and Enteral feeding are preferred over TPN. ERCP only if gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis. No routine antibiotics unless infected necrosis.

Complications

Early (<1 week): SIRS, Shock, ARDS, Renal failure, DIC, Hypocalcemia. Late (>1 week): Necrosis (sterile/infected), Pseudocyst, Abscess, Chronic Pancreatitis, Biliary obstruction.

Acute hepatitis (Option A) Symptoms of acute hepatitis are fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, light-coloured stools, joint pain, and jaundice.

Acute colitis (Option C) In colitis, the mucosal lining of the colon becomes acutely or chronically inflamed. Symptoms of patients with colitis include watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, tenesmus, urgency, fever, subjective fatigue, or blood in the stool.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) Intestinal obstructions present with dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels on abdominal x-ray.

questions.text: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after ___ weeks when on a daily corticosteroid therapy regimen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 6

  • Steroid resistance in nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed when there is no remission despite 6 weeks of treatment with daily corticosteroids.
  • Steroid resistance in nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed when there is no remission despite 6 weeks of treatment with prednisolone (2 mg/kg/day).
  • There are two types:
    • Primary (initial) steroid resistance, where there is no response to steroids from the beginning
    • Secondary (late) steroid resistance, which develops during relapse treatment.
  • All steroid-resistant patients should undergo a kidney biopsy.
  • Common findings include:
    • FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis) or
    • MCD (Minimal Change Disease)
    • Rarely, membranous nephropathy may be seen in older children

Genetic Causes of Steroid Resistance:

  • Genetic mutations in genes like NPHS2 (podocin), NPHS1 (nephrin), PLCE1, and others.
  • Next-generation sequencing can help identify these mutations, which are linked to progressive kidney damage and a lower risk of recurrence after kidney transplantation.

Management:

  • The treatment focuses on inducing remission of proteinuria while minimizing medication side effects.
  • Common treatment regimens include:
    • Immunosuppressive agents like cyclosporine or tacrolimus (calcineurin inhibitors)
    • Tapering doses of prednisolone
    • ACE inhibitors like enalapril (0.3-0.6 mg/kg/day) or ramipril (6 mg/m²/day) help reduce proteinuria and control hypertension
    • Partial remission (1-2+ proteinuria) is acceptable, with complete remission being the goal
    • Most patients respond within 3-6 months
    • For patients who cannot use calcineurin inhibitors, a regimen of 6 pulses of IV cyclophosphamide combined with alternate-day prednisolone can be considered
    • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) like losartan and valsartan can be used as alternatives if a patient experiences persistent dry cough with ACE inhibitors
    • HMG-Coenzyme-A Reductase Inhibitors (Statins) may be considered in patients with persistently elevated LDL (low-density lipoprotein) levels to manage hyperlipidemia

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal bowel tumors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Barium enema

Explanation:

  • Barium enema is the investigation of choice for distal bowel tumors as it provides a detailed view of the colon and rectum by instilling barium contrast via the rectum. It helps detect colorectal masses, strictures, and mucosal irregularities, making it ideal for evaluating distal bowel pathology.

Barium Studies in Gastrointestinal Imaging

Investigation

Indication

Best for

Barium Swallow

Oropharyngeal and esophageal disorders

Esophageal stricture, achalasia, tumors

Barium Meal

Upper GI tract evaluation (stomach, duodenum)

Peptic ulcer disease, gastric tumors

Barium Meal Follow-through

Small bowel imaging

Crohn’s disease, malabsorption syndromes

Enteroclysis

Detailed small bowel study

Subtle small bowel lesions

Barium Enema

Colon and rectal pathology

Distal bowel tumors, polyps, IBD

 

Enteroclysis (Option A): Incorrect because it is used for small bowel evaluation, not for distal bowel tumors. It requires nasojejunal intubation and is ideal for conditions like Crohn’s disease or malabsorption syndromes.

Barium Meal (Option B): Incorrect because it mainly assesses the stomach and duodenum and is not used for detecting distal colon tumors.

Barium Meal Follow-through (Option C): Incorrect because it is designed for small bowel evaluation and is used for conditions like submucosal tumors or Crohn’s disease, rather than distal colon tumors.

questions.text: Most common radio-isotope in pet scan :
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) 18F

Explanation:

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans use radioisotopes that emit positrons, which are detected to create high-resolution images of metabolic activity in tissues.

  • Fluorine-18 (¹⁸F) is the most commonly used radioisotope in PET scans.
  • It is incorporated into Fluorodeoxyglucose (¹⁸F-FDG), a glucose analogue that helps in imaging cancer, brain disorders, and cardiac viability.
  • Half-life of ¹⁸F: ~110 minutes → Ideal for clinical imaging.

 

13C (Carbon-13) (Option A) It is not a positron emitter, but it is used in stable isotope metabolic studies rather than PET scans. Commonly used in breath tests (e.g., H. pylori urea breath test).

14C (Carbon-14) (Option B) A beta-emitting isotope used in radioactive labelling, but not PET imaging. Used in carbon dating and metabolic studies.

All of the Above (Option D) is incorrect, as only ¹⁸F is commonly used in PET scanning.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of 18 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomiting twice in the last 4 hours. The child is irritable but drinking fluids. The optimal therapy for this child is—

choices.text: Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Oral rehydration therapy with ORS

The best therapy for this patient is oral rehydration therapy with ORS since the child is drinking fluids.

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT) is based on the physiological principle that glucose-dependent sodium absorption in the gut remains functional during diarrhoea.
  • In this process, glucose and sodium are transported together across the intestinal mucosa, helping to restore sodium and water lost during diarrhoea.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) uses a 1:1 molar ratio of glucose and sodium to optimize fluid and electrolyte replacement.

Constituent

WHO-ORS (Conventional ORS)

Reduced osmolarity ORS

Sodium

90 mmol/L

75 mmol/L

Chloride

80 mmol/L

65 mmol/L

Glucose, anhydrous

111 mmol/L

75 mmol/L

Potassium

20 mmol/L

20 mmol/L

Citrate

10 mmol/L

10 mmol/L

Total osmolarity

311 mmol/L

245 mmol/L

Options A, C & D are incorrect since oral rehydration therapy should be offered first to children with dehydration who are drinking orally. IV fluids are preferred in cases of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Identify the structure C.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epiglottis

Explanation:

  • Structure C in the image represents the epiglottis, a leaf-shaped elastic cartilage that functions as a flap to prevent food and liquid from entering the trachea during swallowing.

Laryngeal Cartilages

Cartilage

Description

Function

Epiglottis

Leaf-shaped, elastic cartilage

Prevents aspiration by covering the glottis during swallowing

Thyroid cartilage

Largest, shield-shaped cartilage

Provides structure and protects the vocal cords

Cricoid cartilage

Ring-shaped, below thyroid cartilage

Maintains airway patency, attachment for muscles

Arytenoid cartilage

Paired, pyramid-shaped

Controls vocal cord movement

 

Thyroid cartilage (Option C): Incorrect because the thyroid cartilage is larger and shield-shaped, forming the laryngeal prominence (Adam’s apple).

Hyoid bone (Option B): Incorrect because the hyoid bone is a U-shaped structure located above the larynx, providing muscle attachment.

Cricoid cartilage (Option D): Incorrect because the cricoid cartilage is a complete ring below the thyroid cartilage, forming the inferior part of the larynx.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of sudden loss of vision in the left eye for the past two hours in a 58-year-old man who experienced it after his retirement party? The fundoscopic examination reveals a similar image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CRAO

Explanation:

The given image shows a cherry-red spot. The orange reflex from the intact choroid stands out at the thin foveola, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina, giving rise to a ‘cherry-red spot’ appearance. Sudden loss of vision and cherry red spots are characteristic of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO).

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk Factors
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Age
  • Hypertension/Cardiac Diseases
  • Thrombophilic Disorders
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Oral Contraceptive Pills

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss.
  • Painful only in GCA: May present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple.

 

Clinical Signs:

  • Severely reduced Visual Acuity (VA), often to counting fingers or worse.
  • Profound and sometimes total Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also called an amaurotic pupil.

Examination Findings

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole.
  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation.
  • Cattle Truck Appearance: Segmentation of the blood column in retinal veins.
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia (chronic cases).

Investigations

Fluorescein Angiography (FFA):

  • Delayed arterial filling.
  • Masking of background fluorescence due to edematous retina.
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion of a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision.

Other Diagnostic Tests:

  • Retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery.
  • Cranial MRI or CT.
  • Carotid duplex scanning.
  • Echocardiography.

Management
  • Smoking cessation
  • Ocular massage
  • IOP control agents: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotics: Mannitol
  • Carbogen (95% O2 + 5% CO2) inhalation
  • Nd-YAG laser embolectomy

questions.text: The inner layer of the fallopian tube is covered by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ciliated columnar epithelium

Explanation:

  • The inner lining of the fallopian tube (also called the mucosa) is composed of ciliated columnar epithelium, which helps in the transport of the ovum toward the uterus through rhythmic ciliary movements.

Histology of the Fallopian Tube

Layer

Structure

Function

Mucosa

Ciliated columnar epithelium with secretory (peg) cells

Helps in ovum transport and secretion of nutrients

Muscularis

Inner circular and outer longitudinal smooth muscle layers

Peristalsis aids in ovum movement

Serosa

Outer peritoneal covering

Provides structural integrity

 

Simple columnar epithelium (Option A): Incorrect because while the fallopian tube has columnar cells, they are primarily ciliated, aiding ovum movement.

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (Option B): Incorrect because this type is typically found in the respiratory tract, not the fallopian tube.

Cuboidal epithelium with microvilli (Option D): Incorrect because cuboidal epithelium with microvilli is characteristic of renal tubules, not the fallopian tube.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uric Acid Stones

Explanation:

Radiopaque stones:

  • Calcium Oxalate Stones (Option A ruled out)
  • Calcium Phosphate Stones
  • Struvite Stones
  • Cystine stones are also mildly radiopaque (Option C ruled out)

Radiolucent stones include:

  • Uric acid stones (most common) (Option B)
  • Xanthine stones (rarely seen, mainly in patients with xanthinuria) (Option D ruled out)

Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones); Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell-shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

​

​​​

​​

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis.

​

​​

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

​​

​​ ​​

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine.
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine.

​

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thoracolumbar fascia?

choices.text: In the lumbar region, it is in 4 layers
In the thoracic region, it is attached medially to the vertebrae
The anterior, posterior and middle join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) In the lumbar region, it is in 4 layers

Explanation:

  • The thoracolumbar fascia (TLF) is composed of three layers (anterior, middle, and posterior) in the lumbar region, not four. It provides attachment for various muscles and encloses the intrinsic back muscles.

Thoracolumbar Fascia

Region

Layers

Attachments

Function

Thoracic

Single layer

Medially to vertebrae, laterally to ribs

Covers intrinsic back muscles

Lumbar

Three layers (anterior, middle, posterior)

Encloses quadratus lumborum and erector spinae

Supports lumbar spine, transmits forces

 

They contain nociceptive nerve endings (Option A): Correct because thoracolumbar fascia has sensory nerve endings, including nociceptors, which are involved in pain perception.

In the thoracic region, it is attached medially to the vertebrae (Option C): Correct as the fascia in the thoracic region attaches medially to the spinous processes and laterally to the ribs.

The anterior, posterior, and middle join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis (Option D): Correct as the three layers fuse laterally to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis.

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trachealis muscle

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is located posteriorly in the trachea, bridging the open ends of the C-shaped tracheal cartilage rings. This is the trachealis muscle, a smooth muscle that allows flexibility during swallowing and coughing.

Tracheal Structure

Structure

Location

Function

Tracheal cartilage

C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings

Keeps the airway open

Trachealis muscle

Posterior, between cartilage ends

Regulates tracheal diameter, aids in forceful expiration

Esophageal submucosal gland

In the esophagus (posterior to trachea)

Produces mucus for lubrication

Perichondrium

Surrounds cartilage

Provides nutrition and support

 

Tracheal cartilage (Option B): Incorrect because the marked structure is soft muscle, whereas cartilage forms the rigid anterior C-shaped rings.

Esophageal submucosal gland (Option C): Incorrect because the structure is within the trachea, not the esophagus.

Perichondrium (Option D): Incorrect because the perichondrium is the fibrous layer covering the tracheal cartilage, not the posterior muscle.

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-Aortic, 2-Pulmonary, 3-Tricuspid, 4-Mitral

Explanation:

The auscultatory areas of the heart correspond to the locations where the heart valves' sounds are best heard:

  1. Aortic area- Right 2nd intercostal space (near the sternum).
  2. Pulmonary area- Left 2nd intercostal space (near the sternum).
  3. Tricuspid area- Left lower sternal border (around 4th intercostal space).
  4. Mitral area (Apex beat)- 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line.

Auscultation of Heart Sounds

Valve

Auscultation Site

Location

Aortic valve

Right 2nd ICS, parasternal

Best for aortic stenosis murmur

Pulmonary valve

Left 2nd ICS, parasternal

Best for pulmonary stenosis murmur

Tricuspid valve

Left 4th ICS, parasternal

Best for tricuspid regurgitation murmur

Mitral valve

Left 5th ICS, midclavicular line (apex beat)

Best for mitral regurgitation/stenosis murmur

questions.text: The probable cause for a patient with a corneal scar having a visual acuity of 6/36, which improves to 6/18 with a pinhole, is most likely due to...
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Irregular astigmatism

Explanation:

Improvement in visual acuity with a pinhole is suggestive of a refractive error. Among the given options, Irregular astigmatism is the only refractive error. The pinhole test reduces the amount of light scattering in the eye and sharpens vision by narrowing the beam of light entering the pupil.

Pinhole and Stenopeic slit tests:

 

Pinhole Test

Stenopeic Slit Test

Mechanism

Uses a small opaque disc with holes to reduce retinal blur and improve visual acuity in refractive errors up to 4D.

Uses a narrow slit to reduce peripheral aberrations and enhance depth of focus.

 

Clinical Applications
  • Determines if reduced vision is due to refractive errors; vision improvement suggests a refractive issue. (Option C)
  • Quick assessment of visual acuity, often in under-resourced settings.
  • WHO recommended blindness surveys.
  • To assess astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism (as it allows for a more detailed analysis of the patient's visual field by focusing light along a single axis) or complex visual issues.
  • A stenopeic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to help identify the best location for an optical iridectomy.

Limitations
  • Can underestimate post-refractive visual acuity.
  • Reduces light reaching the retina, potentially causing diffraction blur.
  • Limited mainly to complex refractive issues.

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown below in the x-ray radiograph of a neonate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

The X-ray shows bowel loops in the chest which point to congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect where the diaphragm fails to form properly, allowing abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and disrupt normal lung development.

  • Mild cases typically involve smaller-than-normal lungs at birth, with surgical repair of the diaphragm generally leading to favorable outcomes.
  • Severe cases often result in significant lung hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, and may require extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) shortly after birth.
  • The survival rate for severely affected infants is low, and survivors often experience long-term respiratory, feeding, and developmental challenges.

X-ray Findings: On a chest X-ray of a baby with CDH, the following findings may be observed:

  • Displacement of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity, such as the stomach, intestines, or liver.
  • Decreased lung volume on the side of the hernia, with possible mediastinal shift to the opposite side.
  • Hypoplastic lungs that appear smaller than normal on the affected side.
  • Bowel loops or gas-filled structures within the chest, which can often be seen on the X-ray depending on the severity of the hernia.

 

Pneumomediastinum (Option A) presents with extraluminal air within the mediastinum.

Cystic fibrosis (Option B) presents with radiological features like hyperinflation, nonspecific peribronchial thickening, signs of bronchiectasis, nodular densities, patchy atelectasis, prominent hilar lymph nodes, etc.

Bronchiolitis (Option D) has features like consolidation, peribronchial thickening, prominent bronchovascular markings, atelectasis, etc.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is the Whitaker test recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Hydronephrosis

Explanation:

Whitaker test

Feature

Details

Definition

A urodynamic test that measures the pressure gradient between the renal pelvis and bladder to assess upper urinary tract obstruction.

Indications

Equivocal cases of upper urinary tract obstruction, PUJ obstruction, post-pyeloplasty evaluation, distinguishing true obstruction from hydronephrosis.

Procedure

1. Percutaneous nephrostomy placed in the renal pelvis.

2. Bladder catheter inserted for pressure measurement.

3. Fluid infusion into renal pelvis at 10 ml/min.

4. Pressure difference between renal pelvis & bladder recorded.

Interpretation

<15 cm H₂O → No obstruction.

15–22 cm H₂O → Indeterminate (needs further evaluation).

>22 cm H₂O → Significant obstruction present.

Advantages

Helps differentiate true obstruction vs. non-obstructive dilation.

Useful in post-surgical cases.

Limitations

Invasive (rarely used due to modern imaging).

Replaced by diuretic renal scan (DTPA/EC scan) & MR Urography.

Posterior urethral valve (Option B) PUV is a lower urinary tract obstruction (at the urethra), and the Whitaker test assesses upper tract obstruction. Best Test: Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG).

Urethral atresia Congenital absence of urethral patency (Option C) is usually diagnosed prenatally or at birth. Whitaker test is not needed, as the condition is identified early with fetal ultrasound.

Urethral stricture (Option D) Affects the lower urinary tract, while the Whitaker test evaluates upper urinary tract obstruction. Best Test: Retrograde Urethrogram (RUG) or Uroflowmetry.

questions.text: Which type of collagen is present in cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 collagen

Explanation:

  • Cartilage is primarily composed of Type 2 collagen, which provides tensile strength and elasticity while resisting compressive forces. It is the main structural protein in hyaline and elastic cartilage.

Types of Collagen and Their Locations

Collagen Type

Location

Function

Type I

Bone, skin, tendons, ligaments, cornea

Provides tensile strength

Type II

Cartilage (hyaline, elastic, fibrocartilage), vitreous humor

Provides resistance to pressure

Type III

Reticular fibers (skin, blood vessels, fetal tissue)

Provides structural support

Type IV

Basement membrane

Forms structural network in BM

 

Type 1 collagen (Option A): Incorrect because it is found in bone, tendons, and skin, not cartilage.

Type 3 collagen (Option C): Incorrect because it is found in reticular fibers of blood vessels and skin, not cartilage.

Type 4 collagen (Option D): Incorrect because it is a non-fibrillar collagen found in basement membranes, not cartilage.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitelline Fistula

Explanation:

  • A vitelline fistula occurs due to the failure of the vitelline duct (omphalomesenteric duct) to obliterate, leading to meconium discharge from the umbilicus. It connects the midgut to the yolk sac during fetal development, and its persistence results in fecal or intestinal content drainage from the umbilicus.

Embryological Remnants of Umbilical Structures

Structure

Embryological Origin

Failure of Obliteration Leads to

Clinical Presentation

Vitelline Duct

Connects midgut to yolk sac

Vitelline fistula

Meconium discharge from the umbilicus

Urachus

Remnant of allantois (connects bladder to umbilicus)

Patent urachus

Urine discharge from umbilicus

Allantois

Contributes to bladder development

Urachal cyst, urachal sinus

Cystic swelling or umbilical urine leakage

Mesonephric Duct

Wolffian duct (forms male reproductive structures)

No relation to umbilical anomalies

Affects male genital development

 

Mesonephric duct (Option A): Incorrect because it forms the male reproductive system (vas deferens, epididymis, seminal vesicles) and does not contribute to umbilical structures.

Allantois (Option B): Incorrect because it contributes to bladder development, and its failure results in urachal anomalies (urine leakage, not meconium discharge).

Urachus (Option C): Incorrect because a patent urachus leads to urinary discharge from the umbilicus, not meconium.

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defects shown in the image below?

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube

Explanation:

  • The left image shows anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect (NTD) caused by failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryogenesis (by day 25 of gestation). This leads to absence of the brain, skull, and scalp, with exposed brain tissue. The right image suggests difficulty in feeding, which is often associated with cranial NTDs.

Neural Tube Defects (NTDs) and Neuropore Closure Defects

Neuropore

Failure of Closure Leads to

Clinical Features

Anterior Neuropore

Anencephaly

Absence of brain, skull, and scalp; open cranial vault; polyhydramnios (due to absent swallowing reflex)

Posterior Neuropore

Spina bifida (Occulta, Meningocele, Myelomeningocele)

Defects in vertebral arch, meninges, or spinal cord; may present with tuft of hair, sac-like protrusion, or neurological deficits

Complete Neural Tube

Craniorachischisis

Entire brain and spinal cord remain open, leading to lethal defects

Caudal Neuropore

Spina bifida occulta

Mildest form of spina bifida, often asymptomatic, with a tuft of hair over the lumbar region

 

Failure in closure of posterior neuropore (Option B): Incorrect because it causes spina bifida, affecting the spinal cord and vertebral column, not the brain.

Failure in closure of the complete neural tube (Option C): Incorrect because it results in craniorachischisis, a lethal defect where both the brain and spinal cord remain open.

Failure in closure of caudal neuropore (Option D): Incorrect because it leads to spina bifida occulta, a mild defect limited to the lower spine, not affecting brain development.

questions.text: A child presents to your outpatient department with the findings shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor

  • The image given here is of a child with Kwashiorkar.
  • Some characteristic features are pitting oedema, thin and brittle hair, muscle wasting, and hyperpigmentation of the skin among other signs.

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option C) is characterized by massive proteinuria, hyperlipidemia, and hypoalbuminemia. This does cause oedema, poor growth and nutrition but the oedema is often present at birth. The given image shows a child suffering from marasmus.

The nephritic syndrome (Option D) is a clinical syndrome presenting as hematuria, hypertension, oliguria, and oedema. The given image shows a child suffering from marasmus.

questions.text: The following image is of the most common cause of stridor in children. Identify it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Laryngomalacia

  • The given image is a laryngoscopic view showing floppy tissues above the vocal cords and the inward curving of the epiglottis (omega sign) which points to the most common cause of stridor in children, laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia

Definition
  • M/c congenital laryngeal anomaly in children; characterized by floppy tissues above the vocal cords that collapse during inspiration, causing stridor.
  • Accounts for 45% to 75% of stridor cases in infants.

Onset

Appear within the first 2 weeks of life and can worsen for up to six months, with gradual improvement often occurring thereafter.

Factors deciding severity and clinical course
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease
  • Neurological conditions

Investigations
  • Diagnosis is made mainly by clinical symptoms.
  • Outpatient flexible laryngoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis but is not suitable for a baby as well as when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Laryngoscopy sows the omega sign: The inward curling of the epiglottis to become omega-shaped.
  • Airway films and chest radiographs are done when the work of breathing is moderate to severe.
  • A contrast swallow study or Flexible endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) is considered when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Complete bronchoscopy is done for those with moderate to severe obstruction.

Treatment
  • Expectant observation for most infants as the spontaneous resolution of symptoms as the child grows is seen.
  • Laryngoesophageal reflux and GERD are treated with proton pump inhibitors or histamine receptor antagonists, considering the possible iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Supraglottoplasty is done in case of severe disease that causes progressive respiratory distress, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or cor pulmonale.
  • Earlier intervention is needed in children with cardiac disease, neurologic disease, pulmonary disorders, or craniofacial anomalies.

Laryngeal papilloma (Option B) is an overgrowth of the epithelium caused by HPV and not by floppy tissues above the vocal cords as seen in the given image.

Chronic epiglottitis (Option C) is diagnosed clinically and laryngoscopy is not usually done. It is an inflammatory condition and may cause stridor but it is not the most common cause and the given image is not of epiglottitis.

Laryngocoele (Option D) is an abnormal dilation of the saccule of the larynx and is not the most common cause of stridor in children.

questions.text: In an infant, which of the following milestones is achieved the earliest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Ulnar palmar grasp

  • Ulnar palmar grasp is the first grasp and first step toward a baby's grip as this happens in the 4th month.

Age

Fine Motor Domain Milestones

-

Sits in tripod fashion (sitting with own support)

Unidextrous reach; transfers objects

Monosyllables (ba, da, pa), ah-goo sounds

Recognizes strangers, stranger anxiety

8 months

-

-

-

Immature pincer grasp (Option A); probes with forefinger

Bisyllables (mama, baba, dada)

Pincer grasp mature (Option B)

1-2 words with meaning

Jargon

Asks questions; knows full name and gender

4 years

Copies cross; bridge with blocks
