Plays cooperatively in a group; goes to the toilet alone

5 years

Skips

Copies triangle; gate with blocks

Asks the meaning of words

Helps in household tasks, dresses, and undresses

Radial palmar grasp (Option C) (8 to 10 months) is a radial digital grasp typically developed in which an object is held between the fingers and opposed thumb. The fingers are now strong and coordinated enough to hold an object without exterior stabilization from the palm

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to the presence of a sac-like protrusion on the lower back. The protrusion is covered by a thin membrane and contains spinal cord tissue and nerves. The infant's lower limbs exhibit weakness and impaired sensation. The mother reports inadequate prenatal folic acid intake during pregnancy. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Spina bifida

  • Spina bifida is a neural tube defect (NTD) caused by failure of the neural tube to close properly during embryonic development. This condition is strongly associated with maternal folic acid deficiency.

Types of Neural tube defects:

Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

Cleft Lip and Palate (Option A):

  • Caused by failure of fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes.
  • Presents as facial deformities, not a spinal defect.

Down Syndrome (Option B):

  • Due to trisomy 21, characterized by:
    • Facial dysmorphism (flat facial profile, upslanting palpebral fissures).
    • Congenital heart defects (e.g., AV septal defect).
    • Intellectual disability.
  • No neural tube defects or spinal abnormalities.

Gastroschisis (Option C):

  • Congenital abdominal wall defect → intestines protrude without a membrane.
  • No neural involvement.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Genioglossus

Explanation:

  • The Genioglossus muscle is fan-shaped and extends from the mandible to the tongue.
  • The direction of fibers in the image indicates a broad origin from the mandible and insertion into the tongue.
  • Function: It protrudes the tongue (helps in sticking out the tongue).

Extrinsic Muscles of the Tongue

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Function

Innervation

Genioglossus

Genial tubercle of mandible

Entire tongue

Protrudes tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Hyoglossus

Hyoid bone

Side of the tongue

Depresses and retracts tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Styloglossus

Styloid process of temporal bone

Side of tongue

Retracts and elevates tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Palatoglossus

Soft palate

Side of tongue

Elevates posterior tongue

Vagus nerve (CN X)

 

Hyoglossus (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the hyoid bone and functions in tongue depression.

Styloglossus (Option C): Incorrect because it originates from the styloid process and functions in tongue retraction.

Palatoglossus (Option D): Incorrect because it arises from the soft palate and functions in elevating the tongue.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The image shows "claw hand deformity", which is characteristic of ulnar nerve injury.
  • The deformity results from paralysis of the lumbricals (which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers).
  • The 4th and 5th fingers are hyperextended at the MCP joints and flexed at the IP joints, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • Common causes in leprosy: Ulnar nerve involvement due to nerve infiltration and fibrosis, leading to motor impairment.

Ulnar Nerve Palsy and Claw Hand

Feature

Ulnar Nerve Palsy (Claw Hand)

Affected Muscles

Lumbricals (3rd & 4th), Interossei, Hypothenar muscles

Deficit Seen

MCP hyperextension, IP flexion (mainly in 4th & 5th fingers)

Common Causes

Leprosy, trauma at the elbow (cubital tunnel) or wrist (Guyon's canal)

Tests for Ulnar Nerve

Froment’s sign (weak adductor pollicis)

Treatment

Physiotherapy, nerve grafting, claw correction surgery

 

Radial nerve (Option B): Incorrect because its injury causes wrist drop, not claw hand.

Median nerve (Option C): Incorrect because it causes ape hand deformity (loss of thumb opposition).

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option D): Incorrect because it affects finger extension, leading to finger drop, not claw hand.

questions.text: A male patient, aged 18, seeks medical attention due to an eye injury sustained while climbing a tree five days ago. The patient reports experiencing pain, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and redness in the affected eye for the past two days. Upon performing a slit-lamp examination, a lesion is observed as depicted below. Which of the following characteristics is associated with this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Satellite lesion

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of pain, redness, photophobia with presence of thick hypopyon following trauma with vegetative matter is suggestive of Fungal Keratitis. Satellite lesions are characteristic of Fungal keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis:

Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Reverse hypopyon (Option A): Collection of silicon oil in the anterior chamber is reverse hypopyon, usually seen as a complication of Vitreoretinal surgeries.

Dendritic ulcer (Option B): This is not dendritic ulcer as dendritic ulcer is a feature of epithelial keratitis and not fungal corneal ulcer.

Ring abscess (Option C): Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis.

OP136

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly labeled here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subscapular artery

Explanation:

  • The subscapular artery is the largest branch of the axillary artery and arises from its third part.
  • It soon divides into the circumflex scapular artery and thoracodorsal artery.
  • In the given image, the structure labeled as the subscapular artery appears to be incorrectly marked, likely representing another artery.

Branches of the Axillary Artery

Part of Axillary Artery

Branches

First Part (proximal to pectoralis minor)

Superior thoracic artery

Second Part (behind pectoralis minor)

Thoracoacromial artery, Lateral thoracic artery

Third Part (distal to pectoralis minor)

Subscapular artery, Anterior circumflex humeral artery, Posterior circumflex humeral artery

 

Superior thoracic artery (Option A): Correctly labeled.

Thoracoacromial artery (Option B): Correctly labeled.

Posterior circumflex artery (Option D): Correctly labeled

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of chop injury to the right hand is undergoing surgical repairs . It is observed that the patient is unable to completely fold the right ring finger, while making the fist , which structure injury results in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flexor digitorum profundus

Explanation:

  • The flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) is responsible for flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the medial four fingers.
  • If the FDP to the ring finger is injured, the patient will be unable to fully flex the ring finger when making a fist.

Muscles Involved in the Movement of Interphalangeal Joints

The interphalangeal (IP) joints include:

  1. Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints – between proximal and middle phalanges.
  2. Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints – between middle and distal phalanges.

Movement

Muscles Involved

Innervation

Flexion of PIP joints

Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS)

Median nerve

Flexion of DIP joints

Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)

Lateral part (index & middle fingers): Median nerve

Medial part (ring & little fingers): Ulnar nerve

Extension of PIP & DIP joints

Extensor digitorum

Extensor indicis (index finger only)

Extensor digiti minimi (little finger only)

Radial nerve (posterior interosseous branch)

Assists in extension of PIP & DIP joints

Lumbricals

Palmar & dorsal interossei

Lumbricals: Lateral 2 (median nerve), medial 2 (ulnar nerve)

Interossei: Ulnar nerve

 

Median nerve (Option A): Incorrect because median nerve injury would affect multiple fingers (thumb, index, middle), not just the ring finger alone.

Flexor retinaculum (Option B): Incorrect because injury to the retinaculum leads to carpal tunnel syndrome, affecting the median nerve distribution, not isolated finger flexion.

Flexor pollicis longus (Option D): Incorrect because this muscle only flexes the thumb, not the ring finger.

questions.text: Neostriatum consists of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

Explanation:

  • The neostriatum (or striatum) consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen. These structures are functionally and anatomically linked as part of the basal ganglia, playing a crucial role in motor control and cognitive functions.

Components of the Basal Ganglia

Component

Includes

Function

Striatum (Neostriatum)

Caudate nucleus + Putamen

Main input center of the basal ganglia, receives input from the cortex

Lentiform nucleus

Putamen + Globus pallidus

Part of the extrapyramidal motor system, regulates movement

Globus pallidus

Internal (medial) and External (lateral) segments

Main output structure, modulates thalamocortical circuits

Subthalamic nucleus

Located in the diencephalon

Plays a role in modulating basal ganglia output

Substantia nigra

Located in the midbrain

Produces dopamine; degeneration leads to Parkinson’s disease

 

Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus (Option A): Incorrect because globus pallidus is not part of the neostriatum.

Globus pallidus and putamen (Option B): Incorrect because globus pallidus belongs to the paleostriatum, not neostriatum.

Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus (Option C): Incorrect because lentiform nucleus includes putamen and globus pallidus, but the neostriatum consists only of caudate and putamen.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old girl presenting with decreased best corrected visual acuity in the right eye after a school vision screening revealed diminution of acuity in the right eye without any examination findings of the eye and visual pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amblyopia

Explanation:

Decrease in best corrected visual acuity in one or both eyes with no apparent pathology of the eye and visual pathway is suggestive of Amblyopia.

Amblyopia: Definition, Types, and Clinical Characteristics:

Definition:

  • Partial, reversible vision loss in one or both eyes.
  • Absence of organic diseases of l ocular media, retina, visual pathway
  • The eye appears normal, but vision is impaired.

Types of Amblyopia:

Type

Cause

Key Features

Strabismic Amblyopia

The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus).

Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye.

Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia

Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity).

Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development.

Anisometropic Amblyopia

A significant difference in refractive error between eyes.

The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other.

Ametropic Amblyopia

High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes.

Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types.

Meridional Amblyopia

Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians.

Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree.

Clinical Characteristics:

  • Reduced Visual Acuity:
    • Affects recognition acuity more than resolution acuity.
    • Graded by severity:
      • Mild: 20/25 to 20/60
      • Moderate: 20/70 to 20/100
      • Severe: 20/200 or worse
  • Neutral Density Filter Test: Slight improvement in visual acuity through a filter (unlike organic eye diseases).
  • Crowding Phenomenon: Difficulty identifying letters on crowded charts (e.g., Snellen chart).
  • Fixation Pattern: Eccentric fixation (focusing away from the fovea) indicates severity.
  • Color Vision: Usually normal but affected in severe cases (vision below 6/36).
  • Other ocular examination: usually NO abnormalities are found (Option A)

Brain lesion (Option D): A lesion in the visual pathway can result in loss of vision but no such examination findings is mentioned.

Retinoblastoma (Option B): Retinoblastoma shows leukocoria which is absent here.

Congenital cataract (Option C): Loss of red reflex is seen in congenital cataract.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?

choices.text: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone
Collagen is synthesized in bone osteoblasts
Calcium phosphate is one of the major inorganic mineral

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen

Explanation:

  • Bone primarily contains Type I collagen, not Type II. Type I collagen provides structural support and tensile strength to bones. Type II collagen is mainly found in cartilage, not bone.

Bone Composition and Structure

Component

Function

Cells

Osteoblasts (bone formation), Osteocytes (maintenance), Osteoclasts (resorption)

Collagen Type

Type I collagen is the primary structural protein in bone

Inorganic Component

Hydroxyapatite (Calcium phosphate) provides bone rigidity

Bone Matrix

Composed of organic (collagen and proteins) and inorganic (minerals) components

 

Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone (Option A): Correct because osteocytes are the most abundant bone cells, maintaining bone matrix.

Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts (Option B): Correct because osteoblasts produce Type I collagen, a key component of bone matrix.

Calcium phosphate is one of the major inorganic minerals (Option D): Correct as hydroxyapatite (a form of calcium phosphate) is the main inorganic component of bone.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency leading to Xerophthalmia. It can be prevented by timely vitamin A prophylaxis.

 

Blindness in India:

  • Overall most common cause of blindness/visual impairment (VI): Cataract
  • Most common preventable cause of blindness: Vitamin A deficiency
  • Most common cause of blindness in children: Vitamin A deficiency
  • Most common cause of VI in children: Refractive error
  • Other causes of blindness in children: Trachoma, Retinopathy of prematurity; Congenital cataract; Ophthalmia neonatorum.

 

Proposed structure for Vision 2020, NPCB:

Tier

Number of Units

Population Norms

Components

Centres of Excellence

20

1/50 million
  • Professional Leadership
  • Strategy development
  • Continued Medical Education (CME)
  • Laying of standards and quality assurance
  • Research

Training Centres

200

1/5 million
  • Tertiary eye care including retinal surgery, corneal transplantation, glaucoma surgery, etc.
  • Training and CME

Service Centres

2000

1/500000
  • Cataract Surgery
  • Other common eye surgeries
  • Facilities for refraction
  • Referral services

Vision Centres

20,000

1/50000
  • Refraction and prescription of glasses
  • Primary eye care
  • School eye screening programme
  • Screening and referral services

questions.text: Killian’s dehiscence is seen between?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cricopharyngeus and Thyropharyngeus

Explanation:

  • Killian’s dehiscence is a potential weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall, located between the cricopharyngeus (inferior part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor) and thyropharyngeus (superior part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor).
  • This site is prone to the formation of Zenker’s diverticulum, a pharyngeal pouch due to increased pressure during swallowing.

Pharyngeal Muscles and Weak Areas

Pharyngeal Muscle

Function

Clinical Relevance

Thyropharyngeus (Superior part of Inferior Constrictor)

Constricts pharynx

Forms upper boundary of Killian's dehiscence

Cricopharyngeus (Inferior part of Inferior Constrictor)

Acts as upper esophageal sphincter

Forms lower boundary of Killian's dehiscence

Killian’s Dehiscence

Weak area between these muscles

Site of Zenker’s diverticulum

 

Palatopharyngeus and Cricopharyngeus (Option A): Incorrect because palatopharyngeus is a longitudinal muscle of the pharynx, unrelated to Killian’s dehiscence.

Thyropharyngeus and Palatopharyngeus (Option B): Incorrect because palatopharyngeus is not involved in this weak area.

Palatopharyngeus and Salpingopharyngeus (Option D): Incorrect as these muscles are involved in pharyngeal elevation, not the formation of Killian’s dehiscence.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy who showed a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination showing Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

A paediatric patient with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and Histiopathology revealing Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes is diagnostic of Retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette is an example of True rosette and is a highly specific feature of Retinoblastoma.

 

 

Clinical features and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma:

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

 

 

Medulloblastoma (Option B): is a rapidly growing tumor of the brain, is unlikely to present with eye symptoms initially. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Synaptophysin+, CD56+, GFAP+.

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C): presents with acute painful proptosis. Usually seen in boys in the 1st decade of life. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Desmin+.

 

Astrocytoma (Option D): Histopathology would reveal Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells, Eye manifestations are unlikely to be seen in Astrocytoma.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a man of 45 years who arrives at the emergency department with an abrupt loss of vision and experiencing painful movements of the eye? Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is observed in the affected eye. Further visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma in the same eye.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Optic neuritis

 

Explanation:

Clinical scenario of sudden visual loss associated with Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is suggestive of Optic Neuritis.

 

Optic neuritis:

Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis (Option D)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features
  • Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.
  • A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).
  • Optic atrophy present

Clinical features
  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Uhthoff's symptom: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, occurs in patients with isolated optic neuritis.
  • Pulfrich's phenomenon: Depth perception may be impaired, particularly for the moving object.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

Management of Optic neuritis:

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).
           

 

 

 

Optic nerve glioma (Option A): is a tumor that can affect the optic nerve, but it is more commonly seen in children and young adults. MRI shows fusiform thickening of the intra-orbital portion of the optic nerve.

 

Eale's disease (Option C): Also known as retinal vasculitis, typically presents with recurrent episodes of retinal hemorrhages, floaters, and vision loss in young males.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who wears contact lenses and has been experiencing eye watering, redness, and a sensation of having a foreign object in the eye for the last two months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

A history of prolonged soft contact lens use, along with symptoms like bilateral itching, redness, watery discharge, and the presence of large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, points towards a diagnosis of Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis.

 

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis:

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

 

 

Follicular Conjunctivitis (Option A): is the most common clinical form of Viral Conjunctivitis (Adenocirus, Molluscum contagiosum, Herpes simplex, COVID-19). Presents as a milder form of acute conjunctivitis (less symptoms). Follicular appearance of conjunctiva is seen on examination.

 

Spring Catarrh (Option B): Other name of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (type I & IV > type I hypersensitivity reaction), is characterized by seasonal symptoms, cobblestone-like papillae, limbal thickening with Horner-Trantas dots, and potential corneal involvement, unlike giant papillary conjunctivitis, which typically presents with large papillae associated with contact lens use.

 

Trachoma (Option D): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next course of action in managing a male patient, aged 40, who presents with widespread abdominal pain and has a confirmed history of Crohn's disease, as well as rigidity and guarding observed during a physical examination, with ileal perforation being detected on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy

Explanation:

Ileal perforation in Crohn’s disease is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate surgical intervention.

Primary repair vs. Ileostomy:

  • Primary repair is not ideal due to inflamed, friable tissue and high recurrence risk.
  • An ileostomy is preferred to divert faecal contents and allow healing before later reversal.

Without surgery, the patient risks septic shock, multi-organ failure, and death.

Antibiotics and NPO (Option A) Supportive care alone is insufficient for a perforation. Antibiotics help control infection but do not treat the perforation. Surgery is mandatory to remove the perforated segment and control peritonitis.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option B) Not useful for small bowel (ileal) disease. Contraindicated in perforation due to risk of further bowel injury.

CT abdomen (Option D) Imaging is already done, confirming perforation. Further delay increases morbidity and mortality. The next step is definitive surgical intervention, not additional imaging.

questions.text: Which investigation is most suitable for localizing a foreign body in the eye of an industrial worker admitted to the hospital due to an eye injury caused by cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CT

Explanation:

CT scan is the investigation of choice in case of an intraocular foreign body and MRI is contraindicated in cases where there is a risk of metallic foreign bodies.

Intraocular Foreign Bodies (IOFBs):

Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred. (Option C)
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs. (Option A)
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.(Option B)
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger. The swelling reaches the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Indirect inguinal hernia

Explanation:

Origin: Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, entering the deep inguinal ring.

Path: Passes through the inguinal canal, sometimes reaching the scrotum.

Complete reduction through deep inguinal ring: Classic for an indirect hernia.

Gurgling sound: Indicates the presence of bowel loops within the hernia sac.

Femoral hernia (Option A) Located below the inguinal ligament, more common in women, and does not extend into the scrotum. No gurgling sound or reducibility through the deep ring.

Direct inguinal hernia (Option B): Bulges through Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Does not extend into the scrotum and is usually more diffuse, not reducible through the deep ring.

Umbilical hernia (Option D) Occurs at the umbilicus, unrelated to the inguinal region.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Arcuate fasciculus

Explanation:

  • Difficulty in repeating spoken words, trouble with naming and writing, yet intact comprehension of spoken language, suggests Conduction Aphasia.
  • It's caused by a disconnection between language centers in the brain, possibly affecting the Arcuate Fasciculus.
  • This white matter tract links Broca's area (speech production) with Wernicke's area (language comprehension).
  • Damage here can lead to symptoms like those described in conduction aphasia, where patients struggle to repeat words or phrases accurately despite understanding them.

Aphasia Type

Area Affected

Features

Broca's Aphasia

Left frontal lobe (Broca's area)

Non-fluent speech, difficulty forming sentences, good comprehension, and poor writing/speech output.

Wernicke's Aphasia

Left temporal lobe (Wernicke's area)

Fluent speech with normal grammar, but speech is nonsensical or meaningless, poor comprehension.

Conduction Aphasia

Arcuate fasciculus (connecting Broca's and Wernicke's areas)

Difficulty repeating words or phrases, fluent speech with errors, good comprehension.

Global Aphasia

Widespread damage to left hemisphere (Broca's, Wernicke's, and arcuate fasciculus)

Severe communication deficits: non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and inability to repeat.

 

Incorrect Options:

Anterior commissure (Option B): The anterior commissure is involved in the connection between the two cerebral hemispheres but is not typically associated with the specific language symptoms described.

Corpus callosum (Option C): Damage to the corpus callosum can result in a variety of symptoms but is not specifically associated with the language deficits described.

Fornix (Option D): The fornix is a white matter structure involved in memory processes but is not typically associated with the language symptoms described.

questions.text: Please identify the medical condition depicted in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Entropion

Explanation:

The above image shows inward rolling of the lower lid margin towards the globe, which is suggestive of Entropion.

 

Grading of entropion:

Grade-I

Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled

Grade-II

includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip

Grade-III

Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled

Types of Entropion:

Type

Description

Etiology

1) Congenital Entropion

Present since birth, more common in the lower eyelid

  • Lower Eyelid: Improper development of lower lid retractors.
  • Upper Eyelid: Mechanical effects due to microphthalmos.

2) Cicatricial Entropion

Commonly involves the upper eyelid.

 
  • Common causes: Trachoma, chemical burns, pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, symblepharon.

3) Senile (Involutional) Entropion

Affects the lower eyelid in elderly individuals.
  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis.
  • Laxity of orbital septum

4) Mechanical Entropion

Lack of support from the globe to the lids.
  • Occurs in conditions like phthisis bulbi, enophthalmos and after enucleation or evisceration operations.

Ectropion (Option B): Outward rolling of the eyelid away from the globe.

Trichiasis (Option C): Misdirection of the eyelids.

Ptosis (Option D): Drooping of the eyelid of the eyelid is known as ptosis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old patient who has experienced the passage of mucus and blood in their stool, with inflammation predominantly observed in the rectum during sigmoidoscopy, and the presence of crypt abscess detected during biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcerative colitis:

Explanation:

Features

Ulcerative colitis

Crohn’s disease

Location

Limited to colon and rectum

Can involve any part of the GI tract

Distribution

Diffuse lesion

Patchy, with skip lesions.

Gross appearance
  • Mucosal erythema and granularity
  • Broad-based ulcers with a continuous pattern
  • Pseudopolyps
  • Mucosal atrophy
  • Smooth, continuous inflammation
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Cobblestone appearance
  • Fistulae, strictures, abscesses
  • Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping)

Complications
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Colonic dilation
  • Mucosal bridges
  • Strictures
  • Fistulae

Irritable bowel syndrome (Option B) presents with features of abdominal discomfort, bloating, and altered bowel habits (diarrhoea or constipation). No blood in stool, no crypt abscesses, and no inflammation on biopsy.

Crohn's disease (Option C) presents with features of skip lesions, transmural inflammation, and non-caseating granulomas. It can affect any part of the GI tract (mouth to anus), usually sparing the rectum. Fistulas, strictures, cobblestone appearance on endoscopy.

Pseudomembranous colitis (Option D) presents with profuse, watery diarrhoea after recent antibiotic use. Pseudomembranes (yellow plaques) are seen on colonoscopy. No crypt abscesses and inflammation is not limited to the rectum.

questions.text: In a 3-year-old child who has recently developed 15-degree accommodative esotropia, what is the most effective treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Refractive correction

Explanation:

Refraction correction would be the most effective treatment approach in a child with Accommodative esotropia.

Accommodative esotropia:

 

Accommodative Refractive Esotropia

Accommodative Non-refractive Esotropia

Accommodative Mixed Esotropia

Cause

High hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)

Abnormal large AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio

Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/ A ratio

Treatment

Correction of hypermetropia (spectacles)

 
  • Corrected by bifocal glasses with +3 DS added for near vision
  • Miotics (Echothiophate)
  • Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

Orthoptic exercise (Option A): Orthoptic exercises are used for the improvement in the binocular vision to treat paralytic squint .

Surgery (Option B): Surgeries are generally performed to treat non-refractive/ non-accommodative esotropia.

INTACS (Option D): INTACS (intracorneal ring segments) are used for the management of keratoconus.

questions.text: Which of the following lenses would be recommended to correct myopia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Concave

Explanation:

Concave lenses (diverging lenses) are used to correct Myopia.

 

Myopia - management:

General measures
  • Balanced diet
  • Visual hygiene: Posture correction, adequate illumination, reducing usage of video display units (VDUs)

Optical

Concave lenses are prescribed: Spectacles/ contact lenses (Option B)

Surgical

Radial Keratotomy (RK):

  • Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D).
  • No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK.

 

Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK):

  • It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer.
  • Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D.

 

Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE):

  • A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea.
  • Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism.

 

Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation:

  • Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens.
  • Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery.

Convex lens (Option A): Used in the case of presbyopia and in the case of hypermetropia.

Cylindrical lens (Option C): Used for correction of astigmatism.

Abraham lens (Option D): A 66 D lens used for peripheral iridotomy with Nd:Yag laser.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt with dilated veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Varicocele

Explanation:

Varicocele: Dilatation and tortuosity of the pampiniform plexus of veins and testicular veins.

Varicocele

Common Occurrence
  • More common in tall, thin young men
  • More frequent on the left side but can be bilateral

Causes
  • Idiopathic
  • Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein
  • Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein
  • Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein

Effects
  • Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility

Symptoms
  • Swelling at the root of the scrotum
  • Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum
  • "Bag of worms" feeling
  • Impulse on coughing
  • Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma)

Investigations
  • Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin
  • Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumours
  • Semen analysis

Treatment

  • Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein
  • Ligation of veins
  • Excision of veins

Hydrocele (Option A) is an abnormal collection of serous fluid in some part of the processus vaginalis, usually the tunica.

Testicular torsion (Option C) is seen in a teenager or young adult male. It is easily missed. Pain can be referred to the right iliac fossa, and appendicitis will be suspected unless the scrotum is examined.

Epididymo Orchitis (Option D) is intrascrotal swelling, most common among intra-scrotal swelling. It is usually caused as a result of the retrograde ascent of Pathogens.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position, and the opening is located at the 11 o’clock position, 2 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening, and where does the internal opening start?

choices.text: 12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter
11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter
6 o’clock and crypt of the dentate line

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) 11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter

Explanation:

Goodsall's Rule:

  • Anterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the anterior half of the anus (front side), the fistula usually follows a direct path to the internal opening within the anus.
  • Posterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the posterior half of the anus (back side), the fistula typically follows a curved path, forming a horseshoe shape, and opens internally at the midline of the posterior anus.

The exception to Goodsall's Rule:

  • Anterior external opening more than 3 cm from the Anus: If the external opening is located more than 3 cm away from the anal margin (anterior side), the fistula is likely to track to the posterior midline, rather than following a direct path as Goodsall's Rule would typically suggest.

12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter (Option A): The external sphincter is not the primary site for fistula origin; fistulas originate from the crypts in the dentate line.

11 o’clock, and at internal anal sphincter (Option C), does not follow Goodsall’s Rule; posterior fistulae track to the midline (6 o’clock).

9 o’clock and at the anal verge (Option D): This does not match the typical fistula pattern based on the location given.

questions.text: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 33

Explanation:

  • Pressure sores (also called decubitus ulcers or pressure ulcers) occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin, leading to ischemia and tissue necrosis.
  • The critical pressure threshold that exceeds capillary perfusion pressure and causes ischemia is greater than 33 mmHg.
  • Normal capillary pressure is around 25–32 mmHg, so pressure exceeding 33 mmHg leads to inadequate blood supply and tissue damage.

45 mmHg, 54 mmHg, 67 mmHg (Option B, C and D)

  • While higher pressures can accelerate tissue necrosis, ischemia begins at pressures just above 33 mmHg.
  • Higher pressures are often seen in bony prominences (e.g., sacrum, heels), but even lower sustained pressure over time can lead to ulcers.

questions.text: What would be the best treatment option for a patient who has been diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma and has a tumour measuring 10 cm in size, located at the lower part of the kidney, and has negative regional lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radical nephrectomy

Explanation:

Tumor size: The tumour is 10 cm, which classifies it as T2 RCC (T2a if 7–10 cm, T2b if >10 cm but still confined to the kidney).

Location: Since the tumour is large and located in the lower part of the kidney, a partial nephrectomy is not feasible due to a high risk of incomplete resection or complications.

No lymph node involvement: There is no evidence of metastasis (N0M0), making surgery the best option.

Partial nephrectomy (Option B) Indicated for tumours <7 cm (T1) when feasible. A 10 cm tumour is too large for nephron-sparing surgery.

Radiotherapy (Option C) RCC is chemo-resistant. Systemic therapy is considered only for metastatic disease (stage IV).

Chemotherapy (Option D) Chemotherapy isn't generally advised for renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who has a scrotal mass on the left side that is hard in texture, has uneven edges, does not decrease in size when lying down or manipulated, does not have a cough impulse, but shows enlargement in the para-aortic lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Correct answer D) Metastasizing testicular tumor

Explanation:

  • Scrotal mass on the left side → indicate a testicular pathology.
  • Hard texture with uneven edges → Indicative of a solid tumor, likely testicular cancer (e.g., seminoma or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor).
  • Does not decrease in size when lying down or manipulated → Rules out conditions like hydrocele or hernia.
  • No cough impulse → Further rules out an inguinal hernia.
  • Enlarged para-aortic lymph nodes → Strongly indicates metastatic spread from a testicular malignancy, as testicular tumors typically metastasize to retroperitoneal (para-aortic) lymph nodes.

Hydrocele (Option A ) Soft, cystic, transilluminates, and size decreases on lying down. No involvement of para-aortic lymph nodes.

Direct Inguinal Hernia (Option B) Usually reducible, with a positive cough impulse. Does not cause para-aortic lymph node enlargement.

Indirect Inguinal Hernia (Option C) Often soft, reducible, and may extend into the scrotum. Positive cough impulse. Does not cause para-aortic lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: What is the most probable outcome for the patient after undergoing gastrectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

Gastrectomy (partial or total removal of the stomach) significantly affects nutrient absorption, particularly Vitamin B12, due to the loss of intrinsic factors.

  • Intrinsic factor (IF), produced by gastric parietal cells, is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.
  • Gastrectomy removes parietal cells, leading to intrinsic factor deficiency and causing impaired vitamin B12 absorption.
  • This leads to pernicious anemia, presenting with megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and glossitis.
  • Management: Lifelong B12 supplementation (IM or high-dose oral).

Folic acid deficiency (Option A) Folate is absorbed in the proximal jejunum, which remains intact after gastrectomy. It is not a direct consequence of gastrectomy unless there is associated malnutrition.

Gastric ulcer (Option C) Gastrectomy reduces acid secretion, lowering the risk of gastric ulcers. However, marginal ulcers may develop at anastomotic sites in certain procedures.

Constipation (Option D) Gastrectomy does not directly cause constipation; patients may experience dumping syndrome or diarrhoea instead.
